questions.text: Which of the following can be used for induction of anesthesia, maintenance and can be safely used in endotracheal intubation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Sevoflurane

 

Explanation:

 

Sevoflurane is a versatile inhalation anesthetic that can be used for both the induction and maintenance of anesthesia. Its sweet smell makes it suitable for inhalational induction, especially in pediatric patients and others who might find pungent agents unpleasant. Sevoflurane also provides a smooth transition for endotracheal intubation due to its bronchodilatory effects and stable hemodynamic profile. Additionally, its low blood-gas solubility coefficient allows for rapid induction and emergence from anesthesia, which is beneficial in a surgical setting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Halothane: While Halothane can be used for induction and maintenance of anesthesia, it has a higher risk of hepatotoxicity and arrhythmias. It is also less commonly used in modern practice compared to Sevoflurane.

 

Option B. Desflurane: Desflurane is typically used for maintenance rather than induction due to its pungent odor and tendency to cause airway irritation. It also requires a special heated vaporizer due to its high vapor pressure.

 

Option D. Isoflurane: Isoflurane is primarily used for maintenance of anesthesia rather than induction due to its pungent smell and potential to cause airway irritation. It is less suitable for inhalational induction compared to Sevoflurane.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Sevoflurane is an ideal agent for both the induction and maintenance of anesthesia and is safe for use during endotracheal intubation due to its favorable properties.

choices.text: Rabbit ileal loop for enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli
Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a suspected dengue patient
Injecting a hamster with splenic biopsy for diagnosis of leishmaniasis
Intradermal test on guinea pigs for toxigenicity of Corynebacterium diphtheria

questions.text: Which of the following is a Xenodiagnostic method? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a suspected dengue patient

 

Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a suspected dengue patient is the Xeno diagnostic method among the given options.

 

Xenodiagnosis is a diagnostic method used to document the presence of infectious disease microorganisms or pathogens by exposing possibly infected tissue to a vector and then examining the vector for the presence of the microorganisms or pathogens it may have ingested.

 

Uses -

 

  1. Chagas disease diagnosis. Reduviid bugs (vector/foreign host) grown in laboratories are permitted to feed on suspicious patients (original host). The feces of the bugs are checked under a microscope for amastigote forms of the pathogen Trypanosoma cruzi after 4-5 weeks.
  2. Identification of dengue virus – viruses are inoculated into the mosquitoes . The virus can be demonstrated easily as it multiplies in different organs of the mosquito (Aedes aegypti, Aedes albopictus, and Toxorhynchites) and can be easily demonstrated.
  3. In Trichinella spirals infection, Laboratory rats are used as a T. spiralis vector by feeding them pieces of muscle biopsies from suspected patients. The infected lab rats' muscles can be seen to contain T. spiralis larvae.

 

Advantage of xenodiagnosis: helpful in cases where low pathogen count makes direct microscopic diagnosis DIFFICULT.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Rabbit ileal loop for enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli: Incorrect: This is not a xenodiagnostic method. It involves testing the virulence of enterotoxigenic E. coli by observing the fluid accumulation in ligated sections of rabbit intestine.

 

Option C. Injecting a hamster with splenic biopsy for diagnosis of leishmaniasis: Incorrect: This method involves animal inoculation rather than using a vector to diagnose an infection.

 

Option D. Intradermal test on guinea pigs for toxigenicity of Corynebacterium diphtheria: Incorrect: This is a virulence testing method to determine the presence of toxigenic strains of Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

 

Educational Objective

 

Xenodiagnosis involves using a vector to ingest potentially infected tissue or fluids and then examining the vector for the presence of the pathogen, making it particularly useful in cases where direct detection of the pathogen is challenging due to low numbers.

questions.text: Match the following syndromes with their respective karyotypes?  (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-A, 2-B, 3-D, 4-C

 

Explanation:

 

  • MRKH syndrome (Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser): This syndrome has a karyotype of 46XX.
  • Swyer Syndrome: This condition is characterized by 46XY karyotype.
  • Turner Syndrome: This is due to monosomy X, having a karyotype of 45XO.
  • Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome: This condition occurs in individuals with a karyotype of 46XY, where there is a complete androgen insensitivity, resulting in a phenotypically female appearance despite having male (XY) chromosomes.

 

Matching:

 

  1. MRKH: 46XX
  2. Swyer Syndrome: 46XY
  3. Turner Syndrome: 45XO
  4. Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome: 46XY

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the karyotypes associated with different syndromes helps in diagnosing and managing these conditions effectively. MRKH is associated with 46XX, Swyer syndrome with 46XY, Turner syndrome with 45XO, and Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome with 46XY.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg 446,447

questions.text: What is the normal uterocervical length?  (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 7 cm

 

Explanation:

 

  • The normal length of the uterine cavity, including the cervical canal, is usually 6-7 cm. This measurement is essential in gynecological evaluations and procedures.
  • This measurement helps in assessing normal uterine anatomy and can be used in various clinical procedures such as the insertion of intrauterine devices (IUDs).
  • Ovary: The ovary measures about 3 cm x 2 cm x 1 cm.
  • Fallopian Tube: The length of the Fallopian tube is about 10 cm, and the lumen is 1-2 mm at the isthmus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The normal length of the uterine cavity, including the cervical canal, is 6-7 cm.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition Pg 25, Dutta's textbook of gynecology 6th edition Pg 7

questions.text:
What is the sequence of performing a Thomas test?(INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Passive flexion of affected hip
  2. Overcorrection on the normal side
  3. Measure the flexion angle
  4. Checking for lumbar lordosis
questions.solution:
Ans. D) IV, II, I, III

 

THOMAS TEST

 

  • It is used to assess for hip flexion contracture and psoas syndrome.
  • It is especially useful when the fixed flexion deformity is masked by excessive lordosis.
  • Steps:

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence of performing the Thomas test is:

 

Checking for lumbar lordosis

                        ↓

Overcorrection on the normal side

                        ↓

Passive flexion of affected hip

                        ↓

Measure the flexion angle

questions.text: The leading cause of bladder outlet obstruction in male children is: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Posterior urethral valve

 

This is the most common cause of lower urinary tract obstruction in male infants. PUV is a congenital malformation found only in boys where there is an abnormal fold of tissue in the posterior urethra, preventing normal urine outflow and leading to bladder outlet obstruction. The condition can lead to hydronephrosis if not treated promptly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urethral atresia: This is a rare congenital anomaly where a segment of the urethra fails to canalize or develop. It leads to complete obstruction of the urethra, and while it does cause bladder outlet obstruction, it is less common than PUV in male children.

 

Option C. Anterior urethral valve: This is a rare congenital anomaly and is much less common than the posterior urethral valve. While it can cause obstruction, its prevalence and significance in causing bladder outlet obstruction in male children are far less than that of PUV.

 

Option D. Ureterocele: A ureterocele is a cystic dilation of the terminal ureter within the bladder. It can cause obstruction of the ureter itself. They are not the leading cause in male children when compared to PUV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most frequent cause of bladder outflow obstruction in male children is the posterior urethral valve (PUV).
  • PUV is a membranous fold located in the posterior urethra, typically found just distal to the verumontanum. It is thought to occur due to the persistence of the urogenital membrane.
  • Urethral obstruction can cause dilation of the posterior urethral valve, bladder, and bilateral hydronephrosis, leading to a keyhole sign on prenatal ultrasound and potentially oligohydramnios.
  • If not detected prenatally, PUV may present postnatally as a newborn or young infant with urinary tract symptoms, abdominal distension or and recurrent UTIs.
  • Left untreated, PUV may result in chronic kidney disease, bladder dysfunction, and vesicoureteral reflux.
  • Diagnosis of PUV is typically based on the presence of an elongated posterior valve during the voiding phase of the voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG).

choices.text: Atypical antipsychotics is the first line treatment
Prevalence is 7 -10 percent in general population

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement about obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD)? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Depression is a common comorbidity

 

Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) is a condition characterized by intrusive, repetitive thoughts (obsessions) and the urge to perform repetitive behaviors or rituals (compulsions).

 

Many individuals with OCD also suffer from depression. The two conditions can coexist and may even be related in some manner.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atypical antipsychotics is the first line treatment: This is false. The first-line treatments for OCD are selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), clomipramine and cognitive-behavioral therapy. Atypical antipsychotics may be added as an adjunctive treatment in patients who do not respond to standard treatments.

 

Option B. Prevalence is 7-10 percent in general population: This is incorrect. The prevalence of OCD in the general population is around 2-3%.

 

Option D. Contamination is an uncommon obsession: False. Contamination obsessions are the most common types of obsessions in OCD. Individuals may fear germs or becoming ill and may wash their hands excessively as a result.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

OCD is characterized by obsessions and compulsions. Life time prevalence is around 2-3% and is more common among females. Most common presentation is obsessive contamination with compulsive washing followed by pathological doubt with repeated checking. Most common comorbidity is depression. First line treatment includes SSRIs and chlomipramine. Atypical antipsychotics are used as adjunctive treatment.

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 95-97.

questions.text: All of the following are associated with massive splenomegaly except: (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aplastic anemia

 

All the above are associated with massive splenomegaly except aplastic anemia.

 

Aplastic anemia is characterized by pancytopenia (a reduction in red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets) due to the failure of the bone marrow. A key feature of aplastic anemia is the absence of splenomegaly. In fact, the presence of splenomegaly in a patient with pancytopenia often argues against the diagnosis of aplastic anemia.

 

There are several potential causes of splenomegaly:

 

  1. Liver disease (cirrhosis, hepatitis): Parenchymal liver disease causes increased vascular pressure leading to an increase in spleen size.
  2. Hematologic malignancies (lymphomas, leukemias, myeloproliferative disorders): Neoplastic cells cause infiltration of the spleen leading to splenomegaly.
  3. Venous thrombosis (portal or hepatic vein thrombosis): This leads to an increase in vascular pressure leading to splenomegaly.
  4. Splenic congestion (venous thrombosis, portal hypertension, congestive heart failure).
  5. Cytopenias (Immune thrombocytopenic purpura, autoimmune hemolytic anemia, immune-mediated neutropenia, Felty syndrome): Immune-mediated destruction of red blood cells, white blood cells or platelets lead to functional splenomegaly
  6. Splenic sequestration (pediatric sickle cell disease, hemolytic anemias, thalassemias).
  7. Acute or chronic infection (bacterial endocarditis, infectious mononucleosis, HIV, malaria, tuberculosis, histiocytosis, abscess).
  8. Connective tissue diseases (systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis, Adult-onset Still's disease, and some familial autoinflammatory syndromes).[4][5]
  9. Infiltrative disorders (sarcoidosis, amyloidosis, glycogen storage diseases).
  10. Splenic sequestration (pediatric sickle cell, hemolytic anemias, thalassemias).
  11. Focal lesions (hemangiomas, abscess, cysts, metastasis).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aplastic anemia is a syndrome of chronic primary hematopoietic failure. This results in pancytopenia (anemia, neutropenia, and thrombocytopenia). Splenomegaly is characteristically absent; if it is present, the diagnosis of aplastic anemia should be seriously questioned. Similarly, splenomegaly is also never seen in cases of ITP.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg. 1239, 1173

questions.text: Given below is an electron microscopic image of the lung tissue. A patient infected with SARS-COV2 presents with ARDS. The infection would affect and expand which of the labelled layers? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A  

 

The image given in the question demonstrates the electron microscopic image of the blood-air barrier in the lungs. Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) has been set in this patient with COVID-19. Damage to the endothelial (Labelled as A, with inflammation, is the key initiating event and the basis of lung damage. Neutrophils play a significant role in tissue injury in this condition.

 

 

 

The electron micrograph shows at high magnification three components of the air-blood barrier in the alveolar septum. Gaseous exchange occurs across, 1) the cytoplasm of a type I alveolar cell or pneumocyte, P1; 2) the fused basal laminas (basement membranes) of type I alveolar and endothelial cells, BM; and 3) the cytoplasm of an endothelial cell, E, enclosing a blood capillary. Note the erythrocyte, Er, present within the lumen of the blood capillary. A fourth component of the air-blood barrier, surfactant, is not preserved in routine histological sections.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Basement Membrane: While the basement membrane is part of the blood-air barrier, it is not the primary site of injury in ARDS.

 

Option C. Type I Alveolar cell/Pneumocyte: Although these cells are affected in ARDS, the endothelial cells are typically the first to be damaged.

 

Option D. Erythrocyte: The erythrocyte is not structurally affected by ARDS but rather suffers the consequences of impaired gas exchange due to endothelial and alveolar damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In ARDS, especially in cases associated with SARS-CoV-2 infection, the primary injury occurs in the endothelial cells of the blood-air barrier, leading to inflammation, increased permeability, and subsequent respiratory failure.

questions.text: The maximum oxygen flow rate which can be kept with a conventional Hudson oxygen mask is?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 10 L/min

 

Explanation:

 

The maximum oxygen flow rate which can be kept with a conventional oxygen mask (Simple Face Mask, also known as Hudson mask) is 10 L/min. This is a standard setting for delivering oxygen to patients who require moderate levels of oxygen supplementation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 5 L/min: While 5 L/min can be used, it is not the maximum flow rate for a Hudson mask.

 

Option B. 15 L/min: This flow rate is generally used with a non-rebreather mask rather than a conventional Hudson mask.

 

Option D. 20 L/min: This flow rate exceeds the capacity of most conventional oxygen delivery systems like the Hudson mask.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The maximum flow rate for a conventional Hudson oxygen mask is 10 L/min.

questions.text: A man presents with the following lesion after traumatic inoculation. Identify the causative organism? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sporothrix schencki

 

The above lesion is most likely caused by  Sporothrix schencki (S. schenckii)

 

Sporotrichosis, also known as "Rose Gardener's Disease," is a subacute or chronic infection caused by the saprophytic dimorphic fungus Sporothrix schenckii.

 

Sporothrix schenckii is a dimorphic fungus. In its saprophytic stage or when cultured at 25°C, it assumes a filamentous form, composed of hyaline, septate hyphae 1 to 2 μm wide, with conidiogenous cells arising from undifferentiated hyphae forming conidia in groups on small, clustered denticles. These one-celled conidia are tear shaped to clavate and do not yield chains. The S. schenckii colonies never become cottony or floccose.

Infection with the dimorphic soil fungus S schenckii is usually transmitted by the mold form from organic matter through cutaneous inoculation. The mycosis has also been transmitted from animals through bites or scratches.

 

The initial reddish, necrotic, nodular papule of cutaneous sporotrichosis generally appears 1-10 weeks after a penetrating skin injury. The lesion is a suppurating granuloma that consists of histiocytes and giant cells, with neutrophils that accumulate in the center and that are surrounded by lymphocytes and plasma cells.

 

The fungal infection spreads from the initial lesion along lymphatic channels, forming the chain of indolent nodular and ulcerating lesions typical of lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis.

 

Other tissues are involved by direct extension and, less often, by hematogenous dissemination. The most common extracutaneous infection sites are in the bones, joints, tendon sheaths, and bursae. Hematogenous dissemination—particularly in immunocompromised hosts—results in widely disseminated cutaneous and visceral infection, including meningitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mycobacterium scrofulaceum is a scotochromogen. It may cause pulmonary disease and local lymphadenitis, primarily in the submandibular and submaxillary regions. It is usually a benign, self-limited condition with no systemic symptoms except for mild neck pain.

 

Option C. Eumyectoma or mycetoma also called as Madura foot, is a chronic subcutaneous granulomatous soft-tissue infection. The etiological agent may be fungal (eumycetoma) or bacterial (actinomycetoma) and appears under microscopic examination as hyphae or thin filaments, respectively. The cardinal features of the disease are tumefaction, sinus formation, and presentation of grains or granules in draining exudate.

 

Option D. Phialophora verrucosa is a common cause of chromoblastomycosis. A primary lesion is represented by an erythematous papule or a warty growth, which gradually enlarges from the site of infection assuming various forms and sizes. The infection may occur anywhere on the body, however most frequently it affects limbs, especially feet and shins. The fungus is seen as round or irregular, dark brown, yeast-like bodies with septae, (known as sclerotic bodies) on histology.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sporothrix schenckii, the cause of sporotrichosis, typically presents as a chain of nodular and ulcerating lesions along lymphatic channels following traumatic inoculation, earning it the name "Rose Gardener's Disease."

questions.text: Identify the type of drain: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Closed

 

The image displays a Romovac drain placed after mastectomy, which is a closed-type drain. Drains are utilized at surgical sites to collect air or fluid buildup, promoting wound healing by preventing cavity formation. Drains can be prophylactic in elective surgeries and therapeutic in emergency surgeries, with open, semi-open, and closed types.

 

They carry out their actions through suction

 

  • Eg. Romovac drain, Jackson Pratt drain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Open: They are based on the principle of gravity or capillary effect

 

  • Eg. Corrugated drain, Foley’s catheter etc.\

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Romovac drain is a closed negative suction drain placed in subcutaneous tissue and indicated in modified radical mastectomy, subcutaneous swelling excision, and amputations. Other specialized drains include chest drains for air removal from the pleural cavity and T-tubes for bile drainage after surgical exploration of the bile duct.

choices.text: Death rate of a population adjusted to a standard age distribution
Death rate of a population adjusted to a standard sex distribution
Removal of bias due to different age group population in different countries
To eliminate age structure of different countries

questions.text: You are a researcher studying global mortality rates, and you notice substantial differences in the age structures of various countries. Recognizing that direct comparisons could be misleading due to these differences, you explore methods to equalize or adjust the mortality data to get a more accurate comparative view. In your research, you come across the term "standardized age mortality ratio." Which of the following best describes this concept? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Death rate of a population adjusted to a standard age distribution 

 

The standardized age mortality ratio serves as an indicator for the population's mortality rate adjusted to a standardized age distribution.

 

Standardization of Death Rates

 

  • While comparison of death rates of two populations, ‘crude death rate is not the right yardstick’, as age-compositions are different
  • Age-adjustment or age-standardization removes confounding effect of different age structures
  • Standardization may be direct or indirect
  • Standardization is carried out beginning by using a ‘Standard Population’

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Death rate of a population adjusted to a standard sex distribution: Incorrect. Standardization typically adjusts for age, not sex.

 

Option C. Removal of bias due to different age group populations in different countries: Incorrect. This describes the purpose of age standardization, not the definition of standardized age mortality ratio.

 

Option D. To eliminate age structure of different countries: Incorrect. Age standardization accounts for, but does not eliminate, age structure differences.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The standardized age mortality ratio adjusts the death rate of a population to a standard age distribution, allowing for more accurate comparisons between populations with different age structures.

 

Additional Information

 

Types of Standardized Death Rates

 

Direct standardization:

 

  • Method:
    • Age-specific rates of the population (whose crude death rate is to be standardized) is applied 
    • on a standard population
    • Total expected deaths calculated
    • Total expected deaths divided by total standard population to yield standardized death rate
  • Feasibility:
    • Availability of age-specific death rates (ASDR)
    • Availability of population in each age group

 

Indirect standardization: Standardized mortality ratio (SMR): Is simplest and most useful form

 

  • Method: Calculate expected deaths, assuming that study group experiences the death rates of a standard population
  • Feasibility: Permits adjustment where age-specific rates are not available or are unstable because of small numbers
  • Examples of indirect Standardization:

  • Standardized mortality ratio (SMR) = Observed deaths/ Expected deaths × 100

  • Life Table Analysis

  • Survival Analysis

choices.text: Pigmented septate hyphae at 90 degrees, Mucormycosis
Right angle branching septate hyphae, Fusarium
Acute angle branching septate hyphae, Aspergillus

questions.text: A patient presented with fever, dyspnea, palpitations, and tachycardia. The echocardiography revealed vegetation in the septal leaflets. Tissue sections from them reveal the following findings as shown in the image. What is the most likely implicated agent? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Acute angle branching septate hyphae, Aspergillus

 

The given clinical history is suggestive of infective valvulitis with mycotic vegetation. Histologic finding shows an aggregate of fungal hypae with acute angle branching and rare fruiting body (GMS stain) suggestive of aspergillus.

 

Aspergillus – septate, acute branching (40 degrees), and form fruiting bodies. Aspergillus hyphae with the distinct fruiting body can be distinguished from Pseudallescheria boydii and Fusarium spp. by morphology alone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mucor - The fungal forms of mucormycosis are broad, non-septate hyphae. They are wider than Aspergillus species and branch irregularly. The angle of branching is greater than other organisms, and usually approaches 90°.

 

 

Option B. Fusarium - Disseminated fusariosis presents with nodular or necrotic painful skin lesions. It cannot be distinguished from aspergillus by morphology alone and requires culture for identification.

 

Option C. Rhizopus - The main difference between Mucor and Rhizopus is that the Mucor does not have rhizoids and stolons while Rhizopus has both rhizoids and stolons. Further, Mucor has branched sporangiophore while the sporangiophore of Rhizopus is generally unbranched. Also, the Mucor does not have apophyses whereas, the Rhizopus has apophyses in the sporangia.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Aspergillus: Typically seen as septate hyphae with acute angle branching on histological stains such as GMS.
  • Mucor and Rhizopus: Non-septate, broad hyphae with right angle branching, distinguishing them from Aspergillus.
  • Fusarium: Requires culture for definitive identification, although morphologically similar to Aspergillus.

questions.text: The most probable diagnosis for a young male presenting with Leucotrichia and lesions as depicted in the image is? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Segmental vitiligo

 

Localized, unilateral depigmented macules can be seen in the image. This characteristic and a history of leukotrichia point to the diagnosis of segmental vitiligo in the patient.

 

Vitiligo happens because the basal layer lacks melanocytes due to autoimmune destruction by auto antibodies.

 

The gradual loss of melanocytes causes a localized depigmentation to take place.

 

It is categorized as:

 

  1. Segmental vitiligo: This form of vitiligo is characterized by unilateral depigmented macules in a dermatomal or segmental pattern. The presence of Leucotrichia (white or colorless hair) within the lesion is a strong clinical indicator of segmental vitiligo. The image shows a pattern consistent with segmental vitiligo.
  2. Non-segmental vitiligo: which appears as bilateral macules distributed in an acrofacial pattern or scattered symmetrically over the entire body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Focal vitiligo: This is characterized by one or more macules or patches in one area without any recognizable pattern as shown in the image below.

 

 

Option C. Piebaldism: It is a rare autosomal dominant disorder that is present at birth. The hallmark of piebaldism is a white forelock as shown in the image below.

 

 

  • The distribution of lesions is usually symmetrical and remains stable throughout life, which differs from the presentation in the image.

 

Option D. Nevus depigmentosus: This is a congenital, stable hypopigmented patch that does not progress or change with time. Unlike vitiligo, it does not show Leucotrichia, and the lesion does not spread.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Segmental vitiligo presents with one or more macules in a dermatomal or segmental pattern, often accompanied by Leucotrichia.

 

Ref - Rooks Textbook of dermatology 9th Edition page no 88.34

questions.text: Which part of this bone is palpable in the infraclavicular fossa: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. B

 

The coracoid process is palpable in the infraclavicular fossa and is marked on the scapula as B. The coracoid process's tip is located approximately 2.5 cm below the clavicle, immediately lateral to the infraclavicular fossa (deltopectoral triangle). As a result, the coracoid process can be palpated below the clavicle.

 

The coracoid process arises from the upper border of the neck of the scapula and it projects forwards and slightly laterally. Attachments at the coracoid process include

 

  • The conoid portion of the coracoclavicular ligament
  • Pectoralis minor
  • Medial end of coraco-acromial ligament
  • Coracohumeral ligament
  • Glenocorocoidligamnet
  • Coracobrachialis muscle
  • Medial end of coraco-acromial ligament
  • Coracohumeral ligament
  • Glenocorocoidligamnet
  • Coracobrachialis muscle

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acromian process continues from the spine of the scapula. The acromion is subcutaneous over its dorsal surface, The attachments at the acromion are the coracoacromial ligament, the articular capsule of the acromioclavicular joint, and horizontal fibers of the trapezius.

 

Option C. The glenoid fossa is present at the lateral angle of the scapula. It is articular with the humerus to form the shoulder joint.

 

Option D. The inferior angle lies over the seventh rib. Dorsally, it is related to latissimus dorsi. The angle is visible when the arm is raised over the head.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The coracoid process is a palpable landmark in the infraclavicular fossa, important for clinical examination and as a reference point for various shoulder procedures. Its recognition is crucial in the assessment of shoulder pathologies and for orientation during surgical approaches to the shoulder.

questions.text: A child presents to you with itchy lesions on the scalp with hair loss as shown in the image below. What would be the next best step? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) KOH mount

 

  • The image shows itchy lesions on the scalp with hair loss which is suggestive of a fungal infection, commonly tinea capitis.
  • The next best step in confirming the diagnosis would be to do a KOH mount.
  • The potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation is used to visualize fungal elements in skin, hair, and nail samples.
  • When applied, KOH dissolves the keratin in the skin, hair, and nails, leaving only fungal cells intact, which can then be visualized under the microscope.

 

Tinea capitis variants:

 

 

  • Ectothrix - Spores & fungus present outside the hair shaft.
  • Endothrix - Spores & fungi present inside the hair shaft.

 

 

 

Kerion:

 

  • Presents in Children with boggy swelling, easily pluckable hair, with regional lymphadenopathy.
  • It is a severe inflammatory type of tinea capitis.
  • The most common causative organisms of kerion are Zoophilic dermatophytes, T. verrucosum and T. mentagrophytes. In severe cases, there may be pus along with sinus formation.

 

 

Fig: Lesion: Boggy indurated scalp swelling

 

  • Investigation: 10% KOH mount
  • Treatment: DOC overall and for Microsporum is Griseofulvin

 

Note: DOC for Trichophyton is Terbinafine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Slit skin smear (SSS):

 

  • This is a procedure mainly used for diagnosing leprosy.
  • It involves taking a smear from the skin, usually from the earlobe, to look for acid-fast bacilli.
  • It is not appropriate in this case where fungal infection is suspected.

 

Option C. Gram staining:

 

  • This is a microbiological staining technique that is used to differentiate bacterial species into two large groups based on the chemical and physical properties of their cell walls.
  • It's not the first line of investigation for suspected fungal infections.

 

Option D. Biopsy:

 

  • While a biopsy can be used to diagnose various skin conditions, it is invasive and not the first line of investigation for a suspected fungal infection.
  • A KOH mount is a much simpler and direct test to confirm the presence of fungus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For itchy lesions on the scalp with hair loss suggestive of tinea capitis, a KOH mount is the preferred initial test to visualize fungal elements.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II-9th Edition Chapter 32 Page no 32.38, 32.40

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH)? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Urinary sodium <20 mEq/L

 

The syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH) is characterized by the excessive release of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) from the posterior pituitary gland or another source. This excessive release results in water retention and dilutional hyponatremia.

 

Urinary sodium <20 mEq/L: This option is incorrect. In SIADH, urinary sodium is typically high, usually greater than 40 mEq/L, due to the body's inability to excrete water appropriately, which leads to concentrated urine with high sodium levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Serum sodium <135 mEq/L: This option is correct as SIADH commonly presents with hyponatremia (low serum sodium levels) due to the dilution of blood sodium by the retained water.


Option C. Urine osmolality >100 mOsm/kg: This option is correct. In SIADH, urine osmolality is typically high because the kidneys are concentrating the urine inappropriately due to the persistent effect of ADH.

 

Option D. Patient can be clinically euvolemic: This option is correct. Patients with SIADH often appear clinically euvolemic (normal body fluid volume), as the retained water is distributed evenly throughout the body without significant signs of fluid overload.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The key fact to remember is that in SIADH, patients have high urinary sodium (typically >40 mEq/L) due to the body's inability to excrete water properly, leading to concentrated urine.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of secondary amenorrhea? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Kallman syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Kallman syndrome is a condition of hypothalamic hypogonadism that presents as primary amenorrhea with anosmia. It does not cause secondary amenorrhea.

 

Causes of secondary amenorrhea:

 

  • Sheehan's syndrome: This is a condition where the pituitary gland is damaged due to severe blood loss during or after childbirth, leading to secondary amenorrhea.
  • Asherman's syndrome: This condition involves the formation of scar tissue in the uterine cavity, often as a result of surgical procedures like dilation and curettage (D&C), leading to secondary amenorrhea.
  • Turner mosaic: This refers to a form of Turner syndrome where some of the cells have the typical 45,X karyotype and others have a different karyotype (e.g., 46,XX). It can lead to secondary amenorrhea.
  • Premature ovarian failure: This condition occurs when the ovaries stop functioning normally before age 40, causing secondary amenorrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Turner's mosaic: A cause of secondary amenorrhea due to ovarian insufficiency.

 

Option C. Sheehan's syndrome: A cause of secondary amenorrhea due to pituitary damage.

 

Option D. Asherman's syndrome: A cause of secondary amenorrhea due to uterine scarring.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kallman syndrome is a cause of primary amenorrhea due to hypothalamic hypogonadism and anosmia. Secondary amenorrhea can be caused by conditions such as Sheehan's syndrome, Asherman's syndrome, Turner mosaic, and premature ovarian failure.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition Pg375

questions.text:
Which of the following are causes of neonatal seizures? (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Hyponatremia
  2. Hypomagnesemia
  3. Hypocalcemia
  4. Hypernatremia
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3 and 4

 

All of the above-given options- hyponatremia, hypomagnesemia, hypocalcemia, and hypernatremia are causes of neonatal seizures.

 

Metabolic disorders cause neonatal seizures commonly. Hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy is the most common cause.

 

 

Neonatal seizures may be of five types: subtle, tonic, clonic, spasms, and myoclonic.

 

  • Subtle seizures include movements like transient eye deviations, nystagmus, blinking, mouthing, rowing, cycling, pedaling, fluctuations in heart rate, hypertension episodes, and apnea. They are more common in premature than in term babies.
  • Tonic seizures are characterized by increased tension in the muscle groups. They may be focal or generalized.
    • Focal tonic seizures are characterized by sustained posturing of a single limb, sustained asymmetrical posturing of the trunk, and sustained eye deviation. They can not be provoked by stimulation or suppressed by restraint.
    • Generalized tonic seizures occur as bilateral tonic limb extensions or flexions of the upper limbs often accompanied by a tonic extension of the lower limbs and trunk.
  • A clonic seizure is characterized by multiple, repetitive, rhythmic contractions of muscle groups. Muscles of the limbs, face, or trunk can be involved. They can be unifocal or multifocal. It cannot be suppressed by restraint.
  • Spasms are sudden generalized jerks lasting 1-2 sec and are usually associated with a single, very brief, generalized discharge. They may be flexor, extensor, or mixed extensor/flexor and can occur in clusters. It cannot be provoked by stimulation or suppressed by restraint.
  • Myoclonic seizures can be focal, multifocal, or generalized. They are differentiated from clonic seizures by their lack of rhythmicity and the rapidity of the jerks (<50 msec).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neonatal seizures can be caused by various metabolic disturbances, including hyponatremia, hypomagnesemia, hypocalcemia, and hypernatremia, and these should be considered in the differential diagnosis of seizures in neonates.

questions.text:
A pregnant woman at 36 weeks gestation is found to have high blood pressure recording and a urine protein of 3+. Concomitant presence of which of the following symptoms would make you suspect imminent eclampsia? (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Headache
  2. Blurred vision
  3. Persistent pedal edema
  4. Epigastric pain
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 4

 

Explanation:

 

Imminent eclampsia is indicated by the presence of severe symptoms in a patient with preeclampsia. The following symptoms are particularly concerning and suggest the risk of progression to eclampsia:

 

  • Headache
  • Blurred vision
  • Epigastric pain
  • Vomiting (though not listed in the options)

 

Key Points:

 

1. Headache: Severe, persistent headache is a sign of central nervous system involvement.

 

2. Blurred vision: Visual disturbances such as blurred vision or seeing spots are due to cerebral or retinal vasospasm.

 

4. Epigastric pain: Pain in the epigastric or right upper quadrant can indicate hepatic involvement, such as stretching of the Glisson capsule due to liver swelling.

 

Other symptoms not specifically listed:

 

  • Vomiting: This can also be a sign of worsening preeclampsia.

 

Other Option:

 

3. Persistent pedal edema : While edema can be present in preeclampsia, it is not a specific indicator of imminent eclampsia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a pregnant woman with preeclampsia, the presence of headache, blurred vision, and epigastric pain indicates imminent eclampsia and necessitates immediate intervention with prophylactic magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) and planning for delivery to prevent the onset of seizures.

 

Ref: Williams text book of obstetrics 26th edition Pg 1840, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics pg 261,262

questions.text: The most common ocular manifestation of COVID-19 is: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Follicular conjunctivitis

 

  • COVID-19 can cause ocular manifestations due to the presence of ACE-2 receptors on the cornea and conjunctiva, which are potential target tissues for SARS-CoV-2.

 

COVID-19:

 

  • Most common ocular symptoms: Dry eye or foreign body sensation, redness, tearing, itching, eye pain, and discharge.
  • Most common ocular manifestation: Mild follicular conjunctivitis, which can appear as the only sign and symptom of COVID-19.
  • Other less frequent ocular complications: Hemorrhagic conjunctivitis, dry eye disease, episcleritis, chemosis, and photophobia.
  • Intraocular complications that may occur: Retinal artery occlusions, hemorrhages, and cotton wool spots caused by complement-mediated thrombotic angiopathy.
  • Patients with conjunctivitis should undergo a nasopharyngeal RT-PCR test for COVID-19 to rule out systemic infection.
  • Physicians and ophthalmologists should exercise caution when examining patients with conjunctivitis and wear eye-protective gear in addition to face masks and other protective devices.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retinal vein thrombosis: While COVID-19 can cause thrombotic complications, retinal vein thrombosis is not commonly reported as a primary ocular manifestation of COVID-19.

 

Option B. Viral keratouveitis: There is limited evidence to suggest that COVID-19 directly causes viral keratouveitis. This condition involves inflammation of the cornea and uvea and is more commonly associated with other viruses.

 

Option D. Pseudomembranous conjunctivitis: Pseudomembranes in the context of conjunctivitis are not true membranes but rather a buildup of fibrin, inflammatory cells, and mucus. They can adhere to the conjunctival tissue and may cause a gritty or painful sensation in the eye. Some common causes of pseudomembranous conjunctivitis include:
 

  1. Bacterial Infections: Bacterial conjunctivitis, particularly caused by certain strains of bacteria like Corynebacterium diphtheriae or Streptococcus pneumoniae, can lead to the formation of pseudomembranes.
  2. Viral Infections: In rare cases, certain viruses, such as adenoviruses, can cause pseudomembranous conjunctivitis.
  3. Allergic Reactions: Severe allergic conjunctivitis can lead to the development of pseudomembranes, although this is less common.

 

Treatment for pseudomembranous conjunctivitis typically involves addressing the underlying cause, which may include antibiotics for bacterial infections or antiviral medications for viral infections. In some cases, topical steroids may be prescribed to reduce inflammation and relieve symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Follicular conjunctivitis is the most common ocular manifestation seen in patients with COVID-19, highlighting the virus's ability to affect multiple body systems including the eyes. This underscores the importance of protective measures for healthcare providers, such as wearing masks and eye protection when examining patients suspected of having COVID-19.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is preferred in the management of primary progressive multiple sclerosis? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ocrelizumab

 

Ocrelizumab is the preferred drug for the management of primary progressive multiple sclerosis (PPMS). PPMS is a form of multiple sclerosis characterized by a gradual progression of neurological symptoms without relapses. The reference paragraph highlights that Ocrelizumab is the only drug that has been shown to be effective in treating PPMS based on recent clinical trials. Ocrelizumab is a monoclonal antibody that targets CD20-positive B cells, which are believed to play a significant role in the pathogenesis of multiple sclerosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Natalizumab: This drug is used primarily for relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (RRMS). It works by inhibiting the migration of immune cells into the central nervous system, but it has not been shown to be effective in PPMS.

 

Option C. Fingolimod: While Fingolimod is effective in treating RRMS, it is not the preferred treatment for PPMS. Fingolimod works by modulating sphingosine-1-phosphate receptors to prevent lymphocytes from reaching the central nervous system.

 

Option D. Alemtuzumab: This drug is used for RRMS and works by depleting circulating T and B lymphocytes. It has not been demonstrated to be effective in treating PPMS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ocrelizumab is the only drug currently shown to be effective in the management of primary progressive multiple sclerosis (PPMS).

 

Remember - The drug that has been shown to be effective in treating secondary progressive multiple sclerosis (SPMS) is Siponimod, which is a sphingosine-1-phosphate receptor agonist.

questions.text: The latent period, contraction period, and relaxation period of a skeletal muscle are 10 ms, 40 ms, and 50 ms respectively. Calculate the tetanizing frequency? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 25 per second

 

The tetanizing frequency of the given skeletal muscle is 25 per second.

 

Tetanizing frequency: Rate of stimulation at which summation of contractions will occur

 

Tetanizing frequency can be calculated as - 1/contraction period.

 

In this problem, contraction period is 40msec = 0.04sec

 

So, Tetanizing frequency = 1/contraction period = 1/0.04 = 100/4 = 25Hz.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tetanization-  As the frequency increases, there comes a point where each new contraction occurs before the preceding one is over. As a result, the second contraction is added partially to the first, so that the total strength of contraction rises progressively with increasing frequency. When the frequency reaches a critical level, the successive contractions eventually become so rapid that they fuse together, and the whole muscle contraction appears to be completely smooth and continuous. This is called Tetanization.

choices.text: Pleural thickening is typical of COVID-19
Lobar consolidation is typical of COVID-19

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding CORDS? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CORADS-5 is typical of COVID-19

 

Explanation:

 

CORADS-COVID-19 Reporting and Data System

 

CO-RADS is a categorical assessment scale used to evaluate pulmonary involvement of COVID-19 on chest CT scans. Each category reflects the level of suspicion of COVID-19.  

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CO-RADS-0: This category indicates that the CT examination is insufficient for assessment, not that the lungs are normal, which is a common misunderstanding.

 

Option C. Pleural thickening: While pleural thickening can occur in COVID-19, it is not typical or diagnostic of the disease. COVID-19 primarily affects the parenchyma of the lungs rather than the pleura.

 

Option D. Lobar consolidation: Though lobar consolidation may be present in severe cases of COVID-19, it is not typical of the disease, as COVID-19 more frequently presents with peripheral ground-glass opacities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

COVID-19 Reporting and Data System (CO-RADS) is a categorical assessment for pulmonary involvement of COVID-19 on chest CT.

questions.text: A 42-year-old female patient presents with cough, low-grade fever, and hemoptysis. Investigations reveal a cavitary lesion on her right lung apex, which on biopsy reveals caseous necrosis. The underlying pathophysiology is: (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Type 4 hypersensitivity reaction

 

The clinical scenario with complaints of cough, low-grade fever, hemoptysis is suggestive of pulmonary tuberculosis. The diagnosis is further supported by a cavitary lesion in the apex of the lung and a biopsy showing caseous necrosis. The pathophysiology is a type 4 hypersensitivity reaction mediated by activated macrophages.

 

Tuberculosis is a chronic pulmonary and systemic disease caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

 

With certain persistent or nondegradable antigens, such as tubercle bacilli colonizing the lungs or other tissues, the perivascular infiltrate is dominated by macrophages over a period of 2 or 3 weeks. The activated macrophages often undergo a morphologic transformation into epithelium-like cells and are then referred to as epithelioid cells. A microscopic aggregation of epithelioid cells, usually surrounded by a collar of lymphocytes, is referred to as a granuloma. This pattern of inflammation, called granulomatous inflammation, is typically associated with strong T-cell activation with cytokine production. It can also be caused by foreign bodies that activate macrophages without eliciting an adaptive immune response.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enzyme degradation: This does occur in TB but is not the primary mechanism leading to the granulomatous response and caseous necrosis.

 

Option C. Fibrinoid deposition: This is typically associated with immune complex-mediated conditions, not TB.

 

Option D. Sudden cut-off of blood supply: This would more likely result in coagulative necrosis, not the caseous necrosis seen in TB.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pulmonary tuberculosis is characterized by granulomatous inflammation with caseous necrosis, driven by a type 4 hypersensitivity reaction mediated by activated macrophages and T-helper cells.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 392

questions.text:
Inferior thyroid artery supply which of the following structure?

 

1. Thyroid

2. Parathyroid

3. Esophagus

4. Thymus
questions.solution:
Ans.  A. 1, 2, 3 & 4

 

Explanation:

 

The inferior thyroid artery is a branch of the thyrocervical trunk and arises from the subclavian artery. It runs upward in front of the vertebral column and enters the thyroid gland at its lower pole. Along its course, the inferior thyroid artery gives off several branches that supply the thyroid gland, parathyroid glands, larynx, trachea, esophagus, and the pharynx.

 

  1. Thyroid: The inferior thyroid artery primarily supplies blood to the thyroid gland. The gland requires a substantial blood supply due to its high metabolic activity, especially when it's actively producing thyroid hormones. The inferior thyroid artery enters the thyroid gland at its posterior aspect and supplies the majority of the gland, especially its inferior portion.
  2. Parathyroid: The parathyroid glands are small endocrine glands located on the posterior surface of the thyroid gland. There are usually four parathyroid glands: two superior and two inferior. The inferior parathyroid glands are typically supplied by the inferior thyroid artery. The blood supply to these glands is crucial because they produce parathyroid hormone (PTH), which plays a vital role in calcium homeostasis.
  3. Esophagus: The esophagus, especially its cervical portion, may receive some blood supply from the branches of the inferior thyroid artery. However, it's essential to note that the primary blood supply to the esophagus comes from the esophageal branches of various arteries along its length, such as the aorta and the left gastric artery.
  4. Thymus: While the inferior thyroid artery is not a primary source of blood supply for the thymus, there can be some anastomotic connections between the vessels supplying these structures in the anterior mediastinum. However, the primary blood supply to the thymus comes from the internal thoracic and anterior mediastinal branches.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The thyroid gland receives its main arterial blood supply from the superior and inferior thyroid arteries. The inferior thyroid artery also supplies the parathyroid glands with blood. Additionally, its branches provide blood to the esophagus, larynx, trachea, thymus and pharynx.

 

Branches:

 

  • Pharyngeal branches
  • Ascending cervical artery
  • Inferior artery
  • Muscular branches

 

Thymic branches – originate from internal thoracic, inferior thyroid arteryand often superior thyroid arteries & supply the thymus.

questions.text: The strict anaerobe among the following is: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Prevotella

 

The strict anaerobe in the given options is Prevotella.

 

Prevotella spp are anaerobic, gram negative bacilli or coccobacilli.

 

Prevotella spp. are members of the oral, vaginal, and gut microbiota and are often recovered from anaerobic infections of the respiratory tract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Burkholderia cepacia:  Is gram-negative, aerobic bacilli belonging to pseudomonad group.

 

Option B. Yersinia enterocolitica: Are gram negative facultative anaerobes.

 

Option C. Stenotrophomonas maltophilia: Are gram-negative, aerobic bacilli belonging to pseudomonad group.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prevotella species are strict anaerobes, thriving in oxygen-free environments, and are part of the normal flora of the oral, vaginal, and gut microbiota. They can be involved in various anaerobic infections, particularly of the respiratory tract.

questions.text: Match the following disorders causing secondary amenorrhea with their respective lab findings:  (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-A, 2-D, 3-C, 4-B

 

Explanation:

 

  • Secondary amenorrhea is the absence of menses for more than three months in girls or women who previously had regular menstrual cycles or six months in girls or women who had irregular menses.
  • Premature Ovarian failure: FSH and LH levels will be very high, estrogen levels are low
  • Asherman's syndrome: As the cause in the endometrium, hormonal levels are normal. 
  • PCOS: Alteration in the LH/FSH ratio
  • Sheehan's syndrome/ pituitary apoplexy: Hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism: So FSH and LH are low and so is Estrogen

 

Educational Objective:

 

To correctly diagnose the underlying cause of secondary amenorrhea, it is essential to understand and interpret the hormonal profiles associated with different conditions:

 

  • Premature Ovarian Failure: Elevated FSH and LH levels with decreased estradiol indicate ovarian insufficiency.
  • Asherman Syndrome: Low levels of FSH, LH, and estradiol suggest an endometrial cause, such as scarring.
  • PCOS (Polycystic Ovary Syndrome): Typically characterized by normal FSH, elevated LH, and normal estradiol levels, reflecting an imbalance in gonadotropins.
  • Sheehan Syndrome: Normal levels of FSH, LH, and estradiol are indicative of pituitary insufficiency, where the pituitary gland fails to stimulate the ovaries.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition Pg 380,

questions.text:
Which of the following investigations is used to diagnose unicornuate uterus?  (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Falloposcopy
  2. Laparoscopy
  3. HSG
  4. X-ray
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2, 3

 

Explanation:

 

2. Laparoscopy: This is a minimally invasive surgical procedure that allows direct visualization of the pelvic organs, including the uterus. It is effective in diagnosing structural anomalies like a unicornuate uterus.

 

3. HSG (Hysterosalpingogram): This is an X-ray procedure where a contrast dye is injected into the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes. It helps in visualizing the shape of the uterine cavity and the patency of the fallopian tubes, making it useful in diagnosing a unicornuate uterus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2, 4: While laparoscopy (2) is correct, X-ray (4) alone is not specific or detailed enough to diagnose a unicornuate uterus.

 

Option B. 1, 2: Falloposcopy (1) is used to visualize the interior of the fallopian tubes, not to diagnose uterine anomalies. Laparoscopy (2) is correct but falloposcopy is not appropriate for this diagnosis.

 

Option C. 1, 3: Similar to option B, falloposcopy (1) is not relevant for diagnosing uterine anomalies, even though HSG (3) is correct.

 

  • Falloposcopy: Refers to the visualization of the interior of the fallopian tube lumen and tubal ostia using a flexible fiber optic device via hysteroscope.
  • Diagnosis of Mullerian Anomalies: Can be achieved through various methods, including:
    1. Ultrasound (Preferably 3D USG)
    2. MRI (Investigation of choice)
    3. HSG
    4. Hystero-laparoscopy

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laparoscopy and HSG are effective diagnostic tools for identifying unicornuate uterus and other Mullerian anomalies.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition Pg 47, William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg418

questions.text: Which of the following is a dematiaceous fungus? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cladosporium

 

  • The dematiaceous (brown-pigment) fungi are a large and heterogenous group of molds that cause a wide range of diseases including phaeohyphomycosis, chromoblastomycosis, and eumycotic mycetoma.
  • Among the more important human pathogens are Alternaria species, Bipolaris species, Cladophialophora (Cladosporium) bantiana, Curvularia species, Exophiala species, Fonsecaea pedrosoi, Madurella species, Phialophora species, Scedosporium prolificans, Scytalidium dimidiatum, and Wangiella dermatitidis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mucor species: Incorrect Mucor species are not dematiaceous fungi. They are non-pigmented (hyaline) fungi that cause mucormycosis, especially in immunocompromised individuals.
 

Option B. Aspergillus niger: Incorrect Aspergillus niger is not a dematiaceous fungus. It is a black mold, but it does not belong to the group of dematiaceous fungi. It is a common cause of aspergillosis.
 

Option D. Blastomyces dermatitidis: Incorrect Blastomyces dermatitidis is not a dematiaceous fungus. It is a dimorphic fungus that causes blastomycosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cladosporium is a dematiaceous fungus, characterized by its dark pigmentation due to melanin in its cell walls, and it is associated with various diseases including phaeohyphomycosis, chromoblastomycosis, and eumycotic mycetoma.

questions.text: Which pathogen causes attachment-effacement lesion in the intestinal mucosa? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Enteropathogenic Escherichia coli


Attaching-and-effacing is the “hallmark” of the EPEC infections, a lesion that is characterized by the intimate attachment of the bacteria to the host epithelial cell membrane and the effacement of the microvilli. This mechanism is a hallmark of EPEC infections, leading to copious watery diarrhea, especially in infants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (ETEC): Incorrect: ETEC causes watery diarrhea through the production of enterotoxins that increase cyclic AMP (cAMP) or cyclic GMP (cGMP) levels, leading to fluid and electrolyte loss. It does not cause attachment-effacement lesions.

 

Option C. Enteroinvasive Escherichia coli (EIEC): Incorrect: EIEC invades and destroys epithelial cells lining the colon, leading to fever, cramping, watery diarrhea, and dysentery with scant, bloody stools. It does not cause attachment-effacement lesions.

 

Option D. Diffusely adherent Escherichia coli (DAEC): Incorrect: DAEC is known for its diffuse adherence pattern to epithelial cells, causing persistent diarrhea in children. It does not cause attachment-effacement lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient with lytic lesions on the skull is suspected of a diagnosis of Langerhans cell histiocytosis. Which of the following is a characteristic finding on electron microscopy? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Birbeck granules

 

The presence of Birbeck granules in the cytoplasm is a characteristic finding of Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) on electron microscopy.

 

Birbeck granules have a dilated terminal end producing a tennis racket-like appearance. It contains the protein langerin (CD207). It is seen on electron microscopy.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Histiocytes: While LCH involves histiocytic cells (specifically Langerhans cells), the mere presence of histiocytes is not specific to LCH. Many other conditions can also involve histiocytes, so this option is too general.

 

Option C. Eosinophils: Eosinophils are often present in LCH lesions, contributing to the inflammatory response, but they are not a characteristic finding on electron microscopy and are not specific to LCH.

 

Option D. Giant cells: Giant cells may be seen in various granulomatous conditions but are not a characteristic finding specific to LCH on electron microscopy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Birbeck granules on electron microscopy is a characteristic finding in Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH), confirming the diagnosis of this condition.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition Pg 1168

questions.text:
A pediatric resident is preparing a presentation on neonatal mortality in India. She finds a dataset from the verbal autopsy report (2010-2013) and wants to understand the hierarchy of factors contributing to neonatal deaths. Based on this data, how would you arrange these factors from the most significant contributor to the least? (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Prematurity and low birth weight
  2. Birth injuries and birth asphyxia
  3. Congenital anomalies
  4. Sepsis
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1>2>4>3

 

The most significant factors contributing to neonatal mortality are arranged as follows: Prematurity and low birth weight, followed by birth injuries and birth asphyxia, then sepsis, and finally congenital anomalies.

 

1. Prematurity and low birth weight: These are the leading causes of neonatal mortality due to complications associated with underdevelopment.

 

2. Birth injuries and birth asphyxia: These are significant contributors to neonatal deaths due to physical trauma and lack of oxygen during birth.

 

4. Sepsis: Infections are a major cause of death, particularly in the late neonatal period.

 

3. Congenital anomalies: These contribute to neonatal mortality but to a lesser extent compared to the other factors.

 

NNMR - Neonatal mortality rate is the number of neonatal deaths (deaths within completed 28 days after birth) per 1000 live births in that year

 

 

  • Early neonatal mortality (ENNM): Neonatal mortality in first week (1-7 days) of life
  • Late neonatal mortality (LNNM): Neonatal mortality in first to fourth week (8 – 28 days) of life
  • MCC of NNMR in India is preterm birth
    • MCC of ENNMR: Prematurity and congenital anomalies
    • MCC of LNNMR: Infections (diarrhea and tetanus)
  • As per 2022-23 data - India’s NNMR is 20 per 1000 live births
  • NNMR is directly related with birth weight and gestational age
  • NNMRboys >NNMRgirls 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Causes of Neonatal mortality (0 – 4 weeks): 

 

  • Low birth weight and prematurity
  • Birth injury and difficult labour
  • Sepsis
  • Congenital anomalies
  • Hemolytic diseases of newborn
  • Conditions of placenta and cord
  • Diarrhoeal diseases
  • Acute respiratory infections
  • Tetanus

 

According to WHO, Preterm birth, intrapartum-related complications (birth asphyxia), infections and congenital defects are the leading causes of most neonatal deaths.

questions.text: Most preferred chromatography for HbA1c? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ion-exchange chromatography

 

  • Ion-exchange chromatography is the most preferred method for HbA1c analysis that separates molecules based on their charge.
  • While it can be used for HbA1c analysis,

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Electrophoresis:

  • Electrophoresis is a technique that separates molecules based on their charge and size.
  • It is not the most preferred method for HbA1c analysis because it may not provide the specificity and accuracy needed for precise quantification of glycated hemoglobin.

 

Option C. Affinity chromatography:

  • Affinity chromatography separates glycated hemoglobin based on its specific affinity for a stationary phase that can selectively bind to HbA1c.

 

Option D. Immuno turbidimetry:

  • Immuno turbidimetry is a technique that measures the concentration of substances in a solution based on the degree of turbidity.
  • While it can be used for HbA1c analysis, it may not be as specific as affinity chromatography.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glycated hemoglobin (GHB), reported as hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c), is a biochemical marker that is used routinely in the management of individuals with diabetes mellitus to monitor long-term glycemic control and assess the risk of developing complications.

 

Four basic types of methods are used most commonly to measure HbA1c: immunoassay, ion-exchange high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC), boronate affinity HPLC, and enzymatic assays.

choices.text: Dark areas represent necrosis, white areas represent viable liver tissue
Dark areas represent viable liver tissue, white areas represent necrosis
White areas represent central hepatocytes
Dark areas represent peri-portal hepatocytes

questions.text: A patient with cirrhosis and ascites presented to you. The gross appearance of his liver is as shown below. Which among the following is true about it? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dark areas represent necrosis; white areas represent viable liver tissue.

 

The above picture shows centrilobular hemorrhagic necrosis. The cut liver section, in which major blood vessels are visible, is notable for a variegated, mottled, red appearance (nutmeg liver) seen in right heart failure. The dark areas represent necrosis; white areas represent viable liver tissue.

 

Nutmeg liver refers to the mottled appearance of the liver which resembles the cut section of nutmeg. This occurs as a result of hepatic venous congestion following right heart failure. The dark centrilobular zones reflect sinusoidal congestion. Congestion is seen around the central veins usually from right-sided heart failure. The pale periportal zones reflect normal or fatty liver tissue.

 

The liver derives its blood supply from the portal venous system and the hepatic artery. The portal triad constitutes:

 

  • Branches of the hepatic artery
  • Portal vein
  • Bile duct

 

The blood from the portal vein and the hepatic artery flow through the intervening sinusoids and drains into the central vein. The central veins from adjacent lobules form interlobular veins, which then unite as hepatic veins and finally drain into the inferior vena cava.

 

The hepatic lobule is divided into three zones:

 

  • Zone 1 is the periportal area
  • Zone 2 is the Intermediate zone
  • Zone 3 is the area closest to the central vein

 

Right-sided cardiac failure leads to passive congestion of the liver. Left-sided cardiac failure leads to hypoperfusion and hypoxia of hepatocytes around central veins. The combination of hypoperfusion and retrograde congestion causes centrilobular hemorrhagic necrosis, leading to this mottled appearance of the liver, known as nutmeg liver.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dark areas represent viable liver tissue, white areas represent necrosis: This is incorrect because the dark areas are where necrosis has occurred due to congestion, not viable tissue.

 

Option C. White areas represent central hepatocytes: The white areas represent periportal zones, which are generally healthier and not central hepatocytes.

 

Option D. Dark areas represent peri-portal hepatocytes: The dark areas actually represent the centrilobular regions where necrosis has occurred, not the periportal hepatocytes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nutmeg liver is characterized by a mottled appearance, where dark areas represent necrosis due to chronic passive congestion, and white areas represent viable liver tissue.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1665

questions.text: All of the following oncogenic viruses can integrate with the human genome to initiate carcinogenesis except: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HTLV

 

  • HTLV - Human T cell lymphotropic virus causes microbial carcinogenesis by indirect mechanisms.
  • Oncoviruses are classified as direct or indirect carcinogens, although some overlap exists between the distinction. Direct carcinogenic viruses possess viral oncogenes that directly contribute to neoplastic cellular transformation, whereas indirect carcinogens cause chronic inflammation, which can lead to oncogenic transformation.
  • DNA tumor viruses encode viral oncoproteins which may become integrated into the host cell chromosome.
  • RNA viruses are known to cause microbial carcinogenesis by indirect mechanisms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HPV (Human Papillomavirus):

 

  • Mechanism: HPV integrates its DNA into the host genome, leading to the production of oncoproteins E6 and E7, which inactivate tumor suppressor genes p53 and Rb. This disruption of tumor suppressor pathways contributes to the development of cancers such as cervical cancer.
  • Example: Cervical cancer is a well-documented outcome of HPV infection, particularly with high-risk strains like HPV 16 and 18.

 

Option B. HBV (Hepatitis B Virus):

 

  • Mechanism: HBV can integrate its DNA into the host genome, contributing to hepatocellular carcinoma. The integration can lead to genomic instability and the insertional activation of oncogenes or inactivation of tumor suppressor genes.
  • Example: Chronic hepatitis B infection is a major risk factor for hepatocellular carcinoma.

 

Option D. EBV (Epstein-Barr Virus):

 

  • Mechanism: EBV can integrate into the host genome and produce latent proteins that drive cell proliferation and prevent apoptosis. The viral proteins LMP1 and EBNA2 are key players in this process, contributing to the development of various cancers, including Burkitt's lymphoma, Hodgkin's lymphoma, and nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
  • Example: EBV is strongly associated with Burkitt's lymphoma, particularly in endemic areas such as sub-Saharan Africa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oncogenic DNA and RNA Viruses:

 

  • Oncogenic DNA Viruses:
    • EBV (Epstein-Barr Virus)
    • HBV (Hepatitis B Virus)
    • HPV (Human Papillomavirus)
    • HHV-8 (Human Herpesvirus-8)
    • MCPyV (Merkel Cell Polyomavirus)
  • Oncogenic RNA Viruses:
    • HCV (Hepatitis C Virus)
    • HTLV-1 (Human T-cell Lymphotropic Virus-1)

questions.text:
A 30-year-old female patient came to the outpatient department with complaints of neck swelling. She gives a history of weight loss and palpitations. On examination, she has exophthalmos and a diffusely enlarged thyroid gland. What are the essential investigations that should be done for the patient? (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Thyroid scan
  2. Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC)
  3. Thyroid function tests
  4. Ultrasound of neck
  5. Anti-thyroid antibody
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 3, 4, and 5 only

 

The clinical presentation of neck swelling, weight loss, palpitations, exophthalmos, and a diffusely enlarged thyroid gland suggests hyperthyroidism, likely Graves' disease.

 

FNAC is not recommended in this case because it does not provide additional diagnostic yield for Graves' disease, does not alter the treatment plan, and carries a risk of complications due to the gland's increased vascularity in Graves' disease.

 

Other Options:

 

The following investigations are essential:

 

1. Thyroid scan: A radioactive iodine uptake scan helps differentiate between diffuse uptake (indicative of Graves' disease) and nodular uptake (indicative of toxic multinodular goiter or Plummer's disease).

 

3. Thyroid function tests: These are crucial as they provide information on the levels of thyroid hormones (T3, T4) and thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), helping confirm the diagnosis of hyperthyroidism.

 

4. Ultrasound of neck: This imaging modality helps assess the thyroid gland's structure and can reveal increased vascularity, which is characteristic of Graves' disease.

 

5. Anti-thyroid antibody: Testing for antibodies, such as TSH receptor antibodies (TRAbs) or thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins (TSI), is important for diagnosing autoimmune thyroid diseases like Graves' disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with clinical signs of hyperthyroidism and a diffusely enlarged thyroid gland, essential investigations include a thyroid scan, thyroid function tests, ultrasound of the neck, and anti-thyroid antibody tests. Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is not typically required in these cases.

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿ETDRS chart - Early treatment diabetic retinopathy study

questions.text: Identify the chart given in the picture below: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hess chart

 

  • Hess chart is a diagnostic tool used to assess the field of a binocular single vision.
  • It is used to diagnose and monitor patients with incomitant strabismus.
  • Incomitant strabismus is a type of squint that occurs due to the limitation of eye movement associated with paralytic or mechanical etiologies.
  • The chart consists of a smaller chart that indicates the eye with the paretic muscle and a larger chart that indicates the eye with an overacting muscle.
  • The field of binocular single vision is the area where bifoveal fusion of an object of interest occurs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: The Snellen chart is used to test visual acuity. Visual acuity is the eye's ability to discriminate between two points.

 

A picture of the Snellen chart is given below.

 

 

Option C: The Pelli-Robson contrast sensitivity letter chart consists of letters of constant size but decreasing contrast. It is viewed by the patient from a distance of 1 meter until the lowest resolvable group of three letters on the chart is reached. It is used to measure contrast sensitivity, a measure of the ability to distinguish an object against its background. An image of the Pelli-Robson chart used in the Middle East is given below.

 

 

Option D: The early treatment diabetic retinopathy study or ETDRS chart presents a series of 5 letters of equal difficulty on each row, with standardized spacing between letters and rows. It consists of a total of 14 lines having 70 letters. It is also used to test visual acuity. An image of the ETDRS chart is given below.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Hess chart is specifically designed to assess binocular vision and ocular muscle function, especially useful in diagnosing and managing strabismus and similar conditions affecting eye alignment and movement.

questions.text: A boy presents with fever, night sweats, and neck swelling. The biopsy of swelling showed a starry sky appearance. What is the most likely genetic abnormality seen in this case? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) MYC gene

 

The given clinical scenario and the classical histopathological finding of starry sky appearance suggest the diagnosis of Burkitt's lymphoma and the most likely genetic abnormality is the translocation of the MYC gene on chromosome 8. Typical cytogenetic abnormalities is t(8;14) and t(8;22) involving MYC gene on chromosome 8, with overexpression of MYC protein having transforming activity.

 

Burkitt lymphoma is very aggressive (very high Ki67) but responds well to intensive chemotherapy

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. RAS: Mutations in the RAS gene are associated with various cancers, including some leukemias and solid tumors, but not specifically with Burkitt's lymphoma.

 

Option C. BCR-ABL: This genetic abnormality is associated with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) and some cases of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), not with Burkitt's lymphoma.

 

Option D. p53: Mutations in the p53 gene are common in many types of cancer but are not the defining feature of Burkitt's lymphoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Burkitt's lymphoma is characterized by the t(8;14) translocation involving the MYC gene, which leads to the overexpression of the MYC protein, driving the aggressive nature of the disease. The starry sky appearance on histopathology is a key diagnostic feature.

 

Ref: Robbins Pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1123

questions.text: Treatment of choice for an acute attack of cluster headache is: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Subcutaneous sumatriptan

 

Subcutaneous sumatriptan is shown to be effective in treating acute attacks of cluster headaches. The reference indicates that oral sumatriptan is not effective, whereas subcutaneous sumatriptan has been proven beneficial. Intranasal sumatriptan and intranasal zolmitriptan also are shown to be effective.

 

Additionally, 100% oxygen therapy at a rate of at least 12 liters per minute is effective.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral sumatriptan: Oral sumatriptan has not been shown to be effective in treating acute cluster headache attacks.

 

Option C. 100% oxygen at 6 L/minute: Although 100% oxygen is a treatment option, the effective rate is at least 12 liters per minute, making 6 L/minute inadequate.

 

Option D. 100% oxygen at 8 L/minute: Similar to the previous option, 8 L/minute is below the effective rate of 12 liters per minute required for treating acute cluster headaches.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The treatment of choice for an acute attack of cluster headache is subcutaneous sumatriptan, and 100% oxygen therapy should be administered at a rate of at least 12 liters per minute for effectiveness.

choices.text: Inhibition of calcineurin
AMP kinase stimulation
IMP dehydrogenase inhibition

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of cyclosporine? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Inhibition of calcineurin
 

  • Cyclosporine is an immunosuppressant drug that acts by inhibiting Calcineurin.
  • Calcineurin is a calcium/calmodulin-dependent phosphatase required for the induction of T cell lymphokine production and proliferation.
  • Cyclosporine inhibits calcineurin activity by forming a complex with cyclophilin, a cytoplasmic-receptor protein present in target cells, to form a cyclosporine-cyclophilin complex. This drug-receptor complex specifically and competitively binds to and inhibits calcineurin.
  • This, in turn, inhibits the translocation of a family of transcription factors (NF-AT), leading to reduced transcriptional activation of cytokine genes for interleukin (IL)-2 and other factors.
  • Ultimately, the proliferation of T lymphocytes is reduced, resulting in immunomodulation.
  • Indications: It is the most effective drug for the prevention of Graft rejection reaction. It is also used as a second line drug in autoimmune disease like severe Rheumatoid arthritis, uveitis, inflammatory bowel disease and dermatomyositis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. AMP kinase is stimulated by metformin used in treating T2DM
 

Option C. IMP dehydrogenase is inhibited by mycophenolate mofetil, also used in the prophylaxis of transplant rejection.

 

Option D. Dihydro-orotate dehydrogenase is inhibited by leflunomide, a pyrimidine synthesis inhibitor indicated for the management of rheumatoid arthritis in adults.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cyclosporine exerts its immunosuppressive effects by inhibiting calcineurin, thereby preventing the activation of T cells and reducing the production of cytokines such as IL-2. This mechanism is crucial for its role in preventing graft rejection and managing autoimmune diseases.

questions.text:
Arrange the following in sequential order with regards to the steps of collection of samples for pap smear testing: (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Use posterior vaginal wall retractor
  2. Take the sample
  3. Make smear on a slide
