  4. Fix the smear
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

The correct sequence for the steps of collection of samples for pap smear testing is as follows:

 

Procedure of taking a pap smear:

 

  1. Use posterior vaginal wall retractor: The patient is put in a dorsal position, and Cusco's speculum is introduced to visualize the cervix.
  2. Take the sample: The ectocervix is scraped with Ayre's spatula, and the endocervix is scraped with a cytobrush.
  3. Make smear on a slide: The samples are spread separately on 2 different glass slides.
  4. Fix the smear: The slide is immediately fixed using 95% ethyl alcohol (either immersed or sprayed). After immersion in fixative for 30 minutes, the slide is removed and air dried.

 

Additional Steps:

 

  • Staining: The fixed slide is stained with Papanicolaou stain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence for collecting samples for a pap smear is to first use a posterior vaginal wall retractor to visualize the cervix, take the sample, make the smear on a slide, and then fix the smear using 95% ethyl alcohol.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition Pg 110,111, William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition 632, 633

choices.text: Triad of confusion, ophthalmoplegia, and ataxia
Loss of long-term memory but intact personality
Anterograde amnesia with loss of recent memory
Loss of implicit memory and immediate recall

questions.text: Which of the following is true statement about Korsakoff syndrome? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anterograde amnesia with loss of recent memory

 

Korsakoff syndrome is a chronic memory disorder caused by severe deficiency of thiamine (vitamin B1). The most common cause is alcohol misuse, but other conditions that affect nutrition can also lead to Korsakoff syndrome. Its main feature is anterograde amnesia with loss of recent memory i.e., patients with Korsakoff syndrome can't acquire new information or recall recent events, but long-term memories from before the onset of the illness remain intact.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Triad of confusion, ophthalmoplegia, and ataxia: Refers to Wernicke's encephalopathy, which often precedes Korsakoff syndrome and presents with a triad of confusion, ophthalmoplegia, and ataxia. If left untreated, Wernicke's can progress to Korsakoff syndrome.

 

Option B. Loss of long-term memory but intact personality: While long-term memories may be affected in Korsakoff syndrome, it is not a characteristic feature. Personality changes, apathy, and lack of insight can be seen.

 

Option D. Loss of implicit memory and immediate recall: Korsakoff syndrome predominantly affects explicit memory (conscious recall of facts and events), not implicit memory (unconscious memory like skills).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Korsakoff syndrome is a chronic memory disorder caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency. It is primarily associated with chronic alcohol misuse. It is characterized by anterograde amnesia (difficulty forming new memories) and often retrograde amnesia (loss of past memories). Confabulation is common, where patients fill memory gaps with fabricated information. Treatment involves thiamine replacement and abstaining from alcohol. It often follows or coexists with Wernicke's encephalopathy, which is an acute syndrome requiring immediate thiamine treatment.

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 38-40.

questions.text: Match the following eggs to the organism? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-C, 2-D, 3-B, 4-A

 

1. The Hymenolepis nana egg - The egg is roughly spherical or ovoid, 30-40 μm size. It has a thin colorless outer membrane and inner embryopore enclosing the hexacanth oncosphere.  The space between two membranes contains yolk granules and 4-8 thread like polar filaments arising from two knobs on the embryophore. The eggs float in saturated solution of salt and are non-bile stained. They are immediately infective and unable to survive for more than 10 days in external environment.

 

 

2. Ascaris lumbricoides (Roundworm)

 

Two types of eggs are passed by the worms: (1) fertilized and (2) unfertilized.

 

  1. The fertilized eggs, laid by females, inseminated by mating with a male, are embryonated and develop into the infective eggs (Figs 3A to C. .
  2. The unfertilized eggs, are laid by uninseminated female. These are nonembryonated and cannot become infective

 

Features of roundworm egg

 

 

 

3. The egg of Ancylostoma duodenale (hookworm) is:

 

Oval or elliptical, measuring 60 μm by 40 mcm.

 

Colorless, not bile stained.

 

Surrounded by a thin transparent hyaline shell membrane.

 

Floats in saturated salt solution.

 

When released by the worm in the intestine, the egg contains an unsegmented ovum.

 

During its passage down the intestine, the ovum develops. When passed in feces, the egg contains a segmented ovum, usually with four or eight blastomeres.

 

There is a clear space between the segmented ovum and the egg shell (Figs A and B).

 

 

4. The eggs of Taenia solium and Tania saginata are indistinguishable.

 

The egg is spherical, measuring 30-40 mcm diameter. lt has a thin hyaline embryonic membrane around it, which soon disappears after release. The inner embryophore is radially striated and is yellow brown due to bile staining. In the center is a fully-developed embryo (oncosphere) with three pairs of hooklets (hexacanth embryo). The eggs do not float in saturated salt solution. The eggs of T. saginata are infective only to cattle and not to humans, whereas the eggs of T. solium are infective to pigs and humans too.

choices.text: Ferritin translation is increased by binding IRP to IRE
Ferritin translation is decreased by binding IRP to IRE
Transferrin receptor 1 translation is unaffected by binding IRP to IRE
Transferrin receptor 1 translation is decreased by binding IRP to IRE

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient was diagnosed with iron deficiency anemia. Which of the following is true about intracellular regulation of iron in the above condition? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ferritin translation is decreased by binding IP to IRE

 

In iron deficiency anaemia, ferritin translation is decreased by binding iron regulatory protein to iron response elements.

 

Dietary iron is carried in the blood by transferrin and enters cells via endocytosis, mediated by the transferrin receptor. Excess iron is stored by binding to ferritin. The levels of transferrin, transferrin receptor (TfR), and ferritin are therefore crucial to cellular iron homeostasis.

 

The iron regulatory proteins (IRPs) are two cytoplasmic RNA-binding proteins that control iron metabolism which bind to iron response elements (IRE) which are mRNA regions consisting of ferritin and transferrin receptor.

 

When the IRPs bind to the 5' untranslated IRE sequence in the ferritin mRNA, ferritin translation is blocked resulting in decreased ferritin.

 

When IPs are bound to the 3' end of the untranslated IRE sequence, there is increase in transferrin receptor per mRNA molecule due to reduced proteolysis of Tf receptor.

 

In iron-deficiency, iron stores (ferritin) is reduced and iron uptake (through transferrin receptor) is increased.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ferritin translation is increased by binding IRP to IRE: This is incorrect because binding of IRP to IRE inhibits ferritin translation.

 

Option C. Transferrin receptor 1 translation is unaffected by binding IRP to IRE: This is incorrect. IRP binding to IRE at the 3' untranslated region of transferrin receptor mRNA actually increases the stability and translation of transferrin receptor mRNA, increasing iron uptake.

 

Option D. Transferrin receptor 1 translation is decreased by binding IRP to IRE: This is incorrect as described above; binding of IRP to IRE increases transferrin receptor 1 translation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In iron deficiency anemia, ferritin translation is decreased due to the binding of IRP to IRE in the ferritin mRNA, reducing iron storage and making more iron available for use.

questions.text: What is the repair mechanism associated with CRISPR-Cas9? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Non-homologous end joining

 

NHEJ is the primary repair mechanism associated with CRISPR-Cas9. When CRISPR-Cas9 induces double-strand breaks in DNA, NHEJ rejoins the broken DNA ends, often introducing insertions or deletions (indels) at the repair site. This can result in gene knockout or disruption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Base excision repair (BER): BER is a DNA repair mechanism that corrects damaged or mismatched bases in the DNA. It primarily deals with single-base changes and small DNA lesions. CRISPR-Cas9, on the other hand, creates double-strand breaks, so BER is not directly involved in repairing these breaks.

 

Option B. Nucleotide excision repair (NER): NER is another DNA repair mechanism that mainly deals with the removal of larger DNA lesions, such as those caused by UV radiation. It is not the primary repair mechanism associated with CRISPR-Cas9-induced double-strand breaks.

 

Option D. Mismatch repair (MMR): MMR is a repair mechanism that corrects errors in DNA replication, specifically base-pair mismatches and small insertion-deletion loops. It is not the primary mechanism involved in repairing double-strand breaks created by CRISPR-Cas9.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary repair mechanism associated with CRISPR-Cas9 is non-homologous end joining (NHEJ), which repairs double-strand breaks by ligating the broken DNA ends, potentially causing insertions or deletions that disrupt the target gene.

choices.text: Vitamin C

questions.text: Administration of which of the following drugs would increase the bioavailability of saquinavir? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ritonavir


 

  • Both Ritonavir and Saquinavir are Protease inhibitors that can be used in the treatment of HIV.
  • They are metabolized by the hepatic CYP3A4 enzyme system. But at the same time, Ritonavir is also an inhibitor of CYP3A4. Therefore, if small doses of Ritonavir are added along with Saquinavir, it will inhibit the metabolism of Saquinavir or in other words will boost the bioavailability and concentration of Saquinavir.

questions.text: A person was brought to the emergency department with facial swelling, itching, and hypotension following a bee sting. The mentioned clinical features are due to the increase in which immunoglobulin? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IgE

 

The given clinical features suggest a anaphylactic reaction, a type 1 hypersensitivity reaction, and is mediated by immunoglobulin E.

 

Immediate (Type I) hypersensitivity reactions refer to allergic reactions or allergies.

 

It is a rapid immunologic reaction that is triggered by the binding of an antigen to IgE antibody on the surface of mast cells. It occurs in a previously sensitized individual. These reactions are induced by environmental antigens (allergens) that stimulate strong TH2 responses and IgE production in genetically susceptible individuals.

 

Systemic anaphylaxis is characterized by vascular shock, widespread edema, and difficulty in breathing. It may occur in sensitized individuals in hospital settings after administration of foreign proteins (e.g., antisera), hormones, enzymes, polysaccharides, and drugs (such as the antibiotic penicillin), or in the community setting following exposure to food allergens (e.g. peanuts, shellfish) or insect toxins (e.g. those in bee venom).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IgA: IgA is mainly involved in mucosal immunity and does not play a primary role in type I hypersensitivity or anaphylactic reactions.

 

Option C. IgM: IgM is the first antibody produced during an initial immune response but is not involved in allergic or type I hypersensitivity reactions.

 

Option D. IgG: IgG is involved in various immune responses, including type II and type III hypersensitivity reactions, but not in the immediate hypersensitivity reaction that leads to anaphylaxis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IgE is the immunoglobulin responsible for mediating type I hypersensitivity reactions, such as anaphylaxis, which can occur in response to bee stings or other allergens.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 373

choices.text: Aschoff body; Rheumatic heart disease
Calcification of valve; Mitral stenosis

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of dyspnea on exertion for 1 month. Echocardiography showed the presence of mitral stenosis and left ventricular hypertrophy. Identify the histopathological finding given below and the probable diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aschoff body; Rheumatic heart disease

 

The lesion shown in the histopathological slide is Aschoff's body and the most probable diagnosis is rheumatic heart disease (RHD).

 

Aschoff's bodies have the following components:

 

  • Anitschkow cells or plump macrophages
  • Abundant cytoplasm
  • Caterpillar cells - refer to centrally condensed chromatin into slender, wavy ribbons
  • Foci of fibrinoid necrosis
  • Aschoff's giant cells - multinucleated larger macrophages
  • T-cells
  • Plasma cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Calcification of valve; Mitral stenosis: While mitral stenosis can result from calcification, it is more typically associated with chronic rheumatic heart disease, which involves Aschoff bodies rather than calcification alone.

 

Option C. Granuloma; Sarcoidosis: Sarcoidosis is characterized by non-caseating granulomas, but it does not present with Aschoff bodies.

 

Option D. Non-caseating granuloma: Tuberculosis: Tuberculosis typically presents with caseating granulomas, not Aschoff bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aschoff bodies are indicative of Rheumatic heart disease (RHD), and their presence supports the diagnosis in a patient with clinical features such as mitral stenosis and left ventricular hypertrophy.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1044

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient arrives at the clinic with complaints of nasal obstruction on the right side and sporadic occurrences of blood-stained nasal discharge. The CT scan results are depicted in the image provided. What might be the potential underlying reason for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inverted Papilloma

 

An elderly patient with unilateral nasal obstruction, epistaxis and a mass visible points to a diagnosis of Inverted Papilloma.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Maxillary carcinoma arises from maxillary sinus lining and presents with facial paresthesia, lacrimation and pain.

 

 

Option C. Esthesioneuroblastoma/ Olfactory neuroblastomas are tumors arising from the basal layer of the olfactory epithelium in the superior recess of the nasal cavity. They usually present as a soft tissue mass in the superior olfactory recess involving the anterior and middle ethmoid air-cells on one side and extending through the cribriform plate into the anterior cranial fossa.

 

 

Option D. Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma is seen exclusively in males. Commonly presents with profuse epistaxis and nasal obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inverted Papilloma should be considered when an elderly patient presents with unilateral nasal symptoms and imaging reveals a mass, especially when the presentation includes epistaxis and nasal obstruction without the severe pain or neurological symptoms that might suggest a more malignant etiology.

questions.text: The sodium iodide symporter is present in all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pituitary gland

 

Sodium iodide symporter is present in all of the options given above except the pituitary gland. The pituitary does not play a direct role in iodide transport or thyroid hormone synthesis, hence the absence of NIS.

 

The sodium/iodide cotransporter, also known as the sodium/iodide symporter (NIS) is a transmembrane glycoprotein, which transports two sodium cations (Na+) for each iodide anion (I−) into the cell. NIS mediated uptake of iodide into follicular cells of the thyroid gland is the first step in the synthesis of thyroid hormone.

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. Thyroid gland: The primary site of NIS expression, essential for thyroid hormone production.

 

Option B. Placenta: NIS is expressed to transport iodide to the fetus, crucial for fetal development.

 

Option D. Salivary gland: NIS facilitates iodide transport, although its precise role here is less clear.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The sodium iodide symporter (NIS) is essential for iodide transport in various tissues. The NIS seen in:

 

  • Thyroid
  • Salivary glands
  • Gastric mucosa
  • Placenta
  • Ciliary body of the eye
  • Choroid plexus
  • Mammary glands
  • Certain cancers are derived from these tissues.

choices.text: Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, RS cell, EBV
Kaposi sarcoma, Giant cell, HIV
Hodgkin's lymphoma, RS cell, EBV
Infectious mononucleosis, RS cell, CMV

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy came with bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy. What is the probable diagnosis, cell, and virus associated with the image given below? (AIIMS NOV 2021)

 

(RS cell: Reed - Sternberg cell, HIV: Human immunodeficiency virus, CMV: Cytomegalovirus, EBV: Epstein-Barr virus)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hodgkin's lymphoma, RS cell, EBV

 

The probable diagnosis, cell, and virus from the given clinical scenario and the histopathological image are Hodgkin's lymphoma, Reed-Sternberg cells (RS cells), and Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) respectively.

 

Identification of Reed-Sternberg cells and their variants is essential for the diagnosis of Hodgkin’s lymphoma. Diagnostic Reed-Sternberg cells are large cells (≥45 μm in diameter) with multiple nuclei or a single nucleus with multiple nuclear lobes, each with a large inclusion-like nucleolus about the size of a small lymphocyte (5–7 μm in diameter).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, RS cell, EBV: Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma does not typically feature Reed-Sternberg cells. While EBV can be associated with some types of Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, the presence of RS cells is specific to Hodgkin's lymphoma.

 

Option B. Kaposi sarcoma, Giant cell, HIV: Kaposi sarcoma is associated with human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8) and often presents with spindle cells and slit-like vascular spaces, not Reed-Sternberg cells. It is more commonly associated with HIV.

 

Option D. Infectious mononucleosis, RS cell, CMV: Infectious mononucleosis is usually associated with EBV, not CMV, and while it can cause atypical lymphocytosis, it does not produce Reed-Sternberg cells, which are specific to Hodgkin's lymphoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hodgkin's lymphoma is characterized by the presence of Reed-Sternberg (RS) cells, and it is often associated with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), particularly in specific subtypes.

questions.text: All of the following cause a right shift of the oxygen- hemoglobin dissociation curve, except? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increased HbF

 

The oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve describes the relationship between the partial pressure of oxygen (PO2) and the binding of oxygen to hemoglobin in the blood. A left shift of the curve indicates an increase in the affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen, resulting in more oxygen being bound to hemoglobin at a given PO2.

 

Increased HbF has a higher affinity for oxygen than adult hemoglobin (HbA), which causes a left shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve. This allows fetal hemoglobin to extract oxygen more efficiently from the mother's blood in the placenta, where the PO2 is lower than in the adult circulation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Factors causing a right shift (decreased affinity for oxygen):

 

Option B. Raised 2,3 BPG: Increased levels of 2,3-Bisphosphoglycerate decrease hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen.

 

Option C. Acidosis: A decrease in blood pH (increased H⁺ concentration) reduces hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen.

 

Option D. Increased CO₂: Higher levels of carbon dioxide also decrease the affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve shifts to the right with factors that decrease the affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen, such as increased 2,3 BPG, acidosis, and increased CO₂. In contrast, increased fetal hemoglobin (HbF) causes a left shift, indicating higher oxygen affinity.

questions.text: The marked structure develops from which of the following structures? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Supracardinal vein

 

The supracardinal vein gives rise to the structure indicated in the provided figure, which is the azygos vein.

 

The vein network known as the azygos system serves as a conduit between the superior and inferior venae caves. It resides in the posterior mediastinum and higher portion of the posterior abdominal wall. Moreover, it links the vertebral venous, caval, and portal systems. It drains the top part of the lumbar spine and the thoracic wall.

 

Development: The azygos venous system arises from the supra cardinal veins embryologically. The right supra cardinal vein becomes the azygos vein, while the left supra cardinal vein becomes the hemiazygos vein.

 

  • The 4th to 11th right intercostal veins empties into the right supracardinal vein, which together with a portion of the posterior cardinal vein forms the azygos vein.
  • On the left, the 4th to 7th intercostal veins enters into the left supracardinal vein, and the left supracardinal vein, then known as the hemiazygos vein, which also empties into the azygos vein.
  • Cardinal veins form the main venous drainage system of the embryo. It consists of,
  • Anterior cardinal veins, which drain the cephalic part of the embryo, and
  • Posterior cardinal veins, which drain the rest of the embryo.

 

During the fifth to the seventh weeks, a number of additional veins are formed. It includes,

 

  • Subcardinal veins, which mainly drain the kidneys;
  • Sacrocardinal veins, which drain the lower extremities;
  • Supracardinal veins, which drain the body wall by way of the intercostal veins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Common cardinal vein: common cardinal veins drain the embryonic body into the sinus venosus. These are early, primitive venous systems that mainly regress but give rise to parts of the systemic venous system. Specifically, the common cardinal vein will give rise to the sinus venarum of the right atrium and the oblique vein of the left atrium.

 

Option B. Anterior cardinal vein: The anterior cardinal veins develop later and drain the cranial part of the embryo. With further development, the bilateral anterior cardinal veins will form the internal jugular vein and the brachiocephalic vein after some remodeling and anastomosis. It does not directly contribute to the formation of the azygos vein system.

 

Option D. Subcardinal vein: The subcardinal veins primarily play a role in the development of the renal and gonadal venous systems. They give rise to the renal segment of the inferior vena cava and the gonadal veins. They do not directly contribute to the formation of the azygos vein system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The supracardinal veins develop in the embryo as paired structures and are involved in the drainage of the body wall. On the right side, the supracardinal vein becomes the azygos vein, while on the left side, it contributes to the formation of the hemiazygos and accessory hemiazygos veins.

questions.text: The following set of instruments are used for which procedure? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pap smear

 

Explanation:

 

The given set of instruments are commonly used for taking a Pap smear. The instruments include:

 

  • Cusco's bivalved self-retaining speculum: Used to visualize the cervix.
  • Koplin's jar: Used to store the collected sample.
  • Slides to prepare the smear: Used for placing the collected sample.
  • Ayer's spatula and endocervical brush: Used to collect cells from the ectocervix and endocervix, respectively.
  • Fixative containing 95% ethanol: Used to preserve the collected sample on the slides.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hysteroscopy: This procedure involves using a hysteroscope to visualize the inside of the uterine cavity, and the instruments shown are not used for this purpose.

 

Option C. Biopsy: While some of these instruments might be used in a cervical biopsy, the specific combination shown is typically for a Pap smear.

 

Option D. Dilatation and curettage: This procedure involves dilating the cervix and scraping the endometrial lining, which requires different instruments than those shown.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The set of instruments shown, including Cusco's speculum, Koplin's jar, slides, Ayer's spatula, endocervical brush, and fixative, are used for performing a Pap smear to collect and preserve cervical cell samples for cytological examination.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition Pg 110,111, William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition 632, 633

choices.text: From the tip of the nose to the ear lobule to the xiphisternum.
From the angle of the mouth to the tragus to the xiphisternum.
From the ala of the nose to the angle of the mandible to the xiphisternum.
From the angle of the mouth to the ear lobule to the umbilicus

questions.text: What is the appropriate technique to measure the placement of a nasogastric tube? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) From the tip of the nose to the ear lobule to the xiphisternum.

 

This is the correct method. The nasogastric tube length is usually measured by estimating the distance from the tip of the nose, past the ear lobule (or the earlobe), and down to the xiphisternum (the point where the sternum meets the costal margin), also known as N-E-X rule. This method ensures that the tube is long enough to pass through the esophagus and reach the stomach without being too long to cause complications or too short to not be effective.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

To determine the appropriate length of a nasogastric tube (also known as Ryle's tube) used for treating intestinal obstruction or providing nutritional support, the NEX method is commonly used, which involves measuring from the tip of the nose to the ear lobule to the xiphisternum. The approximate length to be inserted is around 55 cm. The preferred position for inserting the Ryle's tube is in a sitting position with the neck slightly flexed.

 

The proper positioning of the tube can be confirmed through auscultation in the epigastric area while injecting a bolus of air or by an abdominal radiograph. The ideal placement for an NG tube used for suction is within the stomach to avoid damage to the duodenum. In contrast, an NG feeding tube should be placed post-pyloric to reduce the risk of aspiration.

 

Indications for NG tube usage include gastric decompression in intestinal obstruction, aspiration of gastric fluid, nutritional support, and medication administration. However, some absolute contraindications to NG tube insertion include severe midface trauma and recent nasal surgery.

 

A tray of specialized instruments is used for nasogastric tube insertion, including a lubricating jelly, an NG tube, a syringe, and gloves, among others.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true? (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Due to increasing mammography, there occurs over-diagnosis of breast carcinoma
  2. Colon cancer screening is done by digital rectal examination
  3. Oral cancer screening is done by visual inspection
  4. Cervix cancer screening is done by a pap smear
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 3, 4

 

Statements 1, 3 and 4 are true.

 

1. Due to increasing mammography, there occurs over-diagnosis of breast carcinoma: This is true. Mammography is an essential tool in the early detection of breast cancer, but it has been associated with over-diagnosis. As a result, some women might receive unnecessary treatment for non-life-threatening tumors.

 

2. Oral cancer screening is done by visual inspection: This is true. Visual inspection of the oral cavity can detect precancerous lesions or early signs of oral cancer. Regular dental check-ups often include a visual check for signs of oral cancer.

 

3. Cervix cancer screening is done by a pap smear: This is true. A Pap smear (or Pap test) is a procedure to test for cervical cancer in women. The test involves collecting cells from the cervix to be examined under a microscope to detect abnormalities that can turn into cervical cancer.

 

Other Option:

 

4. Colon cancer screening is done by digital rectal examination: This statement is not entirely accurate. While a digital rectal examination (DRE) can detect some abnormalities or tumors in the rectum, it is not the primary method for colon cancer screening. The primary methods for colon cancer screening include fecal occult blood testing, sigmoidoscopy, and colonoscopy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  1. Screening for common cancers using relatively non-invasive tests is expected to lead to early diagnosis, allow more conservative surgical therapies with decreased morbidity, and potentially improve surgical cure rates and overall survival rates.
  2. Current American Cancer Society guidelines advocate colon cancer screening for the average-risk population beginning at age 50 years. Recommended procedures include yearly fecal occult blood testing (FOBT)/fecal immunohistochemical testing (FIT), flexible sigmoidoscopy every 5 years, or FOBT/FIT and flexible sigmoidoscopy.
  3. Visual inspection of the oral cavity has been widely used for screening oral cancer. The target population for oral cancer screening includes those aged 30 years and older who use tobacco and/or alcohol. Advantages of visual inspection include its feasibility, safety, acceptability, accuracy to detect oral precancerous and cancerous lesions, and efficacy and cost-effectiveness in reducing oral cancer mortality.
  4. Pap smear is a screening test for cervical cancer. Screening should begin at age 21 years. For women aged between 21-29 years, screening should be done every 3 years with Pap smear examination. For women aged between 30-65 years, screening should be done every 5 years with both HPV and the Pap co-test.
  5. Using mammography as a routine screening tool in women has been reported to reduce mortality from breast cancer. The United Kingdom recently established an independent expert panel to estimate the benefits and harms associated with screening women in its national screening program. The panel estimated that breast screening resulted in a 20% reduction in breast cancer mortality. The panel also noted over-diagnosis of breast carcinoma but concluded that breast screening confers significant benefits and should be continued.

questions.text: A patient came with hypoxemia and a normal alveolar-arterial oxygen gradient. What can be the cause? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypoventilation

 

Hypoxemia with a normal alveolar-arterial (A-a) oxygen gradient typically points to specific causes where the alveolar oxygen (PAO2) and arterial oxygen (PaO2) levels remain proportionate. In this scenario, the primary causes are hypoventilation and situations involving low inspired oxygen tension (low FiO2).

 

Hypoventilation: This condition leads to hypoxemia due to inadequate ventilation. When ventilation is insufficient, the amount of oxygen entering the alveoli drops, leading to a corresponding decrease in the amount of oxygen diffusing into the blood, resulting in hypoxemia. However, because the underlying issue is with ventilation and not with oxygen diffusion or blood flow, the A-a gradient remains normal.

 

Low FiO2 or Low Barometric Pressure: This can occur in scenarios such as high altitude where the barometric pressure is low, leading to reduced oxygen availability in the air. However, these situations were not explicitly listed among the answer choices.

 

According to the reference paragraph, other conditions like ventilation/perfusion (V/Q) mismatch, diffusion limitation, and alveolar membrane damage, cause an increased A-a gradient due to impaired oxygen transfer across the alveolar membrane or mismatched ventilation and perfusion in the lungs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Right to left shunt: This condition causes hypoxemia due to blood bypassing the lungs and not getting oxygenated. It leads to an increased A-a gradient because the oxygen content of the arterial blood is significantly lower compared to the alveolar oxygen level.

 

Option B. Ventilation/Perfusion mismatch: This condition results from areas of the lung receiving oxygen but not perfused with blood or areas perfused with blood but not receiving oxygen. It causes an increased A-a gradient due to ineffective oxygen transfer to the blood.

 

Option D. Alveolar membrane damage: This results in impaired oxygen diffusion across the alveolar-capillary membrane, leading to an increased A-a gradient as oxygen transfer from alveoli to blood is hindered.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypoventilation is a primary cause of hypoxemia with a normal alveolar-arterial oxygen gradient.

questions.text: All of the following are major diagnostic criteria for allergic fungal sinusitis except? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Positive fungal culture

 

A positive fungal culture is a minor diagnostic criterion for allergic fungal rhinosinusitis.

 

This classification was detailed by Bent and Kuhn, who established criteria based on their findings of several clinical features important for the diagnosis of AFRS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Presence of nasal polyps: Polyps are a common and significant finding in AFRS, often contributing to the blockage and symptoms of sinusitis.

 

Option B. Eosinophilic mucin: A hallmark of AFRS, this refers to thick, peanut butter-like mucin with eosinophils.

 

Option C. Characteristic CT findings: These include hyperdense areas within the sinuses, which are indicative of fungal involvement and mucin accumulation.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bent and Kuhn described a diagnostic criterion for AFRS. They found 11 important clinical features, 5 of which were termed major criteria and the remaining 6 features as minor criteria. These criteria includes:

 

Ref - Scott Brown 8th edition, Volume 1, Page No. 1049

questions.text: The cell marked in the black arrow below slide is inhibitory to?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Deep nuclei of cerebellum

 

The marked structure in the image is a flask-shaped neuron in the cerebellar cortex, which is a Purkinje cell. It is inhibitory to deep cerebellar nuclei.

 

The flask-shaped cells known as Purkinje cells are found in the Purkinje cell layer of the cerebellum. They are positioned in a single layer between the molecular and granular cell layers, evenly spaced apart. Each cell's axon travels downhill, crosses the granular cell layer, and ends on the deep cerebellar nuclei, while each cell's dendrite travels upward to enter the molecular layer. They utilize GABA as their neurotransmitter and are inhibitory.

 

Axons of Purkinje cells are the only efferents of the cerebellar cortex. They receive excitatory input from the climbing fibers from the inferior olivary nucleus and mossy fibers.

 

Pathological significance of Purkinje cells:

 

  • Negri bodies in rabies are usually found as eosinophilic, cytoplasmic inclusions in the neurons of the hippocampus and Purkinje cells of the cerebellum.
  • In paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration, there is the destruction of Purkinje cells due to antibodies directed against them.
  • Purkinje cells and neurons in pyramidal cell layers of the hippocampus and cerebral cortex are the most sensitive neurons to hypoxia and are likely to be damaged in cases of global cerebral ischemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vestibular nuclei: The vestibular nuclei are located in the brainstem and are primarily involved in processing information related to balance and spatial orientation from the inner ear. While Purkinje cells can send inhibitory outputs that influence the activity of the vestibular nuclei indirectly, it is not their direct and primary target.

 

Option C. Inferior olivary nucleus: The inferior olivary nucleus is located in the medulla oblongata of the brainstem. It sends excitatory inputs to the cerebellum, specifically to the Purkinje cells, via climbing fibers. These fibers have a strong excitatory influence on Purkinje cells, but Purkinje cells do not directly inhibit the inferior olivary nucleus.

 

Option D. Basal ganglia: The basal ganglia are a group of nuclei in the brain that are associated with a variety of functions, including the regulation of voluntary motor movements, procedural learning, and cognition. While there are complex interactions between the cerebellum and basal ganglia, particularly at the level of the thalamus, Purkinje cells do not directly inhibit the basal ganglia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The deep cerebellar nuclei include the fastigial, interposed (which is further divided into the globose and emboliform nuclei), and the dentate nuclei. The axons of Purkinje cells synapse onto neurons in these nuclei. Importantly, Purkinje cells are inhibitory and utilize the neurotransmitter GABA (gamma-aminobutyric acid) to inhibit the cells of the deep cerebellar nuclei.

questions.text: At what age does a child attain half-height of the adult height? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 20-24 months

 

  • Children attain half of their adult height by the age of 20-24 months.
  • For children under 2 years of age, length is measured with the help of  an infantometer or rigid measuring table. The infant's head is held firmly against a fixed upright headboard, legs are straightened, and feet are at right angles to legs with toes pointing upwards. The length of the baby is measured from a scale set in the measuring table.
  • Measuring the length of a child lying on a mattress or using cloth tapes is inaccurate and not recommended.
  • Height is measured by asking the child to stand upright with heels, buttocks, shoulder blades, and back of the head in contact with a vertical surface such as a wall, height measuring rod, or a stadiometer. The child should look directly forward, and the headpiece is kept firmly over the head to compress the hair.

 

The growth and development of a child between the age of 18 - 24 months can be classified as,

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Children typically attain half of their adult height by 20-24 months, a critical milestone in early childhood growth and development.

questions.text: A neonate is found to have increased irritability, poor feeding, and 2 episodes of seizures. Lumbar puncture was done and the findings were suggestive of meningitis. What is the most likely causative organism? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Streptococcus agalactiae

 

  • Neonatal meningitis is suspected in the given clinical scenario. The most likely causative organism is Streptococcus agalactiae, which is part of group B streptococci.
  • Neonatal meningitis can either have an early or a late start. Late-onset meningitis affects premature infants and is typically caused by coagulase-negative staphylococci (primarily S. epidermidis), as well as S. aureus, E. coli, and Klebsiella species. Early-onset meningitis affects newborns within the first 72 hours of life.
  • Group B streptococci are the most common cause of both meningitis and neonatal sepsis, followed by E. coli. However, E. coli is the most common cause of early-onset sepsis and meningitis among very low birth weight infants (less than 1500 g).

 

Other Options:

 

Option C. Neisseria meningitidis: Asymptomatic meningococcal infections are common. If invasive disease occurs, the clinical spectrum ranges from meningococcal meningitis (which accounts for the majority of cases) to bacteremia without sepsis, meningococcal septicemia with or without meningitis, pneumonia, chronic meningococcemia, and occult bacteremia.

 

Option D. Listeria monocytogenes: Meningitis caused by Listeria monocytogenes is relatively rare but clinically significant. Infants acquire infection in utero or by inoculation through an infected birth canal. Neonatal listeriosis can be,

 

  • Early-onset neonatal disease, which occurs in infants less than 5 days old, usually within 1-2 days of birth. Predominantly septicemic form.
  • Late-onset neonatal disease, which occurs in infants >5 days old. Predominantly meningitic form.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Group B Streptococcus (Streptococcus agalactiae) is the most common cause of neonatal meningitis and sepsis, and early recognition and treatment are critical for reducing morbidity and mortality.

questions.text: An individual is in an environment of a temperature of 47°C. What is the mechanism of heat loss? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sweating

 

The mechanism of heat loss in the given case is sweating.

 

As long as skin temperature is greater than the temperature of the surroundings, heat can be lost by radiation and conduction. But when the temperature of the surroundings becomes greater than that of the skin, instead of losing heat, the body gains heat by both radiation and conduction. Under these conditions, the only means by which the body can rid itself of heat is by evaporation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radiation and B. Conduction are effective when the ambient temperature is lower than the body's skin temperature. However, at temperatures higher than the skin temperature, these methods can result in heat gain rather than heat loss.

 

Option C. Convection can aid in heat loss if the air movement can cool the skin, but at high environmental temperatures, its effectiveness is limited.

 

Educational Objective:

 

At high environmental temperatures, the body relies primarily on sweating and evaporation to lose heat and regulate body temperature effectively.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl presented with amenorrhea. On examination, she had normal genitalia & normal breast development. Her tests reveal a 5 alpha-reductase deficiency. What could be the probable diagnosis?  (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Male pseudohermaphrodite

 

  • The clinical vignette is suggestive of male pseudohermaphroditism.
  • In pseudohermaphroditism, the sex glands are of one sex while the external genitalia are of the opposite sex.
  • Male pseudohermaphroditism (male intersex) is an association of male gonads with female external genitalia.
  • In 5 alpha-reductase deficiency, there is a failure of the testis to descend to the scrotum and ill development of the penis, thereby resulting in the female phenotype.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Concealed sex: Criminals may conceal their sex to avoid detection by changing dress or by other methods. This is not relevant to the clinical scenario presented.

 

Option B. True hermaphroditism: In this condition, the glands of both sexes must be present in the same individual. Such cases are very rare. In most cases, the accessory sex gland is atrophic and lacks functional activity.

 

Option C. Female pseudohermaphrodite: The fault is at the level of an enzyme block of 17-hydroxyprogesterone (21 hydroxylase deficiency is the most common cause) leading to defective production of sex steroids. There are features of virilization (clitoromegaly and the fused labioscrotal folds resemble a rudimentary scrotum). The ovaries may descend within the inguinal canal to lie in the labia majora simulating an inguinal testis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Male pseudohermaphroditism involves male gonads with female external genitalia. In 5 alpha-reductase deficiency, there is a failure of the testis to descend and ill development of the penis, resulting in a female phenotype despite having male internal genitalia.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology  6th edition pg 443

questions.text: What should be the ideal percentage for normal sperm morphology in a seminal fluid analysis? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 4%

 

Explanation:

 

  • Morphology is the most important factor/marker of semen analysis.
  • As per the strict criteria, >4% normal forms of morphology must be present.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ideal percentage for normal sperm morphology in a seminal fluid analysis is >4% according to WHO 2010 criteria.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition Pg442, Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg232

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis from the given clinical image?  (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Uterocervical prolapse

 

The clinical image shows a case of uterocervical prolapse. This condition is common in elderly women due to weak pelvic muscles and hypoestrogenism, leading to a downward displacement of the uterus and cervix into the vaginal canal.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Uterocervical Prolapse: The uterus and cervix descend into the vaginal canal, often visualized clearly as in the image provided.
  • Differential Diagnoses:
    • Cervical carcinoma: Typically presents with a growth or ulceration on the cervix, which is not seen in this image.
    • Uterine inversion: Characterized by the uterus turning inside out, where the cervical rim would be high up around the mass, and no opening would be seen on the presenting portion.
    • Fibroid polyp: Would present as a broad mass without an opening seen on the leading portion, and the cervix would remain high up in its anatomical position.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cervical carcinoma: The image does not show any growth or ulceration, which are typical features of cervical carcinoma.

 

Option B. Uterine inversion: In uterine inversion, the cervix would be high up around the mass, and no opening would be seen on the presenting portion, which is not consistent with the image.

 

Option D. Fibroid polyp: A fibroid polyp would present as a broad mass without an opening seen on the leading portion, and the cervix would remain high up, which is not consistent with the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The clinical image showing clear visualization of the cervix along with the prolapsed uterus indicates uterocervical prolapse, a condition often seen in elderly women due to weakened pelvic muscles and hypoestrogenism.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of Gynecology 3rd edition pg548, Dutta’s textbook of Gynecology 6th edition pg 224

questions.text:
Which of the following instruments are used in the caesarean section?  (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Bard-Parker blade
  2. Doyen's retractor
  3. Cusco's speculum
  4. Allis forceps
  5. Shirodkar's uterine clamp
  6. Green Armytage forceps
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 4, 6

 

Explanation:

 

Instruments used in a cesarean section

 

  • BP handle
  • Allis forceps
  • Artery forceps
  • Doyen retractor
  • Green Armitage forceps
  • Metzenbaum scissors

 

Among the options

 

  • Cusco’s speculum has no role in LSCA It is a vaginal self-retaining speculum with two blades
  • Shirodkar’s uterine clamp is used in gynecological procedures to hold the uterus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Identify that Bard-Parker blade, Doyen's retractor, Allis forceps, and Green Armytage forceps are essential instruments used in a cesarean section, while Cusco's speculum and Shirodkar's uterine clamp are not used in this procedure.

 

Ref: Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition Page no 756

choices.text: Right internal jugular vein
Cervical sympathetic chain
Left vagus nerve
Right internal carotid artery

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl committed suicide by hanging, after a fight with her boyfriend. On conducting the autopsy, the ligature mark is seen at the lower 1/3rd of the neck and she is seen to have a protruded tongue. One side eye is open and both the pupils are dilated. What is the cause for the open eye? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Cervical sympathetic chain

 

In hanging, the ligature knot presses the cervical sympathetic Ganglion, this causes eye on the same side to remain open and pupil dilated.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Right internal jugular vein: Compression would cause venous congestion but is not directly related to the open eye and dilated pupil.

 

Option C. Left vagus nerve: Compression would affect parasympathetic innervation, potentially leading to bradycardia, but not the open eye and dilated pupil.

 

Option D. Right internal carotid artery: Compression could lead to ischemia, but it does not explain the unilateral open eye and pupil dilation.

 

Educational Objective

 

PM findings of hanging in the Neck

 

  • Petechiae-Tardieu spot
  • La facies sympathique
  • Salivary dribbling
  • Ligature mark
  • Tissues under ligature mark are dry, pale, and glistening
  • Thyroid cartilage
  • Hyoid bone fracture

questions.text: Match the following tumours with their treatment choices: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-a, 2-c, 3-b, 4-d

 

 

1. GIANT CELL TUMOR (Osteoclastoma)

 

  • It is bone lesion of uncertain origin, most commonly seen in distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal humerus and distal radius.
  • Radiological features: Eccentric lytic lesion at epiphyseal region, bounded by subchondral bone plate, with soap bubble appearance.
  • Treatment:
    • Curettage and ‘stripping’ of the cavity, followed by swabbing with  hydrogen peroxide or by the application of liquid nitrogen.
    • More aggressive tumors and recurrent lesions: Excision followed by bone grafting.

 

2. OSTEOSARCOMA

 

  • The classic form of osteosarcoma is found in the metaphyseal areas of long bones, with 50% of lesions about the knee joint.
  • The distal femur is the most common site, followed by the proximal tibia and then the proximal humerus.
  • Radiographic Findings:
    • Permeated lytic destruction of metaphyseal bone, with eventual cortical breakthrough into the subperiosteal space and subsequent formation of a Codman triangle at the diaphyseal end of the tumor.
    • As the tumor continues to push its way into the extracortical soft tissue, a typical sunburst pattern of neoplastic  bone may be seen outside the involved bone.
       
  • Management:
    • With the combination of chemotherapy and surgical treatment, the prognosis for 5-year survival is 70-80%.
    • The drugs commonly used today include high-dose methotrexate, doxorubicin, cisplatin, and ifosfamide.
    • In osteosarcoma of the extremities, limb-sparing surgery with wide resection of the tumor is the standard approach.
    • Amputation is reserved for the exceptional or recurrent case.
       

3. SIMPLE BONE CYST

 

  • Simple bone cysts are a common pseudotumor of bone.
  • They are found in the proximal humerus in 50% of cases and in the upper femur in 25%.
  • The calcaneus and pelvis are also uniquely common locations.
  • Patients are asymptomatic until a pathologic fracture occurs.
  • Radiographs typically show a solitary cyst that is centrally located in the metaphyseal area and has marked thinning of the adjacent cortical bone and a pseudoloculated appearance.
  • If there is associated fracture, radiographs may show the characteristic “fallen leaf” sign.
  • In weight-bearing bones, such as the proximal femur, lesions should be treated aggressively.
  • Management:
    • Initial management usually involves aspiration/injection with either bone marrow or corticosteroid.
    • The injections are carried out with bone biopsy needles and are repeated three to five times at intervals of 2 to 3 months, depending on the radiographic response.
    • Curettage and bone grafting may also be an effective modality.

 

4. OSTEOID OSTEOMA

 

  • The most common benign osteoid-forming tumor is the osteoid osteoma, accounting for 10% of all benign bone tumors.
  • The proximal femur is the most common location.
  • Dull, aching, nocturnal pain is characteristic, and it is commonly relieved entirely by nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) secondary to a high concentration of prostaglandins in the nidus.
  • Radiographic Feature:
    • Central, lytic nidus usually 1 cm or less in diameter. The more common cortically-based lesion exhibits extensive reactive sclerosis, creating a fusiform bulge on the bone surface. If the nidus is close to, or actually in, a joint, as in a femoral neck lesion, the resulting reactive synovitis may mimic a pyarthrosis or rheumatoid arthritis.
    • Technetium bone scans are invariably positive. A CT scan is recommended to better anatomically locate the nidus and confirm the diagnosis.
    • In the spine, the typical location for an osteoid osteoma is in the posterior elements.
       
  • Management:
    • Many cases of osteoid osteoma are stage 1 lesions and can be treated symptomatically with aspirin or NSAIDs until they spontaneously resolve. If the patient fails such treatment, intervention is warranted.
    • CT-guided radiofrequency ablation has emerged as the preferred treatment modality in many cases.
    • If open surgical excision is undertaken, the entire nidus must be eradicated.

questions.text: During a global health conference, you're in a discussion with fellow epidemiologists about the changing patterns of disease occurrence over the years. The conversation shifts towards the steady rise in non-communicable diseases over a considerable time span. One of your colleagues quizzes the group on the terminology for such a trend. Which term best describes this pattern of increasing prevalence over extended periods? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Secular 

 

  • This kind of pattern can be explained by secular trend.
  • Secular Trends (Long Term Fluctuations): Implies changes in occurrence of a disease (progressive increase or decrease) over a long period of time, generally several years or decades.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Seasonal: Seasonal trends (Periodic fluctuations) is seasonal variation/fluctuation in occurrence of a disease. Examples: Measles (early spring), upper respiratory infection (winters), gastrointestinal infection (summer).

 

Option B. Cyclical: Cyclic trend (Periodic fluctuations) is occurrence of a disease in cycles spread over short periods of time, which may be days, weeks, months or years. Examples: Measles (every 2-3 years), Rubella (every 6-9 years), Influenza pandemics (every 10-15 years).

 

Option C. Periodic: Periodic fluctuations include both Seasonal and cyclical trends.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Secular trends describe long-term changes in disease occurrence over years or decades, distinct from seasonal or cyclical variations.

questions.text: Identify the component responsible for endotoxic shock in gram-negative bacteria? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1

 

1 represents the lipopolysaccharide component which is responsible for endotoxic shock in a gram-negative cell wall.

 

 

Conventional gram-negative (LPS-diderm) bacteria display these characteristics:

 

  • An inner cell membrane is present (cytoplasmic)
  • A thin peptidoglycan layer is present (this is much thicker in gram-positive bacteria)
  • Has outer membrane containing lipopolysaccharides (LPS, which consists of lipid A, core polysaccharide, and O antigen) in its outer leaflet and phospholipids in the inner leaflet
  • Porins exist in the outer membrane, which act like pores for particular molecules
  • Between the outer membrane and the cytoplasmic membrane there is a space filled with a concentrated gel-like substance called periplasm
  • The S-layer is directly attached to the outer membrane rather than to the peptidoglycan
  • If present, flagella have four supporting rings instead of two
  • Teichoic acids or lipoteichoic acids are absent
  • Lipoproteins are attached to the polysaccharide backbone
  • Some contain Braun's lipoprotein, which serves as a link between the outer membrane and the peptidoglycan chain by a covalent bond

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2: Incorrect: Number 2 represents the flagella, which are responsible for bacterial motility, not endotoxic shock.

 

Option B. 4: Incorrect: Number 4 represents the cytoplasmic membrane, which is not involved in causing endotoxic shock.

 

Option D. 3: Incorrect: Number 3 represents the peptidoglycan layer, which provides structural support to the bacterial cell wall but does not contribute to endotoxic shock.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Differences between exotoxins and endotoxins

choices.text: FEV1 < 0.85 and FEV1/FVC <0.8
FEV1 < 0.85 and FEV1/FVC <0.75
FEV1 < 0.8 and FEV1/FVC <0.7
FEV1 < 0.8 and FEV1/FVC <0.75

questions.text:
A 60-year-old male patient has grade III ASA. Which of the following post bronchodilator PFT findings requires further evaluation of the lung function of the patient? (INICET Nov 2021)

ASA- American Society of Anesthesiology

PFT- Pulmonary function test

FEV1 - Forced expiratory volume in 1 second

FVC- Forced vital capacity
questions.solution:
Ans. C. FEV1 < 0.8 and FEV1/FVC <0.7

 

This option shows a significant reduction in both FEV1 and the FEV1/FVC ratio. An FEV1/FVC ratio of less than 0.7 is a clear indicator of obstructive lung disease. Combined with the reduced FEV1, this suggests significant lung dysfunction that requires further evaluation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. FEV1 < 0.85 and FEV1/FVC <0.8: While these values indicate some reduction in lung function, they do not meet the threshold for a definitive diagnosis of obstructive lung disease. The FEV1/FVC ratio is still above the critical cutoff of 0.7.

 

Option B. FEV1 < 0.85 and FEV1/FVC <0.75: These values suggest reduced lung function but not to the extent that is indicative of moderate or severe COPD. The FEV1/FVC ratio is below 0.8 but not yet at the critical threshold of 0.7.

 

Option D. FEV1 < 0.8 and FEV1/FVC <0.75: While the FEV1 is below 0.8, the FEV1/FVC ratio is not at the critical threshold of 0.7, so it does not indicate significant obstructive lung disease requiring further evaluation.

 

Educational Objective :

 

As per GOLD criteria for COPD, FEV1 <0.8 and FEV1/FVC <0.7 are classified as moderate COPD and require further evaluation of lung function.

 

GOLD criteria for COPD is given as follows:

 

 

Abbreviations: COPD, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease; GOLD, Global Initiative for Lung Disease

 

As per GOLD criteria for COPD, FEV1 <0.8 and FEV1/FVC <0.7 are classified as moderate COPD and require further evaluation of the lung function.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 950

questions.text: What is the gold standard investigation for the diagnosis of myocarditis? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Endo-myocardial biopsy

 

An endo-myocardial biopsy is the gold standard investigation for the diagnosis of myocarditis.

 

Active myocarditis is characterized by an interstitial inflammatory infiltrate associated with degenerating or apoptotic myocytes.

 

Etiological classification of myocarditis:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Magnetic Resonance Imaging: MRI can be used to detect myocardial inflammation and scarring, but it is not the gold standard. It is useful for non-invasive assessment but cannot definitively diagnose myocarditis without histological confirmation.

 

Option C. Brain Natriuretic Peptide (BNP): BNP is a biomarker used to assess heart failure but is not specific or sensitive for diagnosing myocarditis.

 

Option D. LDH1 to LDH2 ratio: This ratio is sometimes used in the context of myocardial infarction but does not have a role in diagnosing myocarditis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endo-myocardial biopsy remains the gold standard for diagnosing myocarditis, as it allows for direct histopathological examination of myocardial tissue.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1064

questions.text: Imagine being part of a team aiming to identify the link between a novel nutritional supplement and its potential effects on muscle growth. You're tasked with deciding the most appropriate study design to establish a cause-and-effect relationship. Among the given options, which study design would be the most effective for demonstrating a connection between cause and effect? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cohort study

 

  • Cohort study is the most effective study design for showcasing the connection between a cause and an effect. A cohort study is a type of analytical (observational) study used for ‘hypothesis testing’. It is known by several synonyms:
    • Prospective study
    • Forward looking study
    • Cause to effect study
    • Exposure to outcome study
    • Risk factor to disease study
    • Incidence study
    • Follow up study

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Case-control study: Case Control Study cannot provide with incidences, so Relative Risk cannot be calculated; In a Case Control Study, we calculate ‘an estimate of Relative Risk’, known as ‘Odds Ratio’ (CROSS PRODUCT RATIO).

 

Option C. Cross sectional study: A cross-sectional study is based on the single examination of a cross-section of a population ‘at one point of time’, results of sample are then projected to whole population. It cannot establish causality as ‘does not establish time sequence’.

 

Option D. Clinical trials: Clinical trials evaluates new studies, drugs and treatment effects on human population.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cohort studies are ideal for establishing cause-and-effect relationships by following exposures over time and observing outcomes.

questions.text: Match the following in the Japanese encephalitis virus life cycle? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-c, 2-d, 3-a, 4-b

 

The image depicts the life cycle of the Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV), which involves various hosts and vectors. Here's the correct matching:

 

  1. Accidental host (Human) - c: Humans are considered accidental hosts for JEV as they do not contribute to the ongoing transmission cycle.
  2. Amplifier (Pigs) - d: Pigs serve as amplifier hosts where the virus replicates to high levels, increasing the likelihood of mosquito transmission.
  3. Reservoir (Ardeid bird) - a: Birds, particularly Ardeid birds (herons and egrets), act as natural reservoirs of JEV.
  4. Vector (Culex) - b: Culex mosquitoes are the primary vectors that transmit JEV from reservoir hosts to amplifier hosts and to accidental hosts.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the Japanese encephalitis virus life cycle:

 

  • Humans are accidental hosts.
  • Pigs are amplifier hosts.
  • Ardeid birds are reservoir hosts.
  • Culex mosquitoes are the vectors responsible for transmission.

questions.text: A patient came to hospital who has not eaten anything for 2 days. Which of the following tests will be positive?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Only 3

 

Explanation:

 

Prolonged fasting leads to ketonuria which can be detected by Rothera’s test i.e., test 3

 

Rothera's test: Saturate 5 mL of urine with solid ammonium sulphate. Add a few drops of freshly prepared sodium nitroprusside followed by 2 mL of liquor ammonia along the sides of the test tube. Development of a purple ring indicates the presence of ketone bodies in urine. Strip tests based on the same principle are also available.

 

Other tests

 

Test 1: Benedict’s test: To 5 mL Benedict’s reagent, add 0.5 mL urine. Boil for 2 minutes. Blue, green, yellow, orange or red precipitate indicate reducing sugars. Black colour (muddy brown) is seen if homogentisic acid is present. Disaccharides may be identified by alkali destruction test. As there is low glucose in blood and will not be excreted in urine. So It will be negative.

 

The urine of a patient with diabetic keto acidosis will give positive Benedict's test as well as Rothera's test. But in starvation ketosis, Benedict's test is negative, but Rothera's test will be positive.

 

Test 2: Shows the heat coagulation test. The heat coagulation test is used to detect the presence of proteins in urine. Since proteins are generally conserved during fasting to protect muscle mass, this test will be negative, rather proteins will be conserved to protect muscles.

 

Educational Objective

 

Prolonged fasting leads to ketosis, which can be detected by Rothera’s test (test 3), resulting in a positive result for ketone bodies in the urine.

choices.text: Incontinence when patient lies down and coughs

questions.text: A 37-year-old male comes with lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS). Which of the following is not a typical presenting LUTS? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Incontinence during intercourse

 

While urinary incontinence during intercourse can occur, it is not considered a typical lower urinary tract symptom (LUTS). LUTS typically encompasses symptoms related to storage and voiding of urine. Incontinence during intercourse might be related to other causes, including psychological factors, or specific conditions impacting the pelvic floor, but it's not a routine symptom when discussing LUTS.

 

Incontinence during sexual activity is not considered a lower urinary tract symptom (LUTS).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sudden urge to urinate: This symptom is known as urgency and is a common lower urinary tract symptom. It is the sudden and strong desire to urinate, which can be difficult to delay.

 

Option B. Incontinence while asleep: This is referred to as nocturnal enuresis or bedwetting. It is a type of urinary incontinence where the patient involuntarily releases urine during sleep. This can be a symptom associated with a variety of conditions, including bladder issues, sleep disorders, or even psychological factors.

 

Option C. Incontinence when a patient lies down and coughs: This is known as stress incontinence. It occurs when physical movement or activity, such as coughing, sneezing, running, or heavy lifting, puts pressure (stress) on the bladder, causing unintentional urine leakage. It's often due to weakened pelvic floor muscles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

LUTS can be divided into three categories: storage, voiding, and post-micturitional.

 

Storage LUTS involves the failure of the bladder to act as a urine reservoir, leading to symptoms such as increased frequency of voiding, nocturia, urgency, and urge incontinence.

 

Voiding LUTS is commonly seen in bladder outlet obstruction and includes symptoms such as hesitancy, reduced stream, and straining.

 

Post-micturitional LUTS, also caused by bladder outlet obstruction, includes symptoms such as incomplete emptying and post-micturition dribble. Other symptoms of LUTS include stress incontinence, nocturnal enuresis, and strangury.

questions.text:
Which of the features given below is of a male pelvis?

 

  1. Triangular obturator foramen

  2. U-shaped pubic angle

  3. Everted ischial tuberosity

  4. Large greater sciatic notch

  5. Large acetabulum

  6. Deep preauricular sulcus
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Only 5   

 

Large acetabulum: The acetabulum in males is generally larger to support a greater range of motion and the weight of a more muscular body.

 

Other Features:

 

1. Triangular obturator foramen: Typically seen in males.

 

2. U-shaped pubic angle: This is more characteristic of the female pelvis, which has a wider pubic angle to facilitate childbirth.

 

3. Everted ischial tuberosity: This is more common in females.

 

4. Large greater sciatic notch: More pronounced in females.

 

6. Deep preauricular sulcus: More commonly seen in females.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Differences between male and female pelvis

questions.text: Which of the following differentials should not be considered for the lesion seen in the image developed in a forest officer?(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Kyasanur Forest Disease (KFD)

 

Eschar can be noted in the given image, and Kyasanur Forest Disease (KFD) is not a possible differential diagnosis for eschar.

  • KFD is a tick-borne viral hemorrhagic fever endemic in South India.
  • The primary clinical manifestations of KFD are fever, headache, severe muscle pain, followed by haemorrhagic symptoms like haemorrhages in the skin, mucosa & viscera, petechial lesions are characteristic skin lesions observed.
  • It is more known for its neurological and hemorrhagic manifestations but NOT Eschar.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Scrub typhus (chigger-borne typhus)

 

  • The infective agent of scrub typhus, Orientia tsutsugamushi (Previously known as Rickettsia tsutsugamushi), is conveyed to humans from its natural rodent reservoir by the bites of the Trombiculid mite.

 

 

  • Humans are infected when they are bitten by the mite larvae known as chiggers.
  • The incubation period is 1- 3 weeks. The primary lesion, or eschar, is a firm papule up to 1 mm in diameter surmounted by a vesicle, which dries to form a black crust.

 

Option C: Cutaneous anthrax (Hide porters’ disease)

 

  • Anthrax is a zoonotic infection with Bacillus anthracis.
  • Between 1 and 5 days after infection, an irritable papule develops at the site of inoculation. A bulla on a red oedematous base soon follows.
  • The bulla ruptures and forms a haemorrhagic crust which will undergo necrosis. Surrounding this several satellite lesions filled with serum or yellow fluid are arranged around a central necrotic lesion which is covered by a black eschar.
  • This is called as Malignant pustule as shown in the image below.

 

 

Option D: Healing brown recluse spider bite.

 

Bite of Loxosceles reclusa (Loxoscelism) → Target lesion develops → Development of eschar → Heals with Ulcer formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kyasanur Forest Disease tick-borne viral hemorrhagic fever, primarily presenting with haemorrhagic and neurological symptoms, should not be considered for skin lesion, Eschar, unlike the other mentioned differentials.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 34 page no 34.33

Ananthanarayan & Paniker’s textbook of Microbiology 10th edition Page no 249, 250, 415, 530

questions.text: Identify the marked structure in the given CT image. (INICET NOVEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pneumatised superior turbinate

 

The superior turbinates form one of the three pairs of conchae in the nose and represent part of the labyrinth of the ethmoid bone, arising as bony projections from its posterior surface.

 

The air passage between the superior nasal concha and the lateral nasal wall is known as the superior meatus and forms part of the nasal cavity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Concha bullosa is a pneumatized middle turbinate.

 

 

Option C. Onodi cell/ Sphenoethmoidal air cell is the posterior most ethmoidal air cell.

 

 

Option D. Haller cell/ infraorbital ethmoidal air cells are ethmoid air cells located lateral to the maxillo-ethmoidal suture along the inferomedial orbital floor.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pneumatisation of the superior turbinate, indicates the presence of air spaces within the turbinates, which can have implications for nasal physiology and potential sinus pathologies.

questions.text: A patient after a road traffic accident presents to the emergency room with difficulty in swallowing and slurred speech. Investigations reveal fractures in the occipitotemporal region. Which of the following areas should be tested in order to find the nerve which is involved? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 2

 

Explanation:

 

The occipitotemporal fracture in the clinical scenario is suggestive of involvement of the 9th and 10th cranial nerves, which are tested by pressing on the uvula, which is indicated as 2 in the image.

 

The jugular foramen is located between the lower border of the petrous part of the temporal bone and the condylar part of the occipital bone. As the investigations reveal fractures in the occipitotemporal region, along with the history of difficulty in swallowing and slurred speech, are suggestive of injury to the glossopharyngeal and vagus nerve passing through the jugular foramen.

 

Unilateral lesions of IX and X cranial nerves are commonly caused by skull-base fractures, strokes, or tumors.

 

Glossopharyngeal and Vagus nerve examination include:

 

  • Observing the position and symmetry of the palate and uvula(marked as 2 in the given image) at rest and with phonation ("aah").
  • The pharyngeal (gag") reflex is evaluated by stimulating the posterior pharyngeal wall on each side with a sterile, blunt object (e.g., tongue blade)

 

Individuals who have a proximal unilateral vagus nerve lesion report having trouble swallowing. On the affected side, the soft palate muscles will be weak. When the patient is asked to utter "aah," for example, an attempt to elevate the soft palate voluntarily will demonstrate a deficit in that side's ability to do so. Due to the palatal muscles' unopposed action on that side, there will also be a deviation of the uvula to the typical side along with this.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. A. 1: This area does not relate to the glossopharyngeal or vagus nerves, which are crucial in the described symptoms.

 

Option. C. 3: This area is likely distant from the jugular foramen where nerves IX and X pass, thus not directly involved with the symptoms presented.

 

Option. D. 4: This lower section of the brain and skull does not typically involve the pathways or exit points of the cranial nerves implicated in swallowing and speech functions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of occipitotemporal fractures with symptoms of difficulty in swallowing and slurred speech, it is critical to assess the function of the glossopharyngeal and vagus nerves, as these are commonly affected by such injuries. Testing should focus on the functionality of the palate and uvula where these nerves can be clinically evaluated.

questions.text: A lesion in which lobe will lead to impairment of hand-eye coordination?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Parietal lobe

 

A lesion in the parietal lobe can lead to impairment of hand-eye coordination. The parietal lobe is responsible for integrating sensory information from various modalities, including vision and touch, to create a unified perception of the body and its surroundings. It also plays a crucial role in spatial awareness and motor control.

 

In particular, the parietal lobe contains the somatosensory cortex, which is responsible for processing tactile information from the body. This information is used to create a map of the body in space, which is used to guide movement and hand-eye coordination. Damage to the parietal lobe can disrupt these processes, leading to deficits in hand-eye coordination and other motor functions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Frontal lobe: Primarily involved in motor control, decision-making, and problem-solving, but not specifically in integrating sensory information for hand-eye coordination.

 

Option C. Temporal lobe: Involved in auditory processing, memory, and language comprehension, not directly in hand-eye coordination.

 

Option D. Occipital lobe: Responsible for visual processing but does not integrate this with sensory-motor functions required for hand-eye coordination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The parietal lobe is essential for hand-eye coordination due to its role in integrating sensory information and spatial awareness, guiding movements accurately in response to visual stimuli.

questions.text: Thiamine deficiency causes lactic acidosis due to inhibition of: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) PDH (Pyruvate dehydrogenase)

 

Thiamine deficiency affects the activity of PDH, which is an enzyme complex responsible for converting pyruvate (a product of glycolysis) into acetyl-CoA, a key molecule in the citric acid cycle (Krebs cycle). When PDH is inhibited, pyruvate cannot enter the citric acid cycle, leading to an accumulation of pyruvate, which is then converted to lactic acid, resulting in lactic acidosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pyruvate carboxylase: Pyruvate carboxylase is not directly related to lactic acidosis in the context of thiamine deficiency. Its primary function is to catalyze the conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate, which can be used in various metabolic pathways.

 

Option C. Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase (PEPCK): PEPCK is involved in gluconeogenesis, a metabolic pathway that synthesizes glucose from non-carbohydrate sources. It does not directly contribute to lactic acidosis in thiamine deficiency.

 

Option D. Pyruvate kinase: Pyruvate kinase is an enzyme involved in the final step of glycolysis, where it catalyzes the conversion of phosphoenolpyruvate (PEP) to pyruvate. It is not directly associated with lactic acidosis due to thiamine deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pyruvate dehydrogenase is the enzyme affected in a patient with thiamine deficiency who develops lactic acidosis.

 

 

Enzyme performing oxidative decarboxylation need vitamin B1 for their reaction. Some examples are:

  1. PDH
  2. Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase
  3. Isocitrate dehydrogenase
  4. Branched chain keto acid dehydrogenase

 

Additional Information:

  • Marker for B1 deficiency is Transketolase activity
  • Coenzyme for simple decarboxylation: B6
  • Marker for B2 deficiency is RBC glutathione reductase activity

choices.text: TACE is used for multinodular lesions
Lenvatinib is used for lesions less than 3 cm
The incidence of HCC is increasing
NASH and NAFLD are risk factors for HCC

questions.text: Identify the false statement out of the following: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lenvatinib is used for lesions less than 3 cm

 

Lenvatinib is used to treat advanced stages of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). Treatment of lesions less than 3 cm is wide excision or liver transplant.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TACE is used for multinodular lesions: True. TACE (Transarterial chemoembolization) combined with other treatments is used for unresectable multiple nodular and massive HCC, especially when a single nodular diameter is greater than 5 cm (intermediate or advanced HCC).

 

Option C. The incidence of HCC is increasing: True. The incidence of HCC is increasing worldwide due to the increase in HCV and HBV infections, along with lifestyle disorders like obesity.

 

Option D. NASH (Non-Alcoholic Steatohepatitis) and NAFLD (Non-Alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease) are risk factors for HCC: True. Obesity is associated with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NALD), which progresses to non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) causing cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma. Thus, NASH and NAFLD are risk factors for HCC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Barcelona-Clinic-Liver Cancer (BCLC) Classification is the commonly used staging system for HCC.
  • Very early HCC is treated by ablation, early HCC with a single nodule is resected, and when there are multiple nodules over 3 cm, ablation or transplantation are considered.
  • Intermediate stage HCC is treated by chemoembolization, and TACE (Trans-arterial chemoembolization) is used for multinodular lesions.
  • Advanced stages of the disease with macrovascular invasion are treated with systemic therapies. Lenvatinib and sorafenib are first-line drugs.
  • Supportive care is given at the terminal stage of the disease.

choices.text: To determine sentinel lymph node involvement
To immediately confirm the definitive diagnosis in all cases
