questions.text: During the surgery of breast carcinoma, a frozen section was conducted. Which of the following options is incorrect regarding this procedure? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) To immediately confirm the definitive diagnosis in all cases

 

Incorrect. While a frozen section can provide rapid results, it does not replace the need for a formal and thorough pathological examination of paraffin-embedded tissue sections. The frozen section technique can sometimes result in artifacts that make interpretation challenging.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To determine sentinel lymph node involvement: Correct. A sentinel lymph node biopsy is commonly performed during breast cancer surgery, and a frozen section of the node can be examined to determine if there's cancerous involvement. If positive, complete axillary lymph node clearance can be done.

 

Option B. To assess margin positivity: Correct. During breast-conserving surgeries, the surgeon aims to remove the tumor along with a rim of normal tissue. A frozen section can be used to immediately check if the margins (edges) of the removed tissue are free of cancer cells. If cancer cells are found at the margin, additional tissue can be removed during the same procedure.

 

Option C. To evaluate metastasis: Correct. The frozen section can be used to evaluate if there's metastasis to the lymph nodes or other tissues sampled during the surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The analysis of frozen sections can assist in diagnosing nodal metastasis and identifying the involvement of sentinel lymph nodes during surgery.
  • If a positive node is detected during the procedure, the surgeon can proceed with the immediate removal of axillary lymph nodes.
  • Conversely, if the sentinel node shows no signs of tumor involvement, additional axillary dissection can be avoided.
  • In breast-conserving surgeries, frozen sections can aid in assessing tumor margins and ensuring complete removal.

questions.text: A patient presents with following lesions on the genitals. Scrapings from the lesion would show? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both A & B

 

Tzanck cells & MNGCs can be seen in Herpes lesions.

 

The provided image displays clusters of vesicles on an erythematous base, indicative of a possible diagnosis of genital herpes caused by Herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection.

 

Tzanck smear:

 

  • To perform a Tzanck smear, scrapings are obtained from the lesions, preferably from the base of the vesicles.
  • Smears are then prepared and stained with a 1% aqueous solution of O-toluidine blue for 15 seconds, which allows the visualization of acantholytic and multinucleated giant cells.
  • In Herpes infections, Tzanck smear examination may reveal the presence of Tzanck cells and multinucleated giant cells.

 

Below image depicts Acantholytic cells

 

 

Below image depicts multinucleated giant cells

 

 

  • Tzanck or Acantholytic cells are formed as a result of acantholysis, which is the breakdown of intercellular connections, like desmosomes.
  • This process leads to a reduction in cohesiveness among keratinocytes.

 

Acantholysis is classified as:

 

 

Other Option:

 

Option D. Henderson Patterson bodies:

 

  • These are intracytoplasmic inclusions seen in cells infected with molluscum contagiosum, a skin infection caused by the molluscum contagiosum virus.
  • This is not consistent with the lesion shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Herpes simplex virus infections, scrapings from lesions may show both Acantholytic / Tzanck cells and Multinucleate giant cells (MNGCs).

 

Ref - Ananthanarayan & Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology 10th edition Page no 474-476

questions.text: A patient suffered from tibial fracture following a road traffic accident. He complained of pain on passive flexion. His posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis pulses were palpable, but he had loss of sensation in the 1st webspace. What will be the next step? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Measure anterior compartment pressure

 

COMPARTMENT SYNDROME

 

  • In acute compartment syndrome, increased pressure in a close fascial space causes loss of microcirculation.
  • Most commonly compartment syndrome involves deep posterior compartment of leg > deep flexor compartment of forearm (commonest in children).
  • It is most commonly seen following fractures of supracondylar humerus and tibia.
  • Most common cause is fractures and dislocations.
  • Other causes of compartment syndrome are:
    • Crush injury/Burn/Infection/Surgical procedure/Tight circumferential dressing
    • Exercise: Exercise may increase intracompartmental pressure and muscle edema, so it is avoided in cases of acute compartmental syndrome.
       
  • Clinical Features:
    • The diagnosis is based on dramatically increasing pain (out of proportion to injury) after fracture/any injury (1st symptom) not even getting relieved on analgesics.
    • Pain and resistance on passive stretch (Distal most joint of extremity) – 1st sign
    • Order of compression of vascular structures with increase of intracompartmental pressure is: capillary compression, venous compression, arterial compression.
    • Pulselessness is a late feature and it is not a reliable indicator of compartment syndrome.
    • The presence of pulse does not exclude the diagnosis.
    • In later stages, paresthesia and paralysis ensue due to nerve involvement.
    • Pressures in the deep volar compartment are significantly elevated compared with pressures in other compartments. Deep flexor muscles are involved particularly flexor digitorum profundus > flexor pollicis longus.
    • Acute compartment syndrome presents with the following 5 Ps:

 

 

  • Treatment: 
    • The limb should be kept at the level of heart rather than elevated.
    • Removal of all circumferential dressing reduce pressure up to 85%.
    • Fasciotomy is recommended in the presence of clinical signs of compartment syndrome, such as undue pain and a palpable firmness in the forearm. The morbidity caused by fasciotomy is minimal, whereas that caused by an untreated compartment syndrome is much greater.
       
  • The general indications for fasciotomy are:
    • Impending tissue ischemia
    • When the tissue pressure reaches 30 mm Hg or the difference between diastolic blood pressure and compartment pressure is less than 30 mm Hg (Normal compartment pressure is 8-10 mm Hg and pressure at calf during walking is 200-300 mm Hg).
       
  • A higher pressure is a strong indication that fasciotomy should be recommended.
  • In a hypotensive patient, the acceptable pressure is lower.

 

Extra Edge:

 

 

Other option:

 

Option A. Reapply cast. Application of cast will further put pressure on the leg compartments. So, this treatment method will not help.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In this clinical scenario, the pain on passive flexion is the first sign of compartment syndrome. Pulselessness is the late feature. So it is advised to measure the compartment pressure first.

choices.text: Causes monofollicular development
Inhibits negative feedback on GnRH
Causes endometrial thinning
Can be used with gonadotropins

questions.text: Which of the following is the incorrect statement regarding clomiphene citrate? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Causes monofollicular development
 

  • Clomiphene citrate is SERM (Selective Estrogen Receptor Modulator) that inhibits the negative feedback of estrogen on the hypothalamus, which in turn leads to an increase in LH/FSH, and this helps in the development of multiple follicles in the ovary. Clomiphene is used in the treatment of anovulatory infertility.
  • Due to its anti-estrogenic action over the endometrium, it causes thickening of the cervical mucus and thinning of the endometrium.
  • Sometimes for ovulation induction, gonadotropins can be used with clomiphene, but it has a risk of giving rise to multiple pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Inhibits negative feedback on GnRH: This statement is correct. Clomiphene citrate inhibits the negative feedback of estrogen on the hypothalamus, which increases the release of GnRH, and subsequently increases LH and FSH secretion from the pituitary gland.

 

Option C. Causes endometrial thinning: This statement is correct. Clomiphene citrate has an anti-estrogenic effect on the endometrium, which can lead to thinning of the endometrial lining, potentially impacting embryo implantation.

 

Option D. Can be used with gonadotropins: This statement is correct. Clomiphene can be used in combination with gonadotropins for ovulation induction, but this approach increases the risk of multiple pregnancies due to the stimulation of multiple follicles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clomiphene citrate induces ovulation by inhibiting the negative feedback of estrogen on the hypothalamus, leading to increased secretion of gonadotropins and the development of multiple follicles. It can cause endometrial thinning and can be used with gonadotropins, but it does not cause monofollicular development.

questions.text: After reaching an equilibrium state during exercising, it was found that the body was consuming oxygen at the rate of 1500 ml/min. Calculate the MET score if the baseline oxygen consumption at rest is 250 ml/min? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 6

 

MET (Metabolic Equivalent) is a unit used to estimate the energy expenditure of physical activities as a multiple of the resting metabolic rate (RMR). One MET is equal to the energy expended at rest, which is approximately 3.5 mL of oxygen per kilogram of body weight per minute (ml/kg/min).

 

To calculate the MET score for a given level of oxygen consumption, we need to first convert the oxygen consumption rate from ml/min to ml/kg/min, and then divide it by the resting oxygen consumption rate to get the MET value.

 

Assuming an average body weight of 70 kg, the oxygen consumption rate of 1500 ml/min corresponds to 21.4 ml/kg/min (1500 ml/min ÷ 70 kg).

 

Dividing this value by the resting oxygen consumption rate of 250 ml/min, we get:

 

MET score = 21.4 ml/kg/min ÷ 3.5 ml/kg/min ≈ 6

 

Therefore, the correct answer is B. 6.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The MET score represents the energy expenditure of an activity as a multiple of the resting metabolic rate.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presented with confusion, constipation, and persistent low mood. ALP was elevated. She was diagnosed with primary hyperparathyroidism. Which of the following is the imaging of choice? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sestamibi scan

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical features of 40-year-old woman with confusion, constipation, along with persistent low mood is suggestive of hypercalcemia, which could be due to primary Hyperparathyroidism.

 

IOC for parathyroid adenoma: Tc99-Sestamibi scan

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MRI: While MRI can provide detailed soft tissue images, it is not the preferred imaging modality for detecting parathyroid adenomas.

 

Option B. FDG PET: PET scans are used in cancer imaging and are not specific for identifying parathyroid adenomas.

 

Option C. CT: While CT scans can identify anatomical details and some tumors, they lack the specificity of Sestamibi scans in identifying hyperactive parathyroid tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A Sestamibi scan is specifically useful for identifying parathyroid adenomas in patients suspected of having primary hyperparathyroidism, due to its ability to effectively localize hyperfunctioning parathyroid tissue.

questions.text: Identify the method of killing shown in the picture below : (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Burking

 

  • Burking is a method of homicidal smothering with traumatic asphyxia.

  • In Burking the assaulter kneels or sits on the chest (traumatic asphyxia) and close the nose and mouth with his hands (smothering)

  • The term 'Burking' is derived from notorious criminal 'Burke', who with his accomplice 'Hare', killed old people by a combination of smothering and traumatic asphyxia, and sold the bodies to the medical school in Edinburgh.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Smothering: This involves blocking the airways by covering the nose and mouth but does not necessarily include the chest compression seen in Burking.

 

Option C. Traumatic asphyxia: This involves compression of the chest, but without the simultaneous smothering of the airways, it does not constitute Burking.

 

Option D. Overlaying: This typically refers to accidental asphyxia, often seen in infants, where a person (usually a caregiver) unintentionally rolls over the child during sleep, causing suffocation. This is not depicted in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Burking involves a combination of smothering and traumatic asphyxia, characterized by chest compression and obstruction of the airways, a method historically associated with the criminal activities of Burke and Hare.

choices.text: Conventional PCR with Restriction Fragment Length pair technique
RT-PCR followed by Real time PCR

questions.text: Which of the following is more appropriate for quantitative analysis of viral RNA genome?(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) RTPCR followed by Real time PCR

 

RT-PCR followed by Real time PCR

 

To quantitatively analyze viral RNA genomes, two key processes are required:

 

  1. Reverse Transcription (RT): Viral RNA must first be converted into complementary DNA (cDNA) because PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction) can only amplify DNA. This is done using Reverse Transcriptase, hence RT-PCR (Reverse Transcription PCR).
  2. Quantification using Real Time PCR (qPCR): Once the cDNA is synthesized, Real-Time PCR is used to quantify the amount of target nucleic acid in real time using fluorescent markers.

 

 

Thus, for quantitative analysis of viral RNA:
 

  • First step → RT-PCR
  • Second step → Real-Time PCR (qPCR)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Real Time PCR: This refers to quantification but only works with DNA, not directly with RNA. Without the reverse transcription step, it cannot quantify viral RNA.
 

Option B. Conventional PCR with RFLP: This is qualitative and used for genotyping or mutation detection, not quantitative analysis.
 

Option C. RT-PCR: RT-PCR alone allows detection of RNA (qualitative), but not quantification unless combined with Real-Time PCR.

 

Educational Objective:


RT PCR followed by Real-time PCR is the most appropriate technique for quantitative analysis of viral RNA genomes, allowing real-time monitoring and quantification of viral RNA load.

questions.text: Double bleb sign seen in early pregnancy is due to? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Yolk sac and amniotic sac

 

Explanation:

 

The double bleb sign is due to the yolk sac and amniotic sac.

 

On USG, gestational sac contains the yolk sac and amniotic sac which appear as two small bubbles known as the double bleb sign.

 

It is seen at 7.5 – 8 weeks.

 

Do not confuse with Double decidual sign

 

 

Double decidual sign – true gestational sac surrounded by two layers – decidua capsularis and decidua parietalis with fluid collection in between.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Twin pregnancy: This would involve two separate gestational sacs or distinct embryonic structures in a single sac, not the double bleb sign of a single gestational sac.

 

Option B. Amnion and chorion: These are two layers surrounding the embryo, but the double bleb sign specifically refers to the early visualization of the yolk sac and amniotic sac.

 

Option D. Heterotopic pregnancy: Involves simultaneous intrauterine and extrauterine pregnancies. This would not specifically relate to the double bleb sign, which is a normal ultrasound finding in a single intrauterine pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The double bleb sign is a normal ultrasound finding in early pregnancy, showing the presence of both the yolk sac and the amniotic sac within the gestational sac, important for confirming a normal early intrauterine pregnancy.

choices.text: Luteal phase LH
Post luteal phase LH
FSH in the follicular phase

questions.text: Which of the following is the best measures ovarian reserve? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH)

 

Explanation:

 

  • Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH) is a glycoprotein secreted by the granulosa cells of pre-antral follicles. It is the best marker of ovarian reserve because it can be tested on any day of the cycle.
  • Values and Interpretation:
    • Normal value: 2-6.8 ng/mL
    • Poor ovarian reserve: <1 ng/mL
    • Polycystic Ovary Disease (PCOD) and Hyperstimulation Syndrome: >10 ng/mL

 

Tests for ovarian reserve:

 

  • FSH levels: Measured in the early follicular phase (Day 2 or 3 of the menstrual cycle). High FSH means the ovarian reserve is getting depleted.
  • Serum estradiol values: Measured on day 3 of the cycle. Serum estradiol >75 pg/mL indicates ovarian hypofunction.
  • Antral follicular count on ultrasound: Counts less than 4-5 on days 2-5 denote poor response to hormones.
  • Inhibin B: Values <40 pg/mL indicate poor reserve.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Luteal phase LH: Not a reliable measure of ovarian reserve.

 

Option B. Post luteal phase LH: Not a reliable measure of ovarian reserve.

 

Option C. FSH in the follicular phase: While useful, it is less reliable than AMH for assessing ovarian reserve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH) is the best marker of ovarian reserve as it can be tested on any day of the menstrual cycle and provides a reliable measure of the ovarian reserve.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition Pg 528,529, William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg435

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient with class II pulmonary hypertension presents with a negative vasoreactivity test. Which of the following is used in the next step of management? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ambrisentan

 

Pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) management depends on the results of the vasoreactivity test. In patients with a negative vasoreactivity test, calcium channel blockers such as nifedipine are not effective. Instead, treatment typically involves the use of endothelin receptor antagonists, phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors, or prostanoids.

 

For a patient with WHO functional class II PAH and a negative vasoreactivity test, the next step in management often includes endothelin receptor antagonists like Ambrisentan. Ambrisentan works by blocking the effects of endothelin-1, a potent vasoconstrictor, thereby reducing pulmonary vascular resistance and improving symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iloprost: Iloprost is a prostacyclin analog, used primarily in more advanced stages of PAH (class III or IV) or when other treatments have failed. It is not typically the first-line treatment for class II PAH with a negative vasoreactivity test.

 

Option C. Nifedipine: Nifedipine, a calcium channel blocker, is used in patients with a positive vasoreactivity test. Since this patient has a negative vasoreactivity test, nifedipine is not appropriate.

 

Option D. Epoprostenol: Epoprostenol is another prostacyclin analog used in advanced PAH (class III or IV) or refractory cases. It is not typically used for initial treatment in class II PAH with a negative vasoreactivity test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In class II and class III pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH), the best option is to use a combination of a phosphodiesterase inhibitor like Tadalafil and an endothelin receptor antagonist like Ambrisentan. Combination therapy is preferred, even though it may not be listed in all options. For refractory class III and class IV PAH patients, prostanoids are used.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with hypertension? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Liddle syndrome

 

Liddle syndrome is a genetic disorder characterized by the overactivation of the epithelial sodium channels (ENaC) in the principal cells of the kidneys. This overactivation is due to a gain-of-function mutation in the genes encoding these channels. The increased activity of ENaC leads to excessive reabsorption of sodium and water, causing hypertension. Concurrently, there is increased excretion of potassium and hydrogen ions, which results in hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis.

 

This condition is often referred to as pseudo-hyperaldosteronism because it mimics the effects of aldosterone but without elevated aldosterone levels. The treatment of choice for Liddle syndrome is amiloride, which directly inhibits ENaC channels, unlike spironolactone, which is ineffective in this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bartter syndrome: Bartter syndrome also presents with hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis, but patients typically have normal blood pressure. It is a group of autosomal recessive disorders that affect the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, mimicking the effects of loop diuretics. Symptoms often present in childhood and may include polyuria, polydipsia, and growth delays. Additionally, patients might have nephrocalcinosis due to increase urinary calcium, recurrent urinary stones, and sometimes sensorineural deafness.

 

Option C. Gitelman syndrome: Gitelman syndrome, like Bartter syndrome, involves hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis with normal blood pressure. It affects the distal convoluted tubule of the kidney, similar to the action of thiazide diuretics. Patients usually present in adulthood with symptoms such as muscle weakness, cramps, and tetany due to hypomagnesemia, which is a significant feature distinguishing it from Bartter syndrome.

 

Option D. Gordon syndrome: Gordon syndrome, or pseudohypoaldosteronism type II, is characterized by hypertension and hyperkalemia, along with metabolic acidosis, not alkalosis. It results from mutations leading to increased sodium chloride reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule. Unlike Liddle syndrome, patients with Gordon syndrome exhibit hyperkalemia and acidosis due to chloride retention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Liddle syndrome is characterized by hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis and hypertension due to the overactivation of epithelial sodium channels in the kidneys.

questions.text: The most specific and typical sign of juvenile dermatomyositis in a 17-year-old patient is?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gottron's papules

 

  • Gottron's papules are a characteristic and specific sign seen in juvenile dermatomyositis.
  • The classical diagnostic criteria for Juvenile Dermatomyositis include the presence of Gottron's papules and heliotrope rash.
  • Gottron's papules are identified as violaceous, lichenoid, inflammatory, flat-topped papules found on the extensor surfaces, particularly the knuckles ( proximal interphalangeal joints, distal interphalangeal joints, and metacarpophalangeal joints) as shown in the image below.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Photosensitive skin rash:

 

  • While photosensitivity can be a feature in some patients with juvenile dermatomyositis, it is not the most specific sign.
  • Photosensitive rashes are also common in other conditions like systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) making it less specific to juvenile dermatomyositis.

 

Option B. Nail bed capillary changes:

 

  • Nail bed capillary changes, such as dilated or drop-out capillaries, can be seen in juvenile dermatomyositis as shown in the image below

 

 

  • However, these changes are also found in other connective tissue diseases, so they are not the most specific for juvenile dermatomyositis.

 

Option D. Malar rash:

 

  • A malar rash, or "butterfly rash" as shown in the image below is typically associated with SLE, not juvenile dermatomyositis.

 

 

  • Although skin manifestations can overlap between different connective tissue diseases, a malar rash is not specific to juvenile dermatomyositis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gottron's papules are flat-topped, red or violaceous papules. They are considered pathognomonic (specifically indicative) of dermatomyositis and are one of the hallmark features of the disease and represent the most specific sign of juvenile dermatomyositis in a 17-year-old patient.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 53, page nos. 53.4, 53.11

Nelson textbook of pediatrics 21st edition Page no 1182, 1183

questions.text: Milk production in pregnancy is inhibited by? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) High estrogen


Milk production in pregnancy is inhibited primarily by high estrogen levels. Although prolactin, an anterior pituitary hormone, is responsible for stimulating milk production (lactogenesis), high levels of estrogen and progesterone during pregnancy prevent the secretion of milk. Estrogen promotes the development of the mammary glands but suppresses milk production. After childbirth, the levels of estrogen and progesterone drop, which allows prolactin to initiate and sustain milk secretion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low luteinizing hormone: Incorrect. Luteinizing hormone (LH) is not directly involved in the regulation of milk production. The primary inhibitors are estrogen and progesterone.

 

Option C. Human somatomammotropin: Incorrect. Human somatomammotropin (also known as human placental lactogen) supports breast development and promotes milk production but does not inhibit it.

 

Option D. Low thyroid-stimulating hormone: Incorrect. Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) is not a primary factor in inhibiting milk production during pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:


High estrogen levels inhibit milk production during pregnancy.

 

Ref: Page no 173, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 6th edition

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis?  (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vulval cancer

 

Explanation:

 

  • The given image shows a 4 cm × 5 cm irregular fungating lesion present on the left labium majus of the vulva. The most likely diagnosis is vulvar carcinoma.
  • Vulvar cancer is typically characterized by irregular, fungating, or ulcerative lesions on the vulva. These lesions can be painful and may bleed or discharge.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vulval hematoma: Vulval hematomas may occur due to direct trauma or accidental injuries. They present as a localized collection of blood within the vulvar tissues, leading to swelling and bruising, but they do not typically form irregular fungating lesions.

 

Option B. Condyloma acuminata: Condyloma acuminata, also known as genital warts, are commonly caused by HPV types 6 and 11.

 

They appear as multiple, small, cauliflower-like growths and are not typically large, irregular, or fungating.

 

Option D. Bartholin cyst: A Bartholin cyst occurs when the duct of the Bartholin gland gets blocked due to infection, resulting in a buildup of glandular secretions.

 

It presents as a swelling on one side of the vaginal opening, but it is typically smooth and round, not irregular and fungating.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vulvar cancer often presents as an irregular, fungating lesion on the vulva.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg 337,338

questions.text: Identify the finding marked by the arrow in the below image: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vossius ring

 

  • The image shows a Vossius ring, which is a circular ring of faint or stippled opacity seen on the anterior surface of the lens.
  • It is caused by brown amorphous granules of pigment lying on the capsule of the lens and is usually seen after blunt trauma to the eye and orbit.
  • The force of the blow drives the cornea and iris backward, producing an impression of the iris on the lens.
  • The ring usually has about the same diameter as the contracted pupil.
  • The resorption of the pigment results in discrete subcapsular opacities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Weiss ring: Is a floater which may be seen by the patient as a circle or other large solitary lesion. It is the detached former attachment to the margin of the optic disc. It is seen in posterior vitreous detachment and is not confirmatory. It is seen in the image below.

 

 

Option C. A Fleischer's ring: Is usually observed in keratoconus, representing epithelial iron deposits. It is seen best with a cobalt blue filter.

 

 

Option D. Kayser-Fleischer ring: Is observed in Wilson's disease, due to intraocular deposition of copper. A brownish-yellow zone is seen in the peripheral Descemet membrane of the cornea. Anterior capsular cataract, also knowns as a sunflower cataract may be seen in some patients.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Vossius ring is an important clinical marker of previous blunt trauma to the eye, characterized by pigment imprint from the iris on the lens surface, mirroring the size of the contracted pupil at the time of impact.

choices.text: Transurethral resection of the bladder tumour

questions.text: An adult male patient in his 60s presented to the outpatient department with a complaint of haematuria. Upon examination, a 2x2 cm bladder mass was observed, which was diagnosed as a low-grade transitional cell carcinoma. What is the recommended course of action for this patient? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Transurethral resection of the bladder tumour

 

For this patient diagnosed with bladder carcinoma, transurethral resection of bladder tumor (TURBT) is the most beneficial treatment option among the given choices. Based on the available evidence, there is no indication of muscle invasion or advanced cancer, suggesting that the most probable pathological stage is pTa - low grade non-muscle invasive cancer, for which TURBT followed by intravesical chemotherapy is the recommended treatment. TURBT is performed to pathologically stage the tumor and determine the appropriate course of treatment. Intravesical therapy using chemotherapy or immunotherapy is administered after TURBT to eradicate any residual cancer cells in the bladder lining, but it is not effective against cancers that have spread to muscle layers.

 

This is the correct answer. TURBT is a standard initial procedure for diagnosing and treating visible tumors, especially for low-grade, noninvasive disease. It involves removing the tumor from the bladder wall via the urethra. The stage of the bladder cancer can be determined by examining the sample removed during a TURBT, which aids in further treatment decisions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Resection with ileal conduit: This is a more invasive surgery typically used for muscle invasive bladder cancers (radical cystectomy). An ileal conduit is a urinary diversion technique where urine is redirected through a piece of the intestine and out to a stoma on the abdomen.

 

Option C. Partial cystectomy with bladder reconstruction: This involves removing a part of the bladder affected by cancer. It's reserved for select patients where the tumor is localized and not near the urethral or ureteral openings. It might not be the first line of treatment for a 2x2 cm low-grade tumor.

 

Option D. Neo-adjuvant chemotherapy: This refers to chemotherapy given before a primary treatment in advanced cancers. In the case of bladder cancer, neo-adjuvant chemotherapy might be used before a surgery to shrink the tumor size or improve outcomes. However, for a low-grade, small tumor, it is not typically the first line of treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Non-muscle invasive bladder tumors (pTa/pT1): TUR-BT + Intravesical chemotherapy

 

Muscle invasive (pT2/pT3 and some pT4): Radical cystectomy + Ileal conduit

questions.text: Which of the following is not glucogenic?(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acetyl coenzyme A

 

  • Acetyl CoA is not glucogenic. It enters the citric acid cycle (Kreb's cycle) for energy production and cannot be directly converted into glucose. It is primarily used for energy generation in the form of ATP.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oxaloacetate: Oxaloacetate is a glucogenic compound. It can be converted into glucose through a series of enzymatic reactions in the gluconeogenesis pathway. This makes it a precursor for glucose synthesis.

 

Option C. Lactate: Lactate is a glucogenic compound. It can be converted into pyruvate in the Cori cycle, and pyruvate can then be used in gluconeogenesis to produce glucose.

 

Option D. Pyruvate: Pyruvate is a glucogenic compound. It serves as a central molecule in both glycolysis and gluconeogenesis, making it a key intermediate in the conversion of various substrates into glucose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acetyl CoA is not a glucogenic compound as it cannot be directly converted into glucose, unlike oxaloacetate, lactate, and pyruvate, which are glucogenic and contribute to glucose synthesis.

 

Substrates of gluconeogenesis (mostly 3C)                                                                                     

  1. Pyruvate (3C)
  2. Lactate (3C)                                                              
  3. Propionic acid (3C)
  4. Glycerol (3C)                                                       
  5. Glucogenic amino acids (18 amino acids)
  6. Both Ketogenic & Glucogenic amino acids
  7. Any TCA Intermediate (forms oxaloacetate which can enter gluconeogenesis)

questions.text: During resuscitation in a patient with severe hypotension and cardiac arrhythmias, a patient received a 20% Intralipid injection. What could have been the most probable diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Local anesthesia toxicity

 

Intralipid (20% lipid emulsion) is used as a treatment for local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST). If a patient accidentally receives an excessive dose of local anesthetic, or if the local anesthetic is inadvertently injected into a blood vessel, it can lead to systemic toxicity, manifesting as CNS symptoms (like seizures) and cardiovascular collapse. Intralipid acts as a lipid sink, effectively reducing the concentration of the local anesthetic in the plasma and thereby reversing the toxic effects. This is why this option is the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Asphyxia due to drowning: While drowning can certainly lead to hypotension and arrhythmias, it does so because of hypoxia and other related complications. Intralipid injection is not a recognized treatment for drowning and its consequences.

 

Option C. Electrocution: While electrocution can cause cardiac arrhythmias and other cardiac problems, the primary treatment is to address the rhythm disturbances directly, treat burns, and support the patient. Intralipid would not be used in this context.

 

Option D. Pulseless electrical activity (PEA): PEA refers to a condition where there is organized or semi-organized electrical activity in the heart (seen on EKG) but no palpable pulse. The treatment for PEA is high-quality CPR, following the advanced cardiac life support (ACLS) algorithm, and addressing any potential reversible causes. Intralipid is not a standard treatment for PEA.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Intralipid (20% lipid emulsion) is used specifically for treating local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST) by acting as a lipid sink to reduce the concentration of the local anesthetic in the plasma.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 885

questions.text: A researcher in epidemiology is planning to conduct a meta-analysis to better understand the effects of a specific intervention. While he lists the various stages and processes associated with a meta-analysis, he includes one element that isn't typically involved in a meta-analysis. Which of the following isn't directly associated with the process of a meta-analysis? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Randomization 

 

  • Randomization is not a part of the meta-analysis process but is a critical component of randomized controlled trials (RCTs), which may be included in a meta-analysis.
  • Meta-analysis involves analysis of multiple studies together.
  • Steps of Meta-analysis involves Hypothesis formation, Study selection, Formulation of data, Analysis of data, examining bias, formulating conclusion.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Selection: Involves selecting studies for inclusion in the meta-analysis.

 

Option B. Analysis: Involves statistical analysis of the combined data from the selected studies.

 

Option D. Abstraction: Involves extracting data from the studies for inclusion in the meta-analysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Randomization is a part of conducting individual randomized controlled trials, not the process of performing a meta-analysis.

questions.text: What is the dose of carbetocin used in the prevention of postpartum hemorrhage? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 100 mcg

 

  • 100 mcg of carbetocin is used in the prevention of postpartum hemorrhage (PPH).
  • The use of carbetocin (100 mcg, IM/IV) is recommended for the prevention of PPH.
  • It is a long-acting synthetic analog of oxytocin which is stable at room temperature (unlike oxytocin which needs the cold chain to be maintained.
  • To effectively prevent PPH, the WHO recommends the use of only one of the following uterotonic agents:
    • Oxytocin (10 IU - IM/IV)
    • Carbetocin (100 ug - IM/IV)
    • Misoprostol (400 g or 600 g, per-oral)
    • Ergometrine/methylergometrine (200 ug - IM/IV)
    • Oxytocin and ergometrine fixed-dose combination (5 IU,500g - IM)
  • Of these, oxytocin is used as the first-line agent (drug of choice) for AMTSL.

 

Educational Objective:


The recommended dose of carbetocin for the prevention of postpartum hemorrhage is 100 mcg, administered either IM or IV.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the quadruple screening test? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inhibin B

 

The triple and Quadruple test are done between 15 – 21 weeks.

 

  • Components of Triple test are: Free β hCG, unconjugated Estriol (uE3) and Maternal Serum α-fetoprotein.
  • Components of the Quadruple test are: Free β hCG, unconjugated Estriol (uE3), Maternal Serum α-fetoprotein. And Inhibin A.

 

 

*Easy to remember: B for Big; so in Down’s syndrome; Beta hCG and InhiBin A: Big/ Increased

 

Educational Objective:

 

The quadruple screening test includes Free β hCG, unconjugated Estriol (uE3), Maternal Serum α-fetoprotein (AFP), and Inhibin A. Inhibin B is not included in the quadruple test.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Identify the virus given in the following replication cycle? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Herpes simplex virus

 

The given image shows the life cycle of the herpes simplex virus (HSV).

 

The herpes virus is a linear double-stranded DNA virus with an icosahedral capsid. The envelope has glycoprotein spikes.

 

Steps of HSV replication:

 

  • The virus enters the cell by fusing with the plasma membrane
  • Viral DNA is released from the capsid at the nuclear pore.
  • Transcription of immediate-early genes - alpha-Proteins
  • Transcription of late genes produces y-proteins which consist of viral structural proteins and participate in virion assembly.
  • Viral DNA is cleaved from concatemers and then packaged into capsids.
  • Viral particles which are enveloped, collect in the endoplasmic reticulum
  • They are transported to cell surface by a vesicular movement

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) virus is spherical, enveloped virus with an icosahedral shell and a cone-shaped core which encloses the ribonucleoproteins. It consists of two identical single-stranded, RNA copies, with the reverse transcriptase enzyme, which is a characteristic feature of retroviruses.

 

HIV virus life cycle.

 

 

Option C. The hepatitis B virus is a DNA virus. It has an outer envelope and an inner nucleocapsid. It contains two linear strands of DNA in a circular configuration. One of the strands (the plus strand is incomplete resulting in partially double stranded and partially single-stranded DNA.

 

 

Option D. Corona viruses: The genome of coronaviruses is made up of positive sense, unsegmented single-stranded RNA. Coronaviruses are enclosed RNA viruses. They feature surface projections in the form of petals. In the cytoplasm, coronavirus nucleocapsids grow and mature by budding into cytoplasmic vesicles. The structure and life cycle of coronaviruses are depicted in the figures below.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Herpes simplex virus (HSV), is characterized by steps involving the fusion of the virus with the plasma membrane, nuclear entry, transcription, replication, capsid assembly, glycosylation, and virus release.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents to the emergency department with intermittent episodes of severe colicky abdominal pain, vomiting, and passage of currant jelly stools. The clinical suspicion is towards intussusception. Taking the child's immunization history, which recent vaccine could be associated with a slightly increased risk of this condition? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rotavirus vaccine

 

Rotavirus vaccine is associated with a complication of intussusception.

 

ROTA virus vaccines

 

  • 4 Types – but 2 used in NIS
  • ROTAVAC and ROTASIL (live, att., lyophilized with diluent citrate bicarbonate buffer)
  • ROTAVAC →1 dose = 0.5 ml
  • ROTASIIL → 1 dose – 2.5 ml with 6 ml syringe
  • 3 doses – 6, 10, 14 weeks
  • Complication - INTUSSUSCEPTION

 

 

 

Other 3 Options: Not associated with intussusception.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rotavirus vaccine is associated with a rare complication of intussusception, an important consideration when assessing an infant presenting with symptoms of this condition.

questions.text: Identify the imaging modality given below? (INCET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) USG

 

Explanation:

 

The given image is suggestive of USG of the neck.

 

The thyroid gland, muscles, blood vessels, bony structures or cartilages, and nerves are all visible on a sonographic examination of the neck.

 

On USG, normal thyroid appears homogeneously hyperechoic with a uniform echotexture. Large blood vessels (the common carotid artery and, more laterally, the internal jugular vein) can be seen laterally to the thyroid.

 

USG is the radiological IOC to evaluate thyroid nodules.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fluoroscopy: Primarily used for real-time imaging of moving body structures using X-rays, which is not indicated by the type of static image and detail shown.

 

Option C. X-Ray: Typically shows denser tissues like bones and lacks the detailed soft tissue contrast visible in this ultrasound image.

 

Option D. MRI: Provides high-resolution images of internal structures using magnetic fields and radio waves, typically not showing the real-time flow or specific echogenic properties visible in ultrasound images.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ultrasound (USG) is the imaging modality of choice for evaluating the thyroid and other neck structures due to its ability to provide detailed images of soft tissue structures without exposure to ionizing radiation. It is particularly useful for assessing the thyroid gland, including the evaluation of nodules and vascular structures.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old male patient with heart failure is scheduled for a heart transplant. His renal function test is deranged, and hemoglobin is 6 g/dL. The physician ordered 2 units of whole blood. Four hours after transfusion, he developed severe respiratory distress. On examination, he is hypoxemic, has tachycardia, and his mean arterial pressure is elevated. Which of the following are the best investigations for the above scenario? (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Chest X-ray
  2. Brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) level
  3. Absolute neutrophil count
  4. Leucocyte antibodies
  5. Platelets
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 and 2

 

The patient presents with signs and symptoms indicative of transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO), which includes elevated mean arterial pressure, hypoxemia, and respiratory distress following a blood transfusion. TACO occurs due to fluid overload from the transfusion, leading to pulmonary edema and increased cardiac filling pressures.

 

1. Chest X-ray: This imaging is crucial as it can reveal bilateral infiltrates indicative of pulmonary edema, a hallmark of TACO. It helps to differentiate between TACO and other causes of respiratory distress post-transfusion.

 

2. Brain Natriuretic Peptide (BNP) Level: BNP is a cardiac biomarker that is elevated in conditions of increased cardiac pressure and volume overload, such as TACO. Elevated BNP levels would support the diagnosis of TACO, whereas BNP levels would not be elevated in transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI), another potential complication post-transfusion that presents with respiratory distress but usually with hypotension.

 

Other Options:

 

3. Absolute neutrophil count and 5. platelets are not specific for diagnosing TACO or TRALI. These parameters do not provide information on fluid overload or cardiac stress.

 

4. Leucocyte antibodies are not directly relevant to the diagnosis of TACO. Leucocyte antibodies might be involved in TRALI, but not TACO.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with suspected transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO), the best investigations are a chest X-ray to detect pulmonary edema and BNP levels to assess cardiac stress and fluid overload

questions.text: Fibers from the marked structure end in which of the following areas of the thalamus?(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Anterior nucleus

 

The anterior nucleus of the thalamus is where the fibres from the mamillary body, which is the structure seen in the above figure, terminate.

 

The third ventricle's floor is made up of two tiny, hemispherical, pea-sized eminences called mammillary bodies, which are arranged side by side. The anterior thalamic nucleus receives fibres from the medial mammillary nucleus.

 

The anterior thalamic nuclei have 3 subdivisions -anteroventral nucleus, anteromedial nucleus, and anterodorsal nucleus.

 

  • Major input: Mammillothalamic tract from the mammillary nuclei of the hypothalamus.
  • Major cortical output: Anterior limbic area, cingulate, and the parahippocampal gyrus
  • Major function:
    • Regulation of alertness and attention
    • Acquisition of memory

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior nucleus: The posterior nuclear group, also known as the pulvinar, is the largest nuclear group in the thalamus. It is involved in the integration of visual, auditory, and somatosensory information. The mammillothalamic tract does not terminate in the posterior nucleus.

 

Option B. Reticular nucleus: The reticular nucleus of the thalamus surrounds the lateral aspect of the thalamus and serves as a modulator of information transfer between different parts of the thalamus and the cerebral cortex. It primarily functions to regulate the activity of relay nuclei in the thalamus. While it plays an important role in modulating thalamic function, the mammillothalamic tract does not primarily terminate here.

 

Option D. Ventral Lateral nucleus: The ventral lateral nucleus is one of the principal relay nuclei of the thalamus that receives inputs from the cerebellum and the basal ganglia and projects to the primary motor cortex. It is involved in the coordination and planning of movements. The mammillothalamic tract does not terminate in the ventral lateral nucleus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anterior nuclear group of the thalamus is involved in emotional tone and recent memory. Fibers from the mammillary bodies, via the mammillothalamic tract, terminate in the anterior nuclei of the thalamus. The connection between the mammillary bodies and the anterior thalamic nucleus is a crucial part of the Papez circuit.

questions.text: Which one of the following is the most radioresistant phase of the cell cycle? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) S phase

 

Explanation:

 

S phase of the cell cycle is considered the most radioresistant. During the S phase, cells are actively duplicating their DNA. The replication machinery during this phase makes the DNA less accessible to radiation-induced damage and the cell has enhanced mechanisms to repair any damage that does occur, thereby making it more resistant to the effects of radiation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. M phase: The mitotic phase where cells are actively dividing. This phase and G2 are often considered more radiosensitive because cells are highly vulnerable to damage during mitosis.

 

Option C. G1 phase: The first gap phase where cells grow and prepare to synthesize DNA. This phase is relatively more radiosensitive compared to the S phase.

 

Option D. G2 phase: The second gap phase right before mitosis where cells prepare to divide. This phase is typically more radiosensitive, as cells are preparing for mitosis and have less capability for DNA repair compared to the S phase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

S phase is the most radioresistant phase of the cell cycle.

questions.text: Which of the following congenital heart disease has equal saturation in all the chambers of the heart? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Total anomalous pulmonary venous circulation

 

  • TAPVC is a congenital heart defect where oxygenated blood from the pulmonary veins does not reach the left atrium but instead reaches the right atrium, which contains deoxygenated blood.
  • The pulmonary veins drain into the superior vena cava or the inferior vena cava, or both, causing a total mixing lesion. This mixing lesion leads to the oxygenated blood passing to the right ventricle and pulmonary artery, and to the left atrium through the atrial septal defect or the patent foramen ovale, and then to the left ventricle.
  • The left atrium receives blood only from this shunt and not from the pulmonary veins, as all of them are draining to the right atrium.
  • This shunt causes equal saturation of oxygenated blood in all four chambers of the heart since the blood from the right atrium reaches all other chambers.  TAPVC can present with cyanosis, respiratory distress, tachypnea, tachycardia, and poor feeding in neonates.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by echocardiography, which shows the abnormal venous return of the pulmonary veins.
  • Treatment requires surgical repair to establish normal pulmonary venous return and improve oxygen saturation. The surgery should be performed as soon as possible to prevent irreversible pulmonary hypertension and cardiac failure.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tetralogy of Fallot: Tetralogy of fallot will not have some saturation in all chambers. Remember the x ray finding is “ boot shape heart “

 

Option C. Tricuspid atresia: Tricuspid atresia will have decrease blood flow going from right atrium to right ventricle. So there will be difference in saturation in chambers.

 

Option D. Transposition of great arteries: In this condition the pulmonary artery is attached to the left ventricle & aorta is attached to the right ventricle which leads to parallel circulation. There will be saturation difference.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Circulation (TAPVC), there is equal oxygen saturation in all chambers of the heart due to the complete mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood in the right atrium.

questions.text: Imagine a scenario where a novel medication is introduced that significantly reduces mortality from a specific disease but does not actually cure the disease. As patients continue to live longer with the disease due to this medication, it would have an effect on the epidemiological metrics. Which of the following statements correctly describes the expected change in prevalence and incidence as a result of this medication? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increase in prevalence

 

  • The given scenario shows that there is a drug which can reduce mortality but cannot cure a particular disease.
  • So, old cases will live longer and thus, there will be increase in prevalence. Incidence will not get affected due to this.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decrease in incidence: Incorrect, as the medication does not affect the rate at which new cases occur.

 

Option B. Decrease in prevalence: Incorrect, since patients living longer with the disease will increase prevalence.

 

Option C. Increase in incidence: Incorrect, because incidence measures new cases, not the duration or survival of existing cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PREVALENCE

 

  • Total current (Old + New) cases in a given population over.
  • Prevalence = Incidence × Mean duration of disease [P = I × d]
  • Prevalence describes the balance between incidence, mortality and recovery

 

INCIDENCE

 

  • Number of new cases occurring in a defined population over a specified period of time.

choices.text: Calcium channel blocker

questions.text: For the diagnosis of resistant hypertension, the patient should have uncontrolled hypertension despite taking three antihypertensive drugs. This should include at least one? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Diuretic

 

Resistant hypertension is defined as blood pressure that remains above the target levels despite the use of three antihypertensive agents of different classes, one of which should be a diuretic. This is because diuretics, typically thiazide diuretics, help to reduce blood volume and are effective in lowering blood pressure. Including a diuretic ensures optimal blood pressure control.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Calcium channel blockers: Calcium channel blockers are used but are not specifically required for the diagnosis of resistant hypertension.

 

Option B. Beta blockers: Beta blockers are also commonly used but not specifically required for the definition.

 

Option C. Alpha blockers: Alpha blockers may be used as part of the treatment regimen but are not specifically required.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnostic criteria for resistant hypertension include having blood pressure above target despite taking three drugs, one of which must be a diuretic, OR having controlled blood pressure with four or more drugs. Typically, a thiazide diuretic is used in the setting of hypertension.

questions.text: In a suspected case of cholangitis in a 47-year-old woman, what other component besides abdominal pain does not comprise Reynold's pentad? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hematemesis

 

Hematemesis (vomiting of blood) is not a component of Reynold's pentad. Reynold's pentad includes: jaundice, fever, abdominal pain, altered sensorium, and hypotension. Hematemesis can be a symptom of various other gastrointestinal issues but is not typically associated with cholangitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  1. Cholangitis is an infection of the common bile duct caused by obstruction and increased pressure due to CBD stones.
  2. The classical triad of cholangitis (Charcot) is fever, right upper quadrant pain, and jaundice.
  3. If left untreated, cholangitis can progress to Reynold's pentad with hypotension and altered mental status due to sepsis.
  4. Abdominal ultrasound is used to diagnose biliary stones and bile duct dilatations in cholangitis.
  5. Treatment for cholangitis includes broad-spectrum antibiotics, rehydration, and biliary drainage using endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP).
  6. Biliary stones are the primary cause of cholangitis and can be removed by endoscopic sphincterotomy during ERCP.

questions.text: A doctor tells a 31-year-old woman, who is 20 weeks pregnant, that her baby has a developmental defect. She has come to you for a second opinion. The following US finding is seen. Identify the defect? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anencephaly

 

The given ultrasound image shows an open neural tube defect in the calvaria (skull), which is consistent with the diagnosis of anencephaly.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Anencephaly: Results from incomplete closure of the neural tube. It can be detected as early as 10 to 11 weeks of gestation.
    • Ultrasound Signs:
      • Frog eye sign: Absence of cranial calvaria with prominent orbits, resembling the face of a frog.
      • Shower cap sign: Absence of the cranium leading to the protrusion of a disorganized mass of brain tissue, resembling a shower cap and giving rise to a characteristic triangular facial appearance.
    • Prevention: Can be prevented by pre-conceptional folic acid supplementation (5 mg) for at least 3 months.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Omphalocele: Congenital herniation of abdominal contents through a defect in the abdominal wall covered by a membrane. It is different from gastroschisis.

 

Option C. Cystic hygroma: Lymphangioma occurring in the head-neck region.

 

Option D. Encephalocele: Protrusion of the brain and membranes through a cranial defect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anencephaly is an open neural tube defect characterized by the absence of the cranial calvaria and prominent orbits, detectable by ultrasound as early as 10 to 11 weeks of gestation. It can be prevented with pre-conceptional folic acid supplementation.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg 201, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg471

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a part of AMTSL? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Early cord clamping

 

Active Management of 3rd Stage of Labor

 

Active Management of the Third Stage of Labor (AMTSL) was described by the WHO in 2007 and involves mainly three basic steps:

 

  1. Administering a uterotonic: Oxytocin is the uterotonic of choice for AMTSL (10 IU IM/IV).
  2. Controlled cord traction: This is done only if a skilled birth attendant is present.
  3. Uterine massage: Sustained uterine massage is not recommended for all women who have received uterotonics; instead, postpartum uterine tone assessment for early identification of uterine atony is done.

 

Key Points:

 

  • AMTSL prevents atonic postpartum hemorrhage (PPH).
  • Delayed cord clamping (performed after 1 to 3 minutes after birth) is recommended for all births while initiating simultaneous essential newborn care. This is not to prevent atonic PPH but was introduced along with AMTSL to ensure it is followed.

 

WHO Guidelines:

 

  • In 2012:
    • Emphasized the main three steps.
    • Oxytocin is the uterotonic of choice.
    • Controlled cord traction only with a skilled birth attendant.
    • Delayed cord clamping recommended.
  • In 2018:
    • Additional uterotonics that can be used include:
      • Carbetocin (100 mcg IM/IV)
      • Misoprostol (400 or 600 mcg PO – to be used where a skilled birth attendant isn’t available)
      • Ergometrine/methylergometrine (200 mcg IV except in hypertensive women)
      • Oxytocin and ergometrine fixed-dose combination (5 IU/500 µg, IM)
    • Injectable prostaglandins (carboprost or sulprostone) are not recommended for the prevention of PPH.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uterotonics after delivery of placenta: This is a key component of AMTSL to prevent atonic PPH.

 

Option B. Controlled cord traction: This is part of the AMTSL process to help deliver the placenta.

 

Option C. Uterine massage: This is included in AMTSL, specifically for assessing uterine tone post-delivery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct components of AMTSL include administering a uterotonic, controlled cord traction, and uterine massage. Early cord clamping is not part of AMTSL; instead, delayed cord clamping is recommended.

questions.text: A 14-day-old neonate brought to the outpatient department is found to have bilateral conjunctivitis. Chest X-ray done showed lung infiltrates. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for the infection? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chlamydia trachomatis

 

  • Chlamydia trachomatis is the likely cause of the infection in neonatal conjunctivitis.
  • The infection usually appears 1 week after birth and is transmitted from the mother's cervix or urethra during delivery.
  • Symptoms include edematous conjunctiva, watery discharge that later becomes purulent or bloody.
  • Diagnosis involves taking samples from both the conjunctiva and oropharynx and examining them for intracellular inclusion bodies.
  • Treatment involves administering erythromycin ethylsuccinate 50 mg/kg daily in four divided doses before feeds for 2-3 weeks.
  • If left untreated, associated systemic diseases such as chlamydial otitis and pneumonia may develop later.
  • Both parents must receive appropriate treatment for genital infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hemophilus influenzae: This bacterium can cause conjunctivitis but is less likely to present with systemic involvement like pneumonia in the context of neonatal infection.

 

Option C. Streptococcus: While capable of causing neonatal infections, Streptococcus species are more commonly associated with other forms of neonatal morbidity such as sepsis or meningitis, rather than conjunctivitis with pneumonia.

 

Option D. Mycoplasma: It is known to cause respiratory infections in older children and adults but is an uncommon cause of neonatal conjunctivitis or pneumonia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neonatal conjunctivitis typically presents during the first month of life and the age of the neonate is an important clue to the infection's etiology.

choices.text: Drug A decreases intestinal absorption of Drug B
﻿﻿﻿Drug A reduces first pass metabolism of Drug B
﻿﻿﻿Drug A increases the metabolism of Drug B
Drug A increases renal elimination of Drug B

questions.text: The table below gives the AUC of drug B alone and that of drug B when combined with another drug A. If the p value is <0.01, then which of the following statements is true? (INICET 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Drug A reduces first pass metabolism of Drug B
 

  • The area under the curve or AUC in plasma concentration vs time graph can be used as a measure of the bioavailability of a drug. The bioavailability of a given drug refers to the fraction of the given dose which reaches the systemic circulation. The greater the area under the curve or AUC, the greater is the bioavailability.
  • From the given data, it is seen that the AUC for Drug B is less than the AUC for Drug A + Drug B. And the p value <0.01 indicates that the data is statistically significant. (As the p value is <0.05)
  • So, it can be inferred that the Drug A increases the bioavailability of drug B.

 

As bioavailability depends on two factors:

 

  • Absorption (Bioavailability is directly proportional to the rate of drug absorption)
  • First Pass Metabolism (Bioavailability is inversely proportional to the rate of first pass metabolism of the drug)
  • Therefore, it can be assumed that drug B either increase the absorption or decrease the first pass metabolism of drug A.
  • So among the given options, best answer seem to be option B: Drug A reduces the first pass metabolism of drug B

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Drug A decreases intestinal absorption of Drug B: This statement is incorrect. If Drug A decreased the intestinal absorption of Drug B, the AUC would be lower when the drugs are combined, not higher.

 

Option C. Drug A increases the metabolism of Drug B: This statement is incorrect. If Drug A increased the metabolism of Drug B, the AUC would be lower when the drugs are combined.

 

Option D. Drug A increases renal elimination of Drug B: This statement is incorrect. If Drug A increased the renal elimination of Drug B, it would lead to a decrease in AUC, not an increase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The increase in the AUC of Drug B when combined with Drug A, with a statistically significant p value, indicates that Drug A reduces the first pass metabolism of Drug B, thereby increasing its bioavailability.

questions.text: The possible diagnosis for a child whose mother had a history of bronchial asthma & child developed itchy plaques bilaterally over the popliteal fossa, & cubital fossa (as shown below) could be? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Atopic dermatitis

 

The image displays a child, with scratch marks and excoriations from itchy plaques over the popliteal and cubital fossae, with a maternal history of bronchial asthma indicative of

 

Atopic dermatitis (or eczema).

 

  • This chronic inflammatory skin condition often occurs in families with atopy, encompassing asthma, hay fever, and allergic rhinitis.
  • The patient's personal history reveals a chronic and recurrent course of this condition.

 

In infants, the first site of involvement is often the face.

 

  • Flexural distribution is observed in both the childhood and adult phases of the condition, while in the infantile phase, extensor distribution is more typical.

 

Atopic eczema can be divided into 3 phases:

 

  • Infantile
  • Childhood
  • Adult

 

 

Atopic eczema infantile variant with face affected:

 

 

  • Atopic dermatitis typically presents with erythematous papules or papulovesicular lesions, often appearing in early childhood.
  • As the condition progresses, the lesions may evolve into excoriated and lichenified areas.
  • Atopic dermatitis is commonly associated with secondary infections and skin dryness.
  • In the diagnosis of atopic dermatitis, the UK refinement of the Hanifin & Rajka criteria is employed.

 

UK refinement of Hanifin & Rajka’s diagnostic criteria of atopic dermatitis (Eczema).

 

  • An itchy skin condition (or parental report of scratching or rubbing in a child)
  • Plus, three or more of the following 
    • Onset below age 2 years (not used if child is under 4 years)
    • History of skin crease involvement (including cheeks in children under 10 years)
    • History of a generally dry skin
  • Personal history of other atopic disease (or history of any topic disease in a first degree relative in children under 4 years)
  • Visible flexural dermatitis (or dermatitis of cheeks/ forehead and outer limbs in children under 4 years)

 

Clinical features include:

 

  • Dennie-morgan fold under lower eyelid
  • Allergic shiners – periorbital pigmentation
  • Allergic salute – horizontal groove on dorsum of nasal bridge

 

 

Fig: Dennie-morgan fold

 

Complications:

 

Staphylococcus aureus is the most common organism to cause secondary infections in the lesions of atopic dermatitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dermatitis herpetiformis:

 

  • It is frequently observed in individuals in their 40s.
  • This is an intensely pruritic condition predominantly affecting extensor surfaces of the body, rather than the flexures and associated with gluten sensitivity and is characterized by grouped vesicles on an erythematous base. It is not related to a history of atopy.

 

Option C. Pemphigus vegetans:

 

  • A variant of pemphigus vulgaris, pemphigus vegetans presents with vegetating plaques, usually in the intertriginous areas.
  • It is not associated with a familial history of atopy and does not predominantly affect the popliteal and cubital fossae.

 

Option D. Psoriasis:

 

  • Psoriasis is a chronic autoimmune skin condition characterized by well-demarcated, scaly plaques.
  • While psoriasis can affect any area of the body but more commonly extensor involvement is seen, it does not typically present as pruritic plaques in the popliteal

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a child with a familial history of atopy presenting with itchy plaques over the popliteal and cubital fossae, Atopic Dermatitis is the most likely diagnosis.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition volume 2 Chapter 41 page no 41.1, 41.2, 41.13-19, volume 3 Chapter 149 page no 149.21

Image source:

https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Category:Atopic_dermatitis

questions.text: Which of the following is not an amphipathic Lipid? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Triglycerides

 

  • Triglycerides are not amphipathic lipids. They consist of three fatty acid chains esterified to a glycerol molecule. These molecules are hydrophobic and do not have a polar or hydrophilic region. Triglycerides are the primary storage form of energy in the body and are commonly found in adipose tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Phosphoglycerol: Phosphoglycerol, also known as phosphoglyceride or glycerophospholipid, is an amphipathic lipid. It has a polar phosphate head group and two hydrophobic fatty acid tails. Phosphoglycerides are essential components of cell membranes, where they form the lipid bilayer.

 

Option C. Glycolipids: Glycolipids are amphipathic lipids. They have a hydrophilic carbohydrate (sugar) head group and hydrophobic lipid tails. Glycolipids are important in cell membranes, particularly in nerve cells and the myelin sheath. They play a role in cell signaling and recognition.

 

Option D. Sphingolipids: Sphingolipids are amphipathic lipids. They consist of a sphingosine backbone, a hydrophilic head group (usually containing a sugar), and one or two hydrophobic fatty acid tails. Sphingolipids are crucial components of cell membranes and are involved in various cellular processes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Triglycerides are not amphipathic lipids, while phosphoglycerol, glycolipids, and sphingolipids are amphipathic and play important roles in cell membrane structure and function.

 

They are formed by esterification between three Fatty acids and one glycerol molecule. As Ester bond is non-polar so, molecule of TG is a non-polar. They are also called as neutral fats.

choices.text: Impact of a semi sharp-edged object
Overstretching of skin and subcutaneous tissue
Tissue crushed between weapon and underlying bone

questions.text: A 30-year-old alcoholic comes to the casualty after being hurt in a fight with a stranger. A lacerated wound is seen over his skull. Which of the following is the correct mechanism of this lacerated wound? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Tissue crushed between weapon and underlying bone

 

The laceration shown above is an incised looking lacerated wound.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Shearing force: Shearing force typically causes a different type of laceration, not the incised-like laceration seen in the image.

 

Option B. Impact of a semi sharp-edged object: This might cause a different wound pattern, more akin to a cut or a clean incision rather than a laceration.

 

Option C. Overstretching of skin and subcutaneous tissue: This causes stretch lacerations, which do not match the appearance of the wound shown.

 

Educational objective

 

Classification of a Laceration:

 

  • Split laceration (incised-like laceration): When the skin is crushed between two hard objects.

  • Incised-looking lacerated wound It is seen where the skin overlies an area of the bone where there is scanty underlying subcutaneous tissue such as the scalp, forehead, shin.

  • Avulsed laceration: A lesion where the skin separates or peels off by tearing from the underlying tissues.

  • Tears: Tearing of skin and subcutaneous tissue from localized impact

  • Stretch laceration: It occurs due to the over-stretching of the skin, beyond its elasticity.

  • Cut laceration: Injury by a heavy sharp-edged instrument like axe.

questions.text: A person working in an industry for a long time developed progressive breathlessness. The histopathological image of his lung biopsy is given below. What industry was he most likely working in? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Asbestos

 

From the clinical history of progressive breathlessness and the histopathological image showing asbestos bodies, ferruginous bodies, and fibrosis, the patient is most likely working in the asbestos industry.

 

Asbestosis is a type of pneumoconiosis associated with asbestos exposure. The disease-causing capabilities of the different forms of asbestos depend on concentration, size, shape, and solubility. This condition is marked by diffuse pulmonary interstitial fibrosis.

 

Grossly, the affected lungs are small and firm with cartilage-like thickening of the pleura.

 

 

The sectioned surface shows variable degree of pulmonary fibrosis, especially in the subpleural areas and in the bases of lungs. The advanced cases may show cystic changes.

 

 

Gross appearance of the lung in asbestosis diagram

 

Histologically, the following changes are observed:

 

  • There is non-specific interstitial fibrosis.
  • There is presence of characteristic asbestos bodies in the involved areas. These are asbestos fibres coated with glycoprotein and haemosiderin and appear beaded or dumbbell-shaped. The coating stains positively for Prussian blue reaction. Similar iron-protein complexes coat other inorganic particulates other than asbestos which are termed as ferruginous bodies.

 

Microscopic appearance of asbestos body. An asbestos body is an asbestos fibre coated with glycoprotein and haemosiderin giving it beaded or dumbbell-shaped appearance with bulbous ends.

 

Note: Asbestos exposure is associated with malignant mesothelioma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Silica: Silica exposure leads to silicosis, which is characterized by nodular fibrosis, not asbestos bodies.

 

Option C. Coal dust: Coal dust exposure leads to coal workers' pneumoconiosis (CWP) or "black lung disease," characterized by coal macules and nodules in the lungs.

 

Option D. Cotton: Cotton dust exposure leads to byssinosis, which is primarily associated with respiratory symptoms but does not cause the fibrosis and asbestos bodies seen in asbestosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Asbestosis is associated with the presence of asbestos bodies and interstitial fibrosis, typically seen in individuals working in industries involving asbestos exposure.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition 1306-1307

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of angle-closure glaucoma has been diagnosed with major depressive disorder. Which of the following drugs have to be avoided in this patient? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Amitriptyline

 

  • Amitriptyline is a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) that is known to have marked anticholinergic activity.
  • TCAs have high affinity for muscarinic acetylcholine (M type) receptors, causing the subsequent blockade of these receptors.
  • Blocking of these receptors can result in decreased outflow of aqueous humour, leading to an increase in intraocular pressure.
  • This effect can exacerbate pre-existing angle-closure type glaucoma, which is already characterized by impaired drainage of aqueous humour.
  • Therefore, amitriptyline is a drug to be avoided in patients with angle-closure glaucoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Options B and D: Sertraline and Fluvoxamine are selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors with no activity at the muscarinic cholinergic receptors and therefore have no effect on the outflow of aqueous humor and thereby, on the intraocular pressure.

 

Option C: Mirtazapine is an atypical antidepressant that is a serotonin-norephedrine reuptake inhibitor with the ability to precipitate angle-closure glaucoma by itself; however, due to lack of any activity at the muscarinic cholinergic receptors, it does not increase the intraocular pressure to the extent that Amitriptyline does.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with angle-closure glaucoma, medications with anticholinergic properties, such as Amitriptyline, should be avoided due to their potential to increase intraocular pressure and exacerbate the condition.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy complains of cough and throat pain. On examination of the oral cavity, a white pseudomembrane was visualized. A swab was taken from it and stained as given in the image below. What is the procedure for the following staining? (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Albert's stain- I
  2. Acid alcohol
  3. Gram's iodine
  4. Safranin
  5. Methylene blue
  6. Crystal violet
  7. Carbol fuschin
  8. Acetone
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 6, 3, 8, 4

 

The image shows Gram's stain of Corynebacterium diphtheria.

 

Corynebacterium diphtheriae are gram +ve rod shaped bacteria, Club shaped, non-capsulated, non sporing, non-motile,. Also known as Kleb’s-Loeffler Bacillus.

 

The Gram staining process includes four basic steps, including:

 

  1. Applying a primary stain (crystal violet). Option 6
  2. Adding a mordant (Gram’s iodine). Option 3
  3. Rapid decolorization with ethanol, acetone or a mixture of both. Option 8
  4. Counterstaining with safranin. Option 4

 

On microscopy –

 

  • Chinese letter arrangement, V or L shaped
  • Forms granules (metachromatic granules) which are the store house of energy.
  • Alberts’s stain, Loeffler’s methylene blue stain and Ponder’s stain shows metachromatic granules formed in the polar regions. Appears green in Alberts’s stain along with bluish black metachromatic granules at the poles.
    • Albert's I solution - Toluidine blue, Malachite green.
    • Albert's II solution - iodine and potassium iodide.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct Gram staining procedure for identifying Corynebacterium diphtheriae includes the steps of applying crystal violet, adding Gram's iodine, decolorizing with acetone, and counterstaining with safranin.

choices.text: EDV and pressure curve shifts to left without change in slope
Slope changes in ESV pressure curve
End systolic volume and pressure curve shifts to left without change in slope
Slope changes in EDV and pressure curve

questions.text:
If the contractility of the heart is decreased, which of the following is seen? (INICET Nov 2021)

 

ESV: End-systolic volume

EDV: End-diastolic volume
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Slope changes in ESV pressure curve

 

A decrease in contractility of the heart can result in changes in the slope of the end-systolic pressure-volume relationship (ESV pressure curve) in addition to changes in end-systolic volume (ESV) and end-diastolic volume (EDV).

 

When contractility is decreased, the ventricle is less able to generate the same pressure for a given volume of blood, resulting in a reduced slope of the ESV pressure curve. This indicates that the heart is less efficient in ejecting blood during systole.

 

Therefore, the correct answer is B. Slope changes in ESV pressure curve. This is because the slope of the ESV pressure curve is an index of contractility, and a decrease in contractility results in a reduced slope of the curve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. is incorrect because a leftward shift of the end-diastolic pressure-volume curve without a change in slope is seen in conditions such as hypertension and aortic stenosis, where the heart has to generate greater pressure to overcome an increased afterload.

 

Option C. is incorrect because a leftward shift of the end-systolic pressure-volume curve without a change in slope is not typically seen in response to changes in contractility.

 

Option D. is incorrect because a change in the slope of the EDV pressure curve is not typically observed in response to changes in contractility.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A decrease in cardiac contractility leads to a decrease in the slope of the end-systolic pressure-volume (ESV) curve, indicating reduced efficiency in blood ejection during systole.

questions.text:
