Arrange the following external fixators used for treatment of fracture of tibia in order of increasing stability: (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Ilizarov

  2. Uniplanar frame with one rod

  3. Biplanar frame

  4. Uniplanar frame with two rods
questions.solution:
Ans. A. II, IV, III, I

 

EXTERNAL FIXATION

 

  • In External fixation, the fixation device is external to skin.

  • Uniplanar frame with one rod provides the least stability as it can only resist forces in one plane.

  • In uniplanar frame with two rods, adding a second rod increases stability compared to a single rod.

  • Biplanar frame provides stability in two planes, making it more secure than uniplanar frames. It improves the resistance to rotational and bending forces.

  • The Ilizarov external fixator is known for its exceptional stability due to its ring structure and multiple pins. It provides high axial and torsional stability.

  • It is often used for complex fractures and lengthening procedures.

  • Ilizarov fixator works on the principles of distraction osteogenesis i.e., an osteotomy is carried out and distracted at the rate of 1 mm per day causing distraction at the callus and subsequently lengthening can be done.

  • It can be used for correction of deformities like malunion, shortening, shortening with discharging sinus, gap non-union and also for CTEV.

  • Therefore, the Ilizarov fixator offers the highest level of stability among the options listed.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For the fixation of tibia fracture, the order of external fixators used in order of increased stability is:

 

Uniplanar frame with one rod (II) < uniplanar frame with two rods (IV) < biplanar frame (III) < ilizarov (I)

choices.text: Blast of air

questions.text: A man who was involved in a bomb blast at a railway station was brought to the hospital with multiple small puncture wounds to the left side of the chest and multiple small abrasions all over the body. Which of the following mechanisms is responsible for these injuries? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Flying missiles

 

The case scenarios define multiple abrasions and puncture wounds suggestive of blast injuries due to flying missiles.

 

T.K. Marshall's (Marshall's triad of bomb injuries) :

 

    • Abrasions
    • Bruises/contusions
    • Puncture lacerations

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Blast of air: Primarily causes primary blast injuries, which affect air-filled organs and do not typically result in puncture wounds.

 

Option C. Explosion burns: Involve thermal injuries and burns rather than puncture wounds and abrasions.

 

Option D. Furniture abrasions: Would result from the victim being thrown into furniture or debris, causing blunt force injuries rather than puncture wounds.

 

Educational Objective

 

Classification of Blast injuries:

 

Injuries from explosions are traditionally classified into:

 

  1. Primary blast injuries: injuries due to solely to the blast wave
  2. Secondary blast or explosive injury: primarily ballistic trauma resulting from fragmentation wounds from the explosive device or the environment
  3. Tertiary blast or explosive injury: result of displacement of the victim or environmental structures, is largely blunt traumatic injuries
  4. Quaternary explosive injuries: burns, toxins, and radiologic contamination

questions.text: Match the following? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A-2, B-4, C-1, D-3

 

Explanation:

 

Twilight (A) refers to a transient, impaired state of consciousness often seen during seizures or certain other medical conditions. Therefore, it matches with Impaired level of consciousness (2).

 

Oneroid state (B) is a term used in psychiatry to describe a dream-like state of consciousness, hence matching with Oneirophrenia (4), which is derived from the words meaning 'dream' and 'mind'.

 

Oligophrenia (C) is an outdated medical term used to describe intellectual disability or subnormal intelligence. Thus, it matches with Subnormal intelligence (1).

 

Paranoid Ideation (D) involves thoughts dominated by ideas of persecution or conspiracy against the individual. This matches with Persecution (3).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Oneroid state is characterized by a dream-like state resembling Oneirophrenia. Oligophrenia refers to intellectual disability, and Paranoid Ideation is centered on ideas of persecution.

 

Reference: Sim’s symptoms in the Mind, 7th edition, Page No 39, 40, 132; Kaplan & Sadock’s Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 10th edition, Page No 4599.

questions.text: According to IADPSG, what is the cut-off value of fasting blood glucose for the diagnosis of gestational diabetes mellitus? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) > 92 mg/dL

 

Explanation:

 

The International Association of Diabetes and Pregnancy Study Groups (IADPSG) has established criteria for the diagnosis of gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM). According to their guidelines:

 

  • The fasting blood glucose cut-off value for diagnosing GDM during a 75g oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) is >92 mg/dL.

 

This value is used as part of a comprehensive assessment, including 1-hour and 2-hour postprandial glucose levels. The IADPSG criteria for GDM diagnosis include:

 

  • Fasting: ≥92 mg/dL
  • 1-hour: ≥180 mg/dL
  • 2-hour: ≥153 mg/dL

 

If any one of these values is abnormal, the diagnosis of GDM can be made.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. >95 mg/dL: This is not the IADPSG recommended cut-off for fasting blood glucose. It is higher than the specified cut-off value for diagnosing GDM.

 

Option C. >106 mg/dL: This value is significantly higher than the recommended cut-off. It exceeds the threshold for diagnosing GDM according to IADPSG guidelines.

 

Option D. >90 mg/dL: While this value is close, it is slightly below the IADPSG recommended cut-off of >92 mg/dL for diagnosing GDM.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cut-off value of fasting blood glucose for the diagnosis of gestational diabetes mellitus according to IADPSG is >92 mg/dL.

 

Ref: Page no 326, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

choices.text: Mono-unsaturated fatty acids
Poly-unsaturated fatty acids

questions.text: Which require maximum energy for assimilation? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Proteins

 

Option A. Proteins:

  • Proteins are complex macromolecules consisting of amino acids.
  • They require a significant amount of energy for assimilation because the body needs to break them down into individual amino acids, which are then used for various metabolic processes, including energy production.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Carbohydrates:

  • Carbohydrates are a primary source of energy for the body.
  • They are relatively easy to assimilate as they are broken down into glucose, which can be readily used for energy.

 

Option C. Mono-unsaturated fatty acids:

  • Mono-unsaturated fatty acids are a type of dietary fat found in foods like olive oil and avocados.
  • They require less energy for assimilation compared to proteins because they can be broken down relatively easily and used for energy or stored as fat.

 

Option D. Poly-unsaturated fatty acids:

  • Poly-unsaturated fatty acids, such as omega-3 and omega-6 fatty acids, are essential fats found in certain foods.
  • Similar to mono-unsaturated fatty acids, they require less energy for assimilation compared to proteins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Proteins require the maximum energy for assimilation among the options listed, as they need to be broken down into individual amino acids for various metabolic processes, including energy production.

questions.text: Which of the following complication is specific to Monochorionic twins?  (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Twin to twin transfusion syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Complications specific to monochorionic twins are:

 

  • Twin to twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS): This is a specific complication seen in monochorionic twins. There is a donor twin and a recipient twin; the donor is anemic and pale with oligohydramnios, while the recipient is polycythemic and may have circulatory overload, ascites, and hydrops. Quintero's staging is used for TTTS, and the treatment involves laser ablation of vessels.
  • TRAP sequence (Twin Reversed Arterial Perfusion): This is another specific complication seen in monochorionic twins, involving an acardiac twin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Selective fetal growth restriction: While this can occur in monochorionic twins, it is not specific to them.

 

Option B. Polyhydramnios: This can be seen in various conditions and is not specific to monochorionic twins.

 

Option D. Neural tube defects: These can occur in any pregnancy and are not specific to monochorionic twins.

 

Thus, options A, B, and D are not specific complications of monochorionic twins.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg904,905

questions.text: A 57-year-old man was brought to the hospital with complaints of dizziness and breathlessness. During his physical examination, you notice the following discoloration over his face. He is presently being treated with amiodarone, metoprolol, verapamil, lisinopril, and amlodipine. Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Amiodarone

 

Amiodarone is known to cause skin discoloration, which can appear as a bluish or greyish hue, especially on areas exposed to the sun. This effect is due to the drug's deposition in the skin and can occur after prolonged use. Amiodarone-induced skin discoloration (also known as ceruloderma or blue man syndrome) is the most likely cause of the bluish discoloration in this patient's case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Amlodipine: A calcium channel blocker used to treat hypertension and angina. Skin discoloration is not a common side effect of amlodipine.

 

Option C. Metoprolol: A beta-blocker used for various heart conditions, including hypertension and arrhythmias. Metoprolol is not typically associated with skin discoloration.

 

Option D. Verapamil: Another calcium channel blocker used for hypertension, angina, and certain arrhythmias. Like amlodipine, it is not commonly associated with causing skin discoloration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amiodarone can cause a characteristic bluish or greyish discoloration of the skin, particularly in sun-exposed areas, due to its deposition in the skin after prolonged use. This side effect is not commonly associated with the other medications listed (amlodipine, metoprolol, and verapamil).

questions.text:
A 60-year-old male patient with critical mitral stenosis presented with atrial fibrillation. He has a history of multiple episodes of transient ischemic attacks. Which of the following are true regarding the prevention of stroke in this patient? (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Only aspirin is given
  2. Warfarin is given
  3. Direct oral anticoagulants are not indicated
  4. Mitral valvotomy should be recommended
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 and 3

 

For a patient with critical mitral stenosis and atrial fibrillation, particularly one with a history of transient ischemic attacks (TIA), anticoagulation therapy is essential.

 

2. Warfarin is the preferred anticoagulant in cases of severe mitral stenosis due to its proven effectiveness in preventing thromboembolic events.

 

3. Direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs) are not recommended in this scenario as they are not indicated for patients with moderate to severe mitral stenosis.

 

Other Options:

 

1. Aspirin alone is insufficient to prevent stroke in this context.

 

4. Mitral valvotomy is not recommended at this point because performing the procedure could dislodge existing clots, leading to embolic events.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with critical mitral stenosis and atrial fibrillation, especially those with a history of TIA, Warfarin should be given for stroke prevention, and direct oral anticoagulants are not indicated.

questions.text: The extracellular concentration of chloride is 100mmol/L and the intracellular concentration is 10 mol/L. What is the equilibrium potential of chloride? (INICET NOVEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) - 60 mV

 

Nernst equation: EMF (millivolts) = [61/z] X log [Co / C]

 

  • EMF = electromotive force (Nernst potential)
  • z = charge of ion
  • Co = concentration outside
  • C = concentration inside

 

When using this formula, it is usually assumed that the potential in the extracellular fluid outside the membrane remains at zero potential, and the Nernst potential is the potential inside the membrane.

 

The sign of the potential is negative (-) if a negative ion is diffusing from outside to inside.

Therefore, Nernst potential = 61/-1 * log [100/10] =-61 * log [10] = - 61 mV

 

To get the charge, always check the final charge intracellularly.

 

The potential is negative intracellularly, so the Nernst equation comes out to be -61m inside the membrane and the closest option is -60 mV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The equilibrium potential for an ion can be calculated using the Nernst equation:

questions.text: Third part of vertebral artery is related to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 2

 

The third part of the vertebral artery (V3) is related to the area marked 2, which is the posterior arch of the first cervical vertebra or the atlas.

 

The given image shows the first cervical vertebra - atlas.

 

  • The area marked 1 is the posterior tubercle.
  • The area marked 2 is the posterior arch. The superior surface bears a groove for the of vertebral artery and venous plexus immediately behind.
  • The area marked 3 is the superior articular facet.
  • The area marked 4 is the posterior surface of the anterior arch. It gives attachment to the apex of dens from the second cervical vertebra.

 

The vertebral artery is formed by the first segment of the subclavian artery. It enters the cranium through the foramina of the transverse processes of the cervical vertebrae from C6 to C1. The basilar artery is formed by the union of the vertebral arteries on both sides. In its course. it is divided into four parts:

 

  1. The first part, V1: begins at its origin from the subclavian artery and ends at its entry into the transverse process of the C6 cervical vertebra. This part is crossed by the inferior thyroid artery on both sides, and thoracic duct on the left side, and the right lymphatic duct on the right side.
  2. The second part, V2: is that part of the artery ascending through the foramina in the transverse process of the cervical vertebrae.
  3. The third part, V3: is curved backward behind the atlas. In this position, it lies in a groove on the posterior arch of the atlas. This part of the artery lies in the suboccipital triangle.
  4. The fourth part, V4: pierces the dura and arachnoid mater and unites with the contralateral vertebral artery to form the midline basilar artery at the lower border of pons.

questions.text:
You are a primary care physician seeing a patient for a routine check-up. The patient expresses concern about colon cancer and asks about potential risk factors and preventive measures. You provide the following information: (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Right and left colon cancers can exhibit distinct behaviour.
  2. Colon cancer can have hereditary components.
  3. Colon cancer risk can be mitigated by metformin.
  4. Liver metastases are a common occurrence in colon cancer.

 

Which of the following options is/are true regarding colon cancer:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, and 4

 

All the 4 statements given are true about colon cancer.

 

  • Right and left colon cancers exhibit different characteristics, with left-sided tumors being more likely to cause obstruction due to the caliber of the bowel and consistency of stool.
  • Proximal colon cancers, or right colon cancers, are typically diagnosed later and may present with iron deficiency anemia or a mass.
  • While the majority of colorectal cancers occur sporadically, some can be hereditary and are more common in patients with a family history of the disease, like FAP and HNPCC. Genetic testing can aid in early diagnosis.
  • Metformin, a biguanide compound used to treat diabetes, has been shown to reduce the risk of colorectal cancer by disrupting cellular energy supply and inhibiting aerobic glycolysis.
  • Liver metastasis is the most frequent site of distant metastasis in colorectal cancer and occurs through hematogenous spread via the portal venous system. Tumor size and grade are risk factors. The second most common site of distant metastasis is the lung, while carcinomatosis can occur through peritoneal seeding.

choices.text: Normal, negatively skewed, positively skewed, skewed with outliers
Normal, positively skewed, negatively skewed, normal with outliers
Normal, negatively skewed, positively skewed, normal with outliers
Skewed with outliers, positively skewed, negatively skewed, normal

questions.text: What information is conveyed by the graph presented below? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Normal, positively skewed, negatively skewed, normal with outliers 

 

The given Box and Whisker plot depicts different types of data distributions:

 

  1. Normal distribution - The median is in the middle of the box, with whiskers of equal length.
  2. Positively skewed distribution - The median is closer to the bottom of the box, with a longer whisker on the upper end.
  3. Negatively skewed distribution - The median is closer to the top of the box, with a longer whisker on the lower end.
  4. Normal distribution with outliers - The median is in the middle of the box, with equal whisker lengths and the presence of outliers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Box and Whisker plot

 

  • A graphical presentation of Numerical Data through its quartiles.
  • It has a box in the center and two wishers in its sides.
  • The box has got 2 ends, Quartile 1 (Q1) & Quartile 3 (Q3)
  • The vertical line inside the box is called median also known as Q2. The whole data is divided into 4 Quartiles
  • The lower end of one whisker represent the minimum value of the distribution.
  • The higher end of other Whisker represents the maximum value of the distribution.

choices.text: Measure CA 125 levels
Follow up after 6 weeks

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman who has had 2 children through normal delivery presents with a dull aching pain over the abdomen, with irregular menses. Per vaginal examination revealed a mass felt through the posterior fornix. A USG showed a clear ovarian cyst of size 5 x 5 cm. What is the next best step? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Follow up after 6 weeks

 

A clear ovarian cyst with minimal symptoms and size less than 8 cm in a woman of reproductive age group is most likely a functional ovarian cyst. The next best step in the management of this case is to follow up after 6-12 weeks and perform a repeat USG.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Functional Ovarian Cyst: In reproductive-aged women, a clear ovarian cyst less than 8 cm is likely functional.
  • Follow-Up: The recommended management is to follow up after 6-12 weeks with a repeat ultrasound to check if the cyst resolves on its own.
  • Indications for Further Intervention: Surgical treatment is warranted if there are worrying features, the cyst is greater than 8 cm, there are significant symptoms, or CA-125 levels are raised.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Measure CA 125 levels: CA 125 is a marker for epithelial ovarian tumors and is more relevant in postmenopausal women. It has limited role in premenopausal women with clear, simple cysts.

 

Option C. Laparoscopy: Surgical intervention such as laparoscopy is not immediately necessary for a 5 cm cyst unless there are concerning features or persistence after follow-up.

 

Option D. CT pelvis: CT scan is not typically indicated for initial assessment of a simple ovarian cyst detected on ultrasound.

 

Additional information:

 

  • OC Pills: Oral contraceptive pills have not been proven effective in treating simple ovarian cysts, though they are often used.
  • Simple Ovarian Cysts: Any simple ovarian cyst less than 5 cm without symptoms can be left alone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a reproductive-aged woman with a clear ovarian cyst less than 8 cm and minimal symptoms, the best approach is to follow up with a repeat ultrasound after 6-12 weeks, rather than immediate intervention.

 

Ref: RCOG greentop guideline number 62 , Williams textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg217

choices.text: The inhibitor can bind with any site resulting in suicidal inhibition
The binding of the enzyme to the substrate analogue is irreversible
They are enzyme specific and used in rational drug design
The inhibitor forms a product with the enzyme and the product inhibits it

questions.text: Identify the false statement regarding suicidal inhibition? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. The inhibitor can bind with any site resulting in suicidal inhibition

 

SUICIDE INHIBTION

 

Suicide inhibition, also known as mechanism-based inhibition, is a unique and fascinating aspect of enzyme kinetics. It's a process where an enzyme binds to a substrate analogue, which initially seems like a normal substrate to the enzyme. However, as the enzyme starts to act on this 'pseudo-substrate,' a chemical reaction occurs that modifies the enzyme in such a way that it becomes irreversibly inactivated. This process is termed 'suicide' because the enzyme actively participates in its own inhibition.

 

STEPS INVOLVED IN SUICIDE INHIBITION

 

  1. Binding: The suicide substrate, which is often structurally similar to the actual substrate, binds to the enzyme's active site.
  2. Initial Reaction: The enzyme catalyses a reaction on this substrate analogue, similar to how it would act on its natural substrate.
  3. Formation of Reactive Intermediate: This reaction, however, leads to the formation of a chemically reactive intermediate. This intermediate is the key to the suicide inhibition mechanism.
  4. Modification of Enzyme: The reactive intermediate then reacts with the enzyme itself, leading to a covalent modification of the enzyme. This modification typically occurs at the active site, crucial for the enzyme's activity.
  5. Irreversible Inhibition: As a result of this modification, the enzyme is irreversibly inactivated. It can no longer bind to its natural substrate or catalyse the reaction it was designed for.
  6. Specificity: One of the key features of suicide inhibition is its specificity. Because the inhibitor is structurally similar to the natural substrate, the process is highly specific to the targeted enzyme. This makes suicide inhibitors very effective as drugs, as they can selectively target and inactivate specific enzymes in the body.

 

Other Options:

Option B. The binding of the enzyme to the substrate analogue is irreversible: This is true. The substrate analogue binds irreversibly to the enzyme, leading to its permanent inactivation.

 

Option C. They are enzyme specific and used in rational drug design: This is true. Suicide inhibitors are designed to be highly specific for the target enzyme, making them valuable in rational drug design.

 

Option D. The inhibitor forms a product with the enzyme and the product inhibits it: This is true. The enzyme catalyzes the conversion of the substrate analogue to a reactive intermediate, which then irreversibly modifies the enzyme, leading to its inhibition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CLINICAL IMPORTANCE

 

Suicide inhibitors have significant implications in drug development, especially for designing drugs that target enzymes involved in disease processes. For instance, certain antibiotics work by suicide inhibition of bacterial enzymes, and some drugs used in the treatment of hypertension and depression also act through this mechanism.

 

Understanding the mechanism of suicide inhibition helps in the development of more effective and specific drugs, with fewer off-target effects. It's a powerful example of how knowledge of biochemistry can be applied in medicinal chemistry and pharmacology.

 

EXAMPLES OF SUICIDE INHIBITORS

 

  • Beta lactams (Penicillins)
  • Aspirin
  • Allopurinol
  • MAO inhibitors

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient with chronic fatigue and lymphadenopathy presents to the outpatient department. His peripheral smear shows the presence of smudge cells. Which of the following additional investigations will you do to arrive at a diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Flow cytometry

 

An elderly patient with chronic fatigue and lymphadenopathy, and a peripheral smear showing the presence of smudge cells suggest a diagnosis of chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

 

Immunophenotyping using flow cytometry is the investigation done to arrive at the diagnosis. The classical immunophenotypic feature of CLL is CD 19+, CD20+, CD 23+, CD5+ and surface immunoglobulins of various classes, monoclonal light chains (λ or κ type).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR): While PCR can be useful in certain hematologic malignancies for detecting specific genetic mutations, it is not the first-line diagnostic tool for CLL.

 

Option B. Fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH): FISH can be used to detect specific chromosomal abnormalities associated with CLL but is not the primary diagnostic tool.

 

Option D. Cytogenetics: Cytogenetic analysis can provide additional prognostic information by identifying chromosomal abnormalities but is typically done after confirming the diagnosis with flow cytometry.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient suspected of having Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL), Flow cytometry is the key diagnostic test to confirm the diagnosis by identifying the characteristic immunophenotype of CLL cells.

 

Ref: Robins Pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1114

questions.text: A child presented with bilateral proptosis. From the peripheral smear, he was suspected to have chloroma. What is the next investigation of choice? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bone marrow examination

 

The next investigation of choice, in a child suspected to have a chloroma, is a bone marrow biopsy.

 

Chloroma or granulocytic sarcoma is an extramedullary manifestation that occurs in 2% to 14% of patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML). It is a localised tumour forming mass occurring in the skin or orbit due to local infiltration of the tissues by leukemic cells. The tumour is greenish in appearance due to the presence of myeloperoxidase.

 

Frequent sites of involvement are the skin, lymph nodes, gastrointestinal tract, bone, soft tissue, testis, and peritoneum. Isolated orbital involvement of myeloid sarcoma is rare. Proptosis is the most common presentation. Other symptoms include lacrimal swelling, conjunctival mass lesion, retinal hemorrhages, ptosis, dystopia. Decreased visual acuity and ocular movement restriction have also been reported.

 

The diagnosis of AML is made by a combination of routine blood picture and bone marrow examination, coupled with cytochemical stains and other special laboratory investigations.

 

The diagnosis of AML is based on the presence of at least 20% myeloid blasts in the bone marrow.

 

Although myeloid sarcomas are radiosensitive, they are managed with systemic chemotherapy in most cases, even in the absence of bone marrow involvement. Surgery and/or radiation therapy may be indicated for symptomatic lesions or tumors causing local organ dysfunction or obstruction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Platelet count: While important in assessing overall hematologic status, platelet count alone is not sufficient to diagnose chloroma or AML.

 

Option B. WBC count: Similarly, WBC count is part of the complete blood count but does not provide the definitive diagnosis needed in this case.

 

Option C. Flow cytometry: This test can help classify leukemia subtypes by analyzing cell surface markers but is typically performed after a bone marrow examination to confirm the diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For suspected chloroma in the context of AML, a bone marrow examination is the critical next step to confirm the diagnosis and guide treatment.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1150-1154

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presented with scrotal swelling and ataxia. Which among the following could likely be a cause? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Non-Hodgkin lymphoma

 

This was an atypical question, which is important only if it is repeated in a subsequent exam.

 

The most likely cause in the following case is Non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) - Diffuse Large B cell lymphoma (DLBCL) type.

 

Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) is the most common form of NHL.

 

The median patient age is about 60 years, but DLBCL also occurs in young adults and children.

 

DLBCL commonly presents with enlarged lymph nodes or rapidly growing mass along with B symptoms, which include fever, night sweats, and weight loss. The B symptoms can be seen in 30% of the patients. Bone marrow involvement is more common in indolent disease and can be seen in up to 50% of the cases.

 

About 50% of the patients have extranodal involvement like stomach or gastrointestinal tract (most common primary extranodal site), skin, bones, spinal cord, testicles, among other locations. Renal involvement can be secondary to bulky disease or lymphadenopathy, causing a ureteral obstruction or due to tumor lysis syndrome. DLBCL can also present with symptoms suggestive of superior vena cava syndrome, compression of the airways. The symptoms can be related to the infiltrated organ if the disease spreads beyond the lymphatics in so-called extranodal disease. A variety of paraneoplastic syndromes may also be associated with B cell lymphomas.

 

Metastasis involves the central nervous system (CNS), skin, contralateral testis, and pleura resulting in local complications.

 

Even though ataxia is seen as a paraneoplastic symptom due to cerebellar degeneration in Hodgkin lymphoma, testicular involvement is very rare and so far, only 5 cases have been reported. Hodgkin lymphoma arises in a single node or chain of nodes and spreads first to anatomically contiguous lymphoid tissues. The extranodal presentation is rare. The extranodal disease can occur at any site like lung, liver, bone, and bone marrow is most common if it occurs. The central nervous system and the testis are exceptionally rare sites for Hodgkin's lymphoma. Thus Hodgkin's lymphoma can be ruled out.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glioblastoma multiforme: Most common sites are the frontal and temporal lobes. Extracranial metastases of malignant gliomas are extremely rare due to absence of a lymphatic system in the brain and spinal cord for systemic dissemination, dense dura around intracranial veins and lack of nurturing stroma in other organs.

 

 

Option B. Hodgkin’s Lymphoma: Doesn’t involve the extra nodal sites

 

Option D. Non-seminomatous germ cell tumor: These tumors primarily metastasize to the lungs, liver, CNS, and bone, in order of frequency. Although CNS involvement can occur, it is relatively rare. The combination of scrotal swelling and ataxia is less typical for non-seminomatous germ cell tumors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL), particularly Diffuse Large B-Cell Lymphoma (DLBCL), is a likely cause of scrotal swelling and ataxia due to its potential for extranodal involvement and associated paraneoplastic syndromes.

questions.text:
True regarding mitochondrial DNA? (INICET Nov 2021)

 

  1. Higher chances of mutations as compared to the nuclear genome
  2. Single stranded Circular DNA
  3. mt codons are slightly different from nuclear DNA codons
  4. mtDNA encodes for all the ETC complex proteins
  5. Has around 16,000 base pairs
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A, C, E

 

MITOCHONDRIAL DNA         

 

Statement A. Higher chances of mutations as compared to the nuclear genome: mtDNA has a higher mutation rate compared to nuclear DNA due to the lack of introns and protective histone proteins, which help prevent mutations in nuclear DNA.

 

Statement C. mt codons are slightly different from nuclear DNA codons: mtDNA uses a slightly different genetic code. For example, the codon UGA, which is a stop codon in the universal genetic code, codes for tryptophan in mtDNA. Similarly, AGG and AGA code for arginine in the universal genetic code but are stop codons in mtDNA. AUA codes for isoleucine in the universal genetic code but codes for methionine in mtDNA.

 

 

Statement E. Has around 16,000 base pairs: mtDNA contains approximately 16,000 base pairs and 37 genes, which make up about 1% of the total cellular DNA.

                                   

Other Statements:

 

Statement B. Single stranded Circular DNA: This statement is incorrect. mtDNA is circular but double-stranded.

 

Statement D. mtDNA encodes for all the ETC complex proteins: This statement is incorrect. mtDNA encodes for only 13 of the 67 proteins required for the electron transport chain (ETC), which is approximately 19% of the total.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mitochondrial DNA has a higher mutation rate compared to nuclear DNA, has a slightly different genetic code, and contains around 16,000 base pairs, encoding for a portion but not all of the proteins required for the electron transport chain.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presented with mild intermittent upper abdominal pain. X-ray is given below. What is the diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hiatal hernia

 

Explanation:

 

Retrocardiac air fluid level is seen on CXR which is suggestive of a hiatal hernia. It is defined as the displacement through esophageal hiatus of GE junction or other parts of the stomach into the thoracic cavity

 

 

IOC for hiatal hernia: Contrast enhanced CT + oral contrast (Iohexol most commonly) (to determine obstruction/ Volvulus)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bochdalek hernia: This is a congenital diaphragmatic hernia typically occurring at the posterolateral part of the diaphragm, not associated with the retrocardiac region.

 

Option B. Morgagni hernia: Another type of congenital diaphragmatic hernia that occurs anteriorly at the sternocostal triangles, not retrocardiac.

 

Option D. Eventration of diaphragm: Involves an abnormal elevation of the diaphragm muscle, not typically presenting as an air-fluid level in the retrocardiac area.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hiatal hernia can be diagnosed on plain chest X-ray when an air-fluid level is visible in the retrocardiac area, indicating herniation of stomach contents into the thorax through the esophageal hiatus. Contrast-enhanced CT with oral contrast is the imaging of choice for further evaluation, particularly to assess for any complications like obstruction or volvulus.

questions.text: Match the following in relation to fingerprint changes: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1-e, 2-c, 3-b, 4-a, 5-d

 

The changes in fingerprints can be associated with various medical conditions and external factors:

 

  1. Incomplete atrophy of ridges - E. Dermatitis:
    • Dermatitis can cause inflammation and swelling, leading to incomplete atrophy of the fingerprint ridges.
  2. Loss of pattern with ridge atrophy - C. Celiac disease:
    • Celiac disease can cause skin changes and atrophy of the fingerprint ridges, leading to the loss of pattern.
  3. Altered ridges - B. Scleroderma:
    • Scleroderma causes hardening and tightening of the skin, which can alter the fingerprint ridges.
  4. Permanent loss of fingerprints - A. Radiation:
    • Exposure to radiation can cause permanent damage to the skin, leading to the permanent loss of fingerprints.
  5. Distance between ridges is changed but pattern is retained - D. Acromegaly:
    • In acromegaly, there is an increase in the growth of bones and tissues, which can change the distance between fingerprint ridges while retaining the overall pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: You are a public health researcher evaluating a new screening test for early detection of a specific disease in a community. Your team successfully conducted a pilot study in a small group. Before planning a large-scale implementation, you wish to ensure that the findings from your pilot study can be applied to larger, diverse groups of individuals outside your initial sample. This ability to extrapolate the findings in the broader population, i.e. the external validity of a screening test is related to which of the following options? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Generalizability

 

  • Generalizability refers to the extent to which the findings from a study or pilot test can be applied to a broader population.
  • It is a measure of the external validity of a study.
  • Ensuring that the results of a pilot study can be extrapolated to larger, diverse groups outside the initial sample is crucial for the success of large-scale implementations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stability: Refers to the consistency of test results over time, ensuring that repeated measurements yield the same results under unchanged conditions. While important, it does not address how findings apply to different populations.

 

Option B. Objectivity: Ensures that test results are unbiased and not influenced by the person administering the test. While critical for reliable results, it does not relate to applying findings to a broader population.

 

Option D. Repeatability: Refers to the consistency of the test results when repeated under identical conditions. This is crucial for reliability but does not address the applicability of the results to different populations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

External validity of a screening test is related to generalizability.

 

Validity refers to what extent the test measures which it purports to measure (adequacy of measurement).

 

Types of Validity

questions.text: What treatment should be avoided for a male patient in his mid-40s who was brought to the emergency department following a road traffic accident, and presents with a heart rate of 120/min, respiratory rate of 30/min, and an X-ray image of his chest? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chest tube insertion

 

Given Scenario with x ray shows left sided traumatic diaphragmatic rupture with herniation of stomach. Nasogastric tube insertion, log roll, or epidural anesthesia can be done. However, intercostal drain should not be put as it would traumatic the herniated content.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The provided image displays an elevated left hemidiaphragm with stomach herniated into thorax, likely due to a diaphragmatic hernia resulting from blunt trauma in a road traffic accident.

 

  • Chest tube insertion or thoracostomy is not recommended in cases of diaphragmatic hernia and is contraindicated
  • Chest tube insertion is generally indicated for pneumothorax, hemothorax, chylothorax, pleural effusion, among others, but is contraindicated in the presence of pulmonary adhesions, pulmonary trauma, coagulopathy, and diaphragmatic hernia.
  • To insert a chest tube, the 5th intercostal space should be accessed anterior to the midaxillary line, within the triangle of safety, which is located above the level of the nipple and below and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle.
  • Acquired diaphragmatic hernia does not contraindicate nasogastric tube insertion, log roll, or epidural anesthesia.

choices.text: Regardless of ejection fraction and the type of heart failure, the 5-year mortality rate is around 50%.
Non-cardiovascular death is more in HFrEF as compared to HFpEF.
ACEi cause cough in 15% and angioedema in 1%.
AF is common in the elderly and is the cause of stroke in a quarter of stroke cases.

questions.text: All are true regarding heart failure except: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Non-cardiovascular death is more in HFrEF as compared to HFpEF.

 

Non-cardiovascular death refers to mortality due to causes other than cardiovascular diseases, such as infections, accidents, or malignancies.

 

The majority of deaths in HFrEF (Heart Failure with reduced Ejection Fraction) are due to cardiovascular causes (85%), and only 15% are due to non-cardiovascular causes.

 

In contrast, in HFpEF (Heart Failure with preserved Ejection Fraction), 60% of deaths are cardiovascular, and 40% are non-cardiovascular.

 

Therefore, non-cardiovascular death is actually more prevalent in HFpEF patients compared to HFrEF patients, making option B incorrect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Regardless of ejection fraction and the type of heart failure, the 5-year mortality rate is around 50%: This statement is correct. Both HFpEF and HFrEF patients have similar 5-year mortality rates, approximately 50%. This indicates that having a preserved ejection fraction does not necessarily correlate with a better long-term survival rate compared to reduced ejection fraction.

 

Option C. ACEi cause cough in 15% and angioedema in 1%: This statement is correct. Angiotensin-Converting Enzyme inhibitors (ACEi) are known to cause a persistent cough in about 15% of patients and angioedema, a more serious but less common side effect, in approximately 1% of patients.

 

Option D. AF is common in the elderly and is the cause of stroke in a quarter of stroke cases: This statement is correct. Atrial Fibrillation (AF) is indeed common among elderly patients and is a significant cause of cardioembolic strokes, accounting for about 25% of such cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Non-cardiovascular deaths are more common in HFpEF patients compared to HFrEF patients.

questions.text: All of the following ions have decreased concentration on the luminal side of proximal convoluted tubule except: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chloride

 

The concentration of chloride on the luminal side is more when compared to sodium, glucose, and amino acids.

 

In the first half of the proximal tubule, sodium is reabsorbed by co-transport along with glucose, amino acids, and other solutes thus decreasing their concentrations markedly along the length of the proximal tubule. Thus, the solution will have a higher concentration of chloride which is around 105 mEg/L.

 

In the second half of the proximal tubule, sodium gets re-absorbed along with chloride. Higher chloride (approx. 140meq/L) concentration favors its own diffusion from the lumen into the renal interstitial fluid.

 

Proximal tubule’s high permeability to water, increases water reabsorption thus helps in maintaining sodium concentration and total osmolarity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amino acids: Their concentration decreases significantly due to nearly complete reabsorption.

 

Option B. Glucose: Similarly, glucose concentration decreases significantly because of active reabsorption.

 

Option D. Bicarbonate: Its concentration also decreases due to active reabsorption facilitated by carbonic anhydrase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chloride concentration on the luminal side of the proximal convoluted tubule does not decrease as significantly as amino acids, glucose, and bicarbonate due to the preferential reabsorption of these other solutes in the early segments of the PCT.

questions.text: What is the most common complication of the central line insertion below the marked bone? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Arterial puncture

 

Explanation:

 

The bone indicated in the image above is the left clavicle. An arterial puncture is the most common complication of a central line insertion below this bone.

 

  • Complications of central vein catheterization are - 
    • Arterial puncture- this is the most common complication.
    • Cardiac tamponade is the most important life-threatening complication. It occurs as a result of puncture of intrapericardial superior vena cava, right atrium, or right ventricle.
    • Pneumothorax- injury to the underlying pleura may lead to pneumothorax. This is more common in subclavian vein catheterization.
    • Chylothorax can occur particularly in left subclavian vein catheterization. But it is not the most common.
    • Injury to the associated nerves like brachial plexus, stellate ganglion, phrenic nerve, or vocal cords.
    • Thromboembolism leading to venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism is more common with femoral veins.
    • Infections

 

 Other Options:

 

Option B. Thrombophlebitis: Thrombophlebitis refers to inflammation of a vein associated with clot formation. While thrombophlebitis can occur following any central line placement, it's more commonly associated with peripheral IV lines. However, central venous catheters are more commonly associated with deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which is the formation of a blood clot inside the larger, deeper veins.

 

Option C. Empyema: Empyema refers to the accumulation of pus in the pleural cavity. While empyema itself is not a direct complication of central line placement, pneumothorax or hemothorax (air or blood in the pleural space, respectively) caused by central line placement can lead to infection and subsequently empyema if not recognized and treated.

 

Option D. Chylothorax: Chylothorax is the accumulation of lymphatic fluid in the pleural space. This can happen if the thoracic duct is damaged. The thoracic duct is a major lymphatic vessel that runs in the thorax but is not typically at risk with subclavian line placement. Chylothorax would be more of a concern with procedures that are done in close proximity to the thoracic duct, like surgeries or interventions in the mediastinum or around the esophagus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Arterial puncture is one of the most common complications associated with the subclavian approach for central venous catheter placement. The subclavian artery lies directly beneath the vein, so inadvertent puncture of the artery can occur if the needle is advanced too deeply or at an incorrect angle. Accidental puncture of the subclavian artery can lead to complications such as hematoma, hemothorax, and can also be problematic if not recognized because threading a catheter into the arterial system can have catastrophic consequences.

questions.text: Which among the following has the highest airway resistance? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bronchi

 

Among the given options, bronchi (medium-sized airway) offer maximum resistance.

 

The best answer here is bronchi, as the other options suggest smaller airways and bronchi is the only medium-sized airway.

 

Since the airway branches in each generation exist in parallel rather than in series, smallest airway contributes little to overall resistance. As the parallel branching increases, the resistance decreases because the total cross-sectional diameter of small airways put together is high resulting in less resistance. Also, airflow velocity decreases substantially because the effective cross-sectional area increases (i.e., the flow becomes laminar).

 

Other factors affecting airway resistance:

 

  • Lung volume, as lung volume increases the resistance decreases and vice versa. Lung volume increases the trans airway pressure thus increasing the caliber of the airway.
  • Airway mucus, edema, and contraction of bronchial smooth muscle increase the airway resistance. Its clinical application is seen in asthma, bronchitis, and emphysema
  • The density and viscosity of inspired gas also contribute to airway resistance. A gas with more density imparts more resistance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alveolar duct and C. Respiratory bronchioles: These smaller airways have much lower resistance due to their large total cross-sectional area, which reduces resistance despite their small individual diameters.

 

Option D. Small bronchioles: Similar to the respiratory bronchioles, their high number and extensive branching reduce overall resistance.

 

Educational Objective

 

Bronchi, the medium-sized airways, have the highest airway resistance due to their relatively narrow diameter compared to the total cross-sectional area of smaller airways.

 

Airflow can be derived from Poiseuille- Hagen formula:

 

 

Where:

 

  • R is the resistance
  • is pie symbol
  • r is radius
  • is viscosity
  • L is length

 

According to Poisuille’s formula, Airway resistance is inversely proportional to the fourth power radius.

 

Poiseuille- Hagen formula suggests that the smallest airways are the major site of resistance.

questions.text: Which of the following marked structure is damaged in respiratory distress syndrome? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2

 

The structure marked as 2 represents Type II pneumocytes, which are crucial in the pathophysiology of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS).

 

Key Points:

 

  • Type I pneumocytes (Marked as 1): These cells are large and flattened, making up the majority of the alveolar surface area. They form the thin barrier necessary for efficient gas exchange.
  • Type II pneumocytes (Marked as 2): These cells are rounded and responsible for producing surfactant, a substance composed of phospholipids and proteins that reduces surface tension within the alveoli. Surfactant is essential for preventing alveolar collapse (atelectasis) during exhalation. In respiratory distress syndrome, especially in premature infants, the deficiency or dysfunction of these Type II cells leads to insufficient surfactant production, causing the alveoli to collapse and resulting in severe breathing difficulties.
  • Endothelial cells of capillaries (Marked as 3): These cells line the blood vessels within the lungs and are involved in the exchange of gases between the blood and alveoli. They are not primarily involved in the pathogenesis of RDS.
  • Red Blood Cells (Marked as 4): These are the cells responsible for carrying oxygen from the lungs to the rest of the body and returning carbon dioxide to the lungs for exhalation. While essential for overall respiratory function, they are not the site of damage in RDS.

 

Clinical Relevance:

 

  • Respiratory Distress Syndrome (RDS): Commonly seen in premature infants, RDS is primarily caused by a deficiency of surfactant due to immature Type II pneumocytes. The lack of surfactant leads to increased surface tension, alveolar collapse, and severe respiratory distress. This condition is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality in preterm infants.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Type II pneumocytes are crucial for surfactant production and alveolar stability, and their dysfunction or immaturity is the primary cause of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) in neonates.

questions.text: You are a nutritionist giving a lecture about milk pasteurization and its quality assurance tests. A curious student inquires about the various tests to validate the efficacy of pasteurization. You begin to list them, but highlight one that is not directly related to the pasteurization process. Which of the following tests does not directly evaluate the efficiency of milk pasteurization? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) lodine test 

 

  • Given tests are associated with the milk pasteurization process except for the iodine test.
  • This test is conducted to examine the potential adulteration of milk with starch or cereal flour.
  • Iodine test - The presence of addition of starch in milk can be detected using an iodine test.
  • When two or three drops of iodine solution is added to milk taken in a test tube, the solution turns dark blue.
  • This shows the presence of starch mixed with the milk.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phosphatase Test: Used to check for the presence of the enzyme phosphatase, which should be inactivated by proper pasteurization. This ensures that the milk has been heated sufficiently.

 

Option C. Standard Plate Count: Measures the total bacterial count to ensure it meets the standards for pasteurized milk. A lower count indicates effective pasteurization.

 

Option D. Methylene Blue Reduction Test: Measures the time it takes for methylene blue to lose its color, which correlates with bacterial activity; high counts indicate inadequate pasteurization. This test helps verify the reduction of microbial load.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PASTEURIZATION TESTS:

 

  1. Phosphatase Test: Widely used test
  2. Standard Plate Count: Standard is coliforms be absent in 1 ml of milk
  3. Methylene blue reduction test: Enforced limit is 30,000 bacterial count per ml of pasteurized milk

questions.text: A 72-year-old patient with obstructive jaundice has a distended gall bladder and a dilated common bile duct and intrahepatic biliary radicles on ultrasound. Which of the following will be most useful to localize the cause? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP)

 

Given scenario of an elderly male with obstructive jaundice and distended gall bladder, is suggestive of periampullary tumour. The best investigation would be a CECT abdomen (not provided in the option) or MRCP.

 

Correct. MRCP is a non-invasive imaging technique that visualizes the biliary and pancreatic ducts. It provides detailed images without the need for ionizing radiation or invasive procedures. Given the patient's age and presentation, MRCP is an ideal choice to visualize obstructions or abnormalities in the bile duct system without posing additional risks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Endoscopic ultrasound: This is a useful modality for visualizing the biliary tree, pancreas, and surrounding structures. It can be particularly helpful in assessing small lesions or stones that might be missed by other imaging modalities. It would be utilised if MRCP/CECT did not yield adequate diagnosis, or for staging of periampullary tumors.

 

Option C. Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography: This is an invasive procedure where contrast is injected directly into the biliary system through the liver, and then X-rays are taken. It can be diagnostic as well as therapeutic (e.g., for bile duct drainage). However, it's more invasive than MRCP and might not be the first choice for solely diagnostic purposes in a 72-year-old patient.

 

Option D. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP): ERCP is both diagnostic and therapeutic. It involves inserting an endoscope through the mouth to the duodenum and injecting contrast into the bile and pancreatic ducts. While ERCP can visualize and treat obstructions, it's invasive and carries risks like pancreatitis, especially if used primarily for diagnostic purposes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Obstructive jaundice is a condition in which there is a blockage of the flow of bile out of the liver. This results in redirection of excess bile and its by-products into the blood, and bile excretion from the body is incomplete

 

Symptoms of obstructive jaundice include yellowing of the skin and whites of the eyes; paler stools and darker urine; and intense itching.

 

The most common cause of obstructive jaundice is the presence of CBD stones (choledocholithiasis). Other causes of obstructive jaundice are tumors, trauma, cysts, and inflammation in the bile ducts.

questions.text: A patient is not able to see the lateral fields. He was having a mild headache for a few weeks and now presented to the clinic. Visual field examination shows the following finding. What is the probable site of the lesion based on the image displayed?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Optic chiasma

 

The visual field defect in the image is indicative of bitemporal hemianopia, so the probable site of the lesion is the optic chiasma.

 

The most common cause of this is pituitary gland tumours.

 

Other causes include suprasellar aneurysms, chronic arachnoiditis, suprasellar tumours like craniopharyngioma and suprasellar meningioma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Occipital lobe: Lesions here typically cause congruent homonymous hemianopia, where the same visual field is lost in both eyes, not bitemporal defects.

 

Option C. Optic tract: Lesions in the optic tract cause homonymous hemianopia, affecting the same side of the visual field in both eyes.

 

Option D. Optic radiation: Lesions here also cause homonymous hemianopia, but depending on the location, they might lead to variations like a superior or inferior quadrantanopia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Visual field defects:

choices.text: Life expectancy at birth, literacy and standard of living
Life expectancy at 1 year, literacy and standard of living
Infant mortality rate, literacy and standard of living
Life expectancy at 1 year, literacy and infant mortality rate

questions.text: You are a global health researcher working on a report assessing the development status of various countries. To classify the countries and compare them, you decide to use the Human Development Index (HDI). You recall that HDI is a commonly utilized measure but seek to clarify its exact components, as presented by organizations like the World Health Organization (WHO). Which of the following correctly identifies the components that make up the HDI? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Life expectancy at birth, literacy and standard of living 

 

Human Development Index (HDI)

 

The Human Development Index (HDI) is a composite statistic used to rank countries based on human development levels. It consists of three main components:

 

  • Life Expectancy at Birth: Measures the average number of years a newborn is expected to live.
  • Education (Literacy and Mean Years of Schooling): Assesses the average number of years of education received by people ages 25 and older and the expected years of schooling for children entering school.
  • Standard of Living (Gross National Income per capita): Adjusted for purchasing power parity (PPP).

 

Note -

 

  •  
    • HDI values range: 0 to + 1
    • HDI India is 0. 633 (Rank 134 out of 186 countries)
    • Human poverty index [HPI] is complementary to HDI

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: You're mentoring a group of budding epidemiologists who are keen on understanding the nuances of different study designs. One of them is particularly interested in case-control studies. During your discussion, you decide to quiz them on aspects that are typically not inherent to case-control studies. Which of the given options would not usually be part of a case-control study? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Follow up 

 

  • Follow up is not a component of case-control studies.
  • These studies are retrospective and do not involve tracking subjects over time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Matching: Process of selecting controls in a such a way that they are similar to cases (with regard to certain pertinent selected variables which may influence the outcome of disease, thereby distorting the results). It eliminates confounding.

 

Option C. Strength of association: In case-control studies, the strength of association is measured using the odds ratio (an estimate of relative risk).

 

Option D. Selection of study subjects: Essential in case-control studies, involving the selection of cases with the disease and controls without the disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Case-control studies do not include follow-up of subjects but focus on matching, assessing the strength of association using odds ratios, and selecting cases and controls for analysis.

questions.text: A person working in a restaurant comes to the casualty with a huge burn on his abdomen. On examination, the injury looks like below. What is the most likely cause of the injury?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Moist heat

 

  • In the case scenario given above the patient has suffered from a ‘Scald injury’

  • Clinical presentation - erythema, blisters, and a line of demarcation

  • Cause of scald - application of liquid above 60°C or from steam which is moist heat.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Electric burn: Electric burns typically have entry and exit points and are caused by electrical currents passing through the body, which is not seen in the image.

 

Option B. Chemical burn: Chemical burns result from exposure to corrosive substances and may have different patterns and additional signs such as discoloration or tissue damage beyond just blisters and erythema.

 

Option C. Dry heat: Burns caused by dry heat, such as flames or hot objects, usually present with charring or a different burn pattern compared to scald injuries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most likely cause of the burn injury shown in the image is moist heat, specifically a scald injury caused by hot liquids or steam.

 

TYPES of SCALD INJURIES

 

  • Immersion burns: Due to immersion in hot liquid, usually water.

  • Accidental Splash burns

  • Steam burns: Exposure to superheated steam.

questions.text: A surgeon performs an appendicectomy with a grid iron incision. He later converts the incision to Rutherford Morrison incision. Which of the following are cut? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

When the initial Gridiron incision is converted to Rutherford Morrison incision, the external oblique, internal oblique, and transverse abdominis muscles are cut.

 

Gridiron incision is also known as McArthur’s incision. It is a muscle splitting incision used in open appendicectomy.

 

Rutherford Morrison incision is useful in cases where the appendix is para- or retrocaecal and fixed. The lower end of the incision is located over McBurney's point and extends obliquely upwards and laterally as necessary. It involves cutting through the skin, subcutaneous tissues, external oblique, underlying internal oblique, transversus abdominis, and peritoneum along the line of the incision.

 

The Lanz incision is a transverse or skin crease incision for appendicitis, located 2 cm below the umbilicus and centered on the midclavicular-mid-inguinal line.

 

The Pfannenstiel incision is an infraumbilical transverse incision in the lower abdomen, often used for gynecological and obstetric procedures.

choices.text: Oxidative decarboxylation of alpha-ketoglutarate is increased.
﻿﻿﻿Increased synthesis of glutamine and glutamate from alpha-ketoglutarate

questions.text: Which of the following is false in a patient with advanced liver disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oxidative decarboxylation of alpha-ketoglutarate

 

“Oxidative decarboxylation of alpha-ketoglutarate is increased is false. 

 

This process occurs in the TCA (Krebs) cycle and is catalyzed by alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, a mitochondrial enzyme.


In advanced liver disease, alpha-ketoglutarate is diverted toward glutamate and glutamine synthesis (to help detoxify ammonia), which decreases its availability for the TCA cycle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increased synthesis of glutamine and glutamate from alpha-ketoglutarate is true. In liver disease, there is an increased synthesis of glutamine and glutamate as a way to detoxify ammonia. 

 

Option C. Decreased ATP synthesis is true. in advanced liver disease, ammonia levels increase which withdraws α-ketoglutarate to form glutamate and glutamine. This in turn results in lowered concentrations of citric acid cycle intermediates, and hence decreased ATP synthesis.

 

 

Option D. Hyperammonemia is true. In advanced liver disease, the liver's ability to detoxify ammonia is compromised, leading to elevated ammonia levels in the bloodstream, resulting in hyperammonemia.

 

Educational Objective:

Detoxification of ammonia takes place in the liver, where it is metabolised and excreted as urea (urea cycle). Due to impairment of ammonia metabolism in advanced liver disease, ammonia levels increase which withdraws α-ketoglutarate to form glutamate and glutamine.

 

 

This in turn results in lowered concentrations of citric acid cycle intermediates, and hence decreased ATP synthesis.

questions.text: What is the frequency of tetanic stimulation used in neuromuscular monitoring? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 50 Hz

 

Explanation:

 

This is the frequency typically used for tetanic stimulation in neuromuscular monitoring. A stimulation of 50 Hz for 5 seconds results in a tetanic contraction. If the patient is under profound neuromuscular blockade, no contraction will be observed. If there's some recovery from blockade, a contraction will be noted but may be weaker than in a patient with no blockade. Fade during or after tetanic stimulation can indicate incomplete recovery from blockade.

 

Tetanic stimulation is a method used in neuromuscular monitoring to assess the degree of neuromuscular blockade in patients who have received neuromuscular blocking agents (often used during surgeries to produce muscle paralysis). Tetanic stimulation involves giving a high-frequency series of electrical impulses to a peripheral nerve to cause sustained muscle contraction. The response to tetanic stimulation can help determine the depth of neuromuscular blockade and the presence of fade.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 0.2 Hz: This frequency is more representative of a "single twitch" stimulation, where one stimulus is delivered every 5 seconds. It is used to monitor the initial onset and the later stages of recovery from neuromuscular blockade.

 

Option B. 2 Hz: This refers to a train-of-four (TOF) stimulation where four stimuli are given at a frequency of 2 Hz (2 stimuli per second). It's a common method of monitoring neuromuscular blockade, especially when assessing for residual blockade. A fading response in the TOF is indicative of neuromuscular blockade.

 

Option C. 20 Hz: This isn't a standard frequency for neuromuscular monitoring.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The frequency of tetanic stimulation used in neuromuscular monitoring is typically 50 Hz.

 

 

PATTERN OF NERVE STIMULATION:

 

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 1359

questions.text: Identify the incorrect match: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 4 - Lamina propria 

 

Is an incorrect match because the structure labelled 4 shows the basement membrane rather than the lamina propria.

 

The image shows irregular cells attached to the basement membrane and is of pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium (marked as 4 in the image). It appears to have multiple layers. There is, however, only one layer of cells. The multi-layered appearance is caused by the nuclei of epithelial cells (shown as 3 in the image) being located at different levels.1`

 

The epithelium shows hair-like projections called cilia (marked as 1 in the image) and goblet cells (marked as 2 in the image). Goblet cells secrete mucous which helps to trap dust entering the passages. The cilia are capable of movement and help in the clearance of mucous

 

Example include epithelium lining the trachea and in large bronchi.

 

Other Options:

 

1- Cilia: These are the hair-like projections visible at the top of the epithelial cells, which help in moving mucus and trapped particles out of the respiratory passages.

 

2- Goblet cells: These cells are interspersed between the epithelial cells and are responsible for producing mucus. They appear as clear, expanded cells at the level marked "2."

 

3- Nuclei of epithelial cell: The nuclei shown here are located at different heights within the cells, giving the epithelium a pseudostratified appearance.

 

4- Basement membrane: This layer supports the epithelium and is incorrectly labeled as the lamina propria in the options. It is a thin, fibrous structure evident just below the epithelial cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The marked structure in the image are

 

1- Cilia

2- Goblet cell

3- Nuclei of epithelial cell

4- Basement membrane

questions.text: Which of the following emergency contraceptive is used in India? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg


In India, Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg is commonly used as an emergency contraceptive. This medication is effective when taken within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse. It works primarily by inhibiting or delaying ovulation, thus preventing pregnancy.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Misoprostol 400 mcg: Incorrect. Misoprostol is used for medical abortion and does not serve as an emergency contraceptive.

 

Option B. Ethinyl estradiol 600 mcg: Incorrect. Ethinyl estradiol is used in combined oral contraceptive pills, but it is not commonly used alone for emergency contraception. The Yuzpe regimen, which includes ethynyl estradiol, is less commonly used compared to levonorgestrel.

 

Option C. Ulipristal 30 mg: Incorrect. Ulipristal acetate (30 mg) is a selective progesterone receptor modulator used as an emergency contraceptive, but it is not as widely available or commonly used in India as levonorgestrel.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg is the emergency contraceptive used in India.

 

Ref: Page no 243, Berek and Novak’s Gynecology 15th edition

questions.text: Identify the rules used as tests of insanity? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Both A and B

 

  • Durham's rule and Curren's rule are used in cases as tests for insanity.

  • The Durham's rule states, “an accused is not criminally responsible if his unlawful act was the product of mental disease or mental defect”.

  • The Curren's rule states that “an accused person will not be criminally responsible, if at the time of committing the act, he did not have the capacity to regulate his conduct to the requirements of law, as a result of mental disease or defect”.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Both Durham's rule and Curren's rule are significant tests used to determine criminal responsibility in cases where the defendant's mental state is in question.

questions.text: Which of the following is not classified as OCD as per ICD 11? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) PTSD

 

The International Classification of Diseases (ICD-11), like the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5), classifies a number of disorders under the umbrella of obsessive-compulsive and related disorders. However, PTSD (Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder) is not classified as an obsessive-compulsive-related disorder in ICD-11. Instead, it's classified under trauma- and stressor-related disorders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichotillomania: This is classified as an obsessive-compulsive-related disorder in ICD-11.

 

Option B. Body dysmorphic disorder: This too is categorized as an obsessive-compulsive-related disorder in ICD-11.

 

Option C. Hypochondriac disorder: Now termed "Illness Anxiety Disorder" in DSM-5, this is categorized as an obsessive-compulsive-related disorder in ICD-11.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Obsessive-compulsive or related disorders in ICD-11 are classified as:

 

  • Obsessive-compulsive disorder
  • Body dysmorphic disorder
  • Olfactory reference disorder
  • Hypochondriasis
  • Hoarding disorder
  • Trichotillomania
  • Excoriation disorder

 

Reference: International Classification of Diseases, 11th edition, Page No 43-47

questions.text: Which of the following is not used to treat PCOD? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tamoxifen

 

Explanation:

 

Tamoxifen is not commonly used in the treatment of Polycystic Ovary Disease (PCOD). Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) primarily used in the treatment and prevention of breast cancer.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Medical Management of PCOD:
    • OCP (Option D): Oral contraceptive pills regulate the menstrual cycle and hormones and are given to women who are not desirous of fertility to regularize their cycles.
    • Metformin (Option B): Metformin is an insulin sensitizer, which decreases hyperinsulinemia and improves fertility in patients with PCOD.
    • Ovulation Induction Drugs:
      • Clomiphene (Option A): Clomiphene citrate is commonly used to induce ovulation in women with infertility due to PCOD.
      • Letrozole: Letrozole, an aromatase inhibitor, is the drug of choice for ovulation induction in PCOD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clomiphene citrate: Clomiphene is an ovulation induction agent used in the treatment of infertility in women with PCOD.

 

Option B. Metformin: Metformin is used to decrease insulin resistance and hyperinsulinemia in PCOD, which can help in regulating menstrual cycles and improving fertility.

 

Option D. OCP: Oral contraceptive pills are used to regulate menstrual cycles and manage hormonal imbalances in women with PCOD who do not seek to become pregnant.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tamoxifen is not typically used in the treatment of PCOD. Instead, treatments include oral contraceptive pills, metformin, and ovulation induction agents such as clomiphene and letrozole.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of Gynecology 3rd edition. Pg 398 Dutta’s textbook of Gynecology 6th edition pg470

questions.text: Which of the following devices can be used for managing a patient with B/L external auditory canal atresia?(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A.

 

 

Image A shows Bone Anchored Hearing Aid (BAHA) and it can be used in managing B/L external auditory canal atresia.

 

INDICATIONS FOR BAHA

 

  1. When air-conduction (AC) hearing aid cannot be used:
  2. Canal atresia, congenital or acquired, not amenable to treatment.
  3. Chronic ear discharge, not amenable to treatment.
  4. Excessive feedback and discomfort from air-conduction hearing aid.
  5. Conductive or mixed hearing loss, e.g., otosclerosis and tympanosclerosis where surgery is contraindicated.
  6. Single-sided hearing loss.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cochlear implant is an electronic device that can provide useful hearing and improved communication abilities for persons who have severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss and who cannot benefit from hearing aids.

 

Cochlear implants may be used both in children and adults. The following criteria help define candidacy for cochlear implantation:

 

  1. Bilateral severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss.
  2. Little or no benefit from hearing aids.
  3. No medical contraindication for surgery.
  4. Realistic expectation.
  5. Good family and social support toward habilitation.
  6. Adequate cognitive function to be able to use the device.

 

Option C. Stapedectomy piston is used in otosclerosis patients.

 

Option D. Partial ossicular replacement prosthesis is used to replace the incudo-stapedial joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients with bilateral external auditory canal atresia, BAHA is an excellent management option, leveraging bone conduction to bypass the outer and middle ear, thus facilitating hearing when traditional air-conduction devices cannot be used.

choices.text: 1-5% of the population can have epileptiform discharges.
Scalp EEG may be helpful in localizing frontal lobe epilepsy.
Doing EEG is mandatory for the diagnosis of seizures.
Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy shows triphasic and slow waves.

questions.text: True about electroencephalogram (EEG) is all except: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Doing EEG is mandatory for the diagnosis of seizures.

 

Electroencephalography (EEG) is a key diagnostic tool in the evaluation of neurological conditions, particularly epilepsy. However, it is not mandatory for the diagnosis of seizures. A patient can have seizures even if their EEG results are normal. An abnormal EEG can provide reassurance of a diagnosis of epilepsy when the clinical context supports it, but a normal EEG does not rule out epilepsy or seizures. Therefore, making an EEG mandatory for the diagnosis of seizures is incorrect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1-5% of the population can have epileptiform discharges: This statement is correct. Epileptiform discharges can be present in a small percentage of the general population without necessarily indicating that the individual has epilepsy.

 

Option B. Scalp EEG may be helpful in localizing frontal lobe epilepsy: This statement is correct. Scalp EEG can indeed help localize the origin of epileptic activity, including frontal lobe epilepsy, although it might not always be definitive.

 

Option D. Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy shows triphasic and slow waves: This statement is correct. Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) and other forms of encephalopathy can show triphasic waves and slow wave patterns on an EEG.

 

Educational Objective:

 

EEG is not mandatory for the diagnosis of seizures as patients can have seizures even with a normal EEG.

questions.text: Which of the following will halter the maturity of collagen?(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Scurvy

 

Option B. Scurvy:

  • Scurvy is a nutritional deficiency disease caused by a lack of vitamin C (ascorbic acid).
  • Vitamin C is essential for the synthesis of collagen. Without adequate vitamin C, collagen production is impaired, leading to the characteristic symptoms of scurvy, including impaired wound healing and gum bleeding.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Beri-Beri:

  • Beri-Beri is a nutritional deficiency disease caused by a lack of vitamin B1 (thiamine).
  • Thiamine deficiency primarily affects the nervous system and cardiovascular system and does not directly impact collagen maturity.

 

Option C. Night Blindness:

  • Night blindness is often associated with a deficiency in vitamin A (retinol).
  • Vitamin A deficiency primarily affects vision and does not directly impact collagen maturity.

 

Option D. Rickets:

  • Rickets is a nutritional deficiency disease caused by a lack of vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate.
  • Vitamin D plays a role in calcium and phosphate homeostasis, which is crucial for bone health but does not directly impact collagen maturity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Scurvy is the condition that will halt the maturity of collagen because it is caused by a deficiency in vitamin C, which is essential for collagen synthesis.

 

Ascorbic acid is necessary for the post-translational hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues.

 

 

Hydroxyproline and hydroxylysine are essential for the formation of cross links in the collagen, which gives the tensile strength to the fibers. This process is absolutely necessary for the normal production of supporting tissues such as osteoid, collagen and intercellular cement substance of capillaries.

 

Thus, in ascorbic acid deficiency (Scurvy), collagen is abnormal and the intercellular cement substance is brittle. So, capillaries are fragile, leading to the tendency to bleed even under minor pressure.

questions.text: Wobble hypothesis is due to which property of the codon?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Degeneracy

 

  • The wobble hypothesis is primarily due to the degeneracy of the genetic code. Degeneracy means that multiple codons can code for the same amino acid. The third position of the codon (the wobble position) is less constrained and allows for some variation in the base pairing, which accommodates the degeneracy in the genetic code.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ambiguity: Ambiguity is not a property of the codon but rather a state of uncertainty or multiple interpretations. In the genetic code, codons are specific and not ambiguous in their assignment to amino acids.
