Option C. Universality: Universality refers to the fact that the genetic code is nearly identical in all living organisms. While universality is an important property of the genetic code, it is not directly related to the wobble hypothesis.

 

Option D. Commaless: "Commaless" is not a recognized property related to the codon or the wobble hypothesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The wobble hypothesis is primarily due to the degeneracy of the genetic code, allowing multiple codons to code for the same amino acid, with variation in the third (wobble) position of the codon.

 

Wobble bases

 

3rd base of the codon on mRNA and 1st base of anticodon on tRNA in 5’ to 3’ direction are wobble positions.

 

 

Wobble hypothesis says that for binding between bases present in these positions, some imprecision is allowed. i.e. one base in anticodon can bind with various bases of codon. This is also called as degeneracy of codon i.e. There is more than one codon for one amino acid. So, Wobble hypothesis is due to degeneracy of codons.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male patient presented to the outpatient department with cervical lymphadenopathy. As a part of the evaluation, the Paul-Bunnell test was done. What is the principle of this test? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Heterophile antibodies

 

The principle of the Paul-Bunnell test is based on heterophile antibodies.

 

Heterophile antibodies agglutinate shared antigens.

 

Paul-Bunnell test is used diagnosing for infectious mononucleosis, wherein heterophile antibodies agglutinate sheep erythrocytes.

 

The Weil-Felix reaction is another example heterophile agglutination test. Here the common antigen is shared between typhus rickettsia and some strains of proteus bacilli. It is helpful in the serodiagnosis of typhus fevers.

 

Streptococcus MG agglutination test for primary atypical pneumonia and the cold agglutination test for mycoplasma (primary atypical) pneumonia are also based on heterophile antibody.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Complement fixation: Incorrect: The complement fixation test is based on the ability of antigen-antibody complexes to fix complement. This is a different mechanism from the heterophile antibody agglutination used in the Paul-Bunnell test.

 

Option B. Super-antigens: Incorrect: Superantigens are a class of antigens that cause excessive activation of the immune system by non-specific activation of T-cells, leading to massive cytokine release. This is not related to the Paul-Bunnell test.

 

Option D. Haptens: Incorrect: Haptens are small molecules that elicit an immune response only when attached to a large carrier such as a protein. The Paul-Bunnell test does not involve haptens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Paul-Bunnell test is based on the detection of heterophile antibodies, which agglutinate sheep erythrocytes, and is used in the diagnosis of infectious mononucleosis.

questions.text: What is the fixative used for a pap smear? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 95% ethanol

 

The most common fixative used in a Pap smear is 95% ethyl alcohol (ethanol). This fixative helps preserve the cells collected on the slides for cytological examination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Formalin: Formalin (10%) is commonly used as a fixative for histology specimens but is not used for Pap smears.

 

Option B. Air dried: Air drying is not a method used for preserving Pap smear specimens as it can lead to poor preservation of cellular details.

 

Option C. Normal saline: Normal saline is not a fixative. Tissues must be immediately transferred to formol saline if using normal saline temporarily.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fixative used for a Pap smear is typically 95% ethanol, which helps preserve the cellular details on the slides for accurate cytological examination.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition Pg 110,111, William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition 632, 633

questions.text: What is the most common cause for hospital admission after day care surgery? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Postoperative nausea and vomiting

 

Explanation:

 

The most common cause for hospital admission or delayed discharge from the hospital post day care surgery is Postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV). PONV is a frequent complication following surgery and anesthesia, significantly impacting patient comfort and recovery, and often leading to extended hospital stays or readmissions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Respiratory distress: While it is a serious concern, it is not as commonly the cause for hospital admission after day care surgery as PONV.

 

Option B. Post-surgical pain: Although post-surgical pain is a common issue, it is generally managed effectively with analgesics and is less frequently the cause for hospital admission compared to PONV.

 

Option D. Bleeding: Postoperative bleeding can be a complication but is less common as a cause for hospital admission after day care surgery compared to PONV.

 

Risk factors for PONV:

 

 

Educational Objective :

 

Postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV) is the most common cause for hospital admission or delayed discharge after day care surgery.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 2603

questions.text: Imagine you are a clinician administering vaccines to a group of travelers going to a region with high Hepatitis B prevalence. One of the travelers, who has a background in biology, curiously asks which specific part of the Hepatitis B virus is actually present in the vaccine to induce an immune response. Out of the given options, which antigen is included in the Hepatitis B subunit vaccine? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) HbsAg

 

  • Hepatitis B is endemic throughout the world
  • Hepatitis B subunit vaccines consist of HBsAg (Hepatitis B virus surface antigen).
  • These vaccines are created using large molecules obtained from the immunogenic parts of pathogens through recombinant DNA technology.
  • They contrast with fully inactivated whole-cell vaccines as they exclusively contain the antigenic elements of the pathogen.
  • These elements are essential for prompting a defensive immune reaction.

 

Vaccines for Hepatitis B:

 

  • Plasma derived vaccine:
    • Is formalin inactivated sub-unit vaccine
    • Is based on HBsAg
    • Derived from carriers of Hepatitis B
    • Hepatitis B vaccine, dose schedule in adult (months) 0, 1, 6 months
  • rDNA yeast derived vaccine: Recombinant DNA vaccine (genetically engineered)

 

Hepatitis B Immunoglobulin: 

 

  • Required for immediate protection:
    • Surgeons, nurse, laboratory workers
    • Newborn infants of carrier mothers
    • Sexual contacts of acute Hepatitis B patients
    • Ideally administered within 6 hours (not later than 48 hours)

  • Dose: 0.05–0.07 mL/kg, 2 doses 30 days apart

     

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Hepatitis B subunit vaccine contains HBsAg, which is essential for inducing an immune response against the virus.

questions.text: A patient presented with vertigo, tinnitus, and head tilt. He underwent myringoplasty for the safe type of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) 6 months back. What is your diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Perilymphatic fistula

 

  • The clinical scenario with symptoms of vertigo, tinnitus, and head tilt and history of myringoplasty done for CSOM suggest that the diagnosis is perilymphatic fistula.
  • A peri-lymphatic fistula is an abnormal communication between the inner ear and the middle ear that can allow perilymph to leak from the cochlea or vestibule, most commonly through the round or oval window.
  • Precipitating causes include surgery, blunt trauma, penetrating trauma, barotrauma, infection, cholesteatoma, or sudden changes in CSF pressure as can occur with straining, sneezing, or Valsalva’s maneuver. Congenital ear abnormalities may predispose to perilymph leaks. Spontaneous perilymph fistulae are rare.
  • The clinical picture of perilymph fistulae is variable, with symptoms ranging from mild to incapacitating. Vertigo, or more often unsteadiness, is the most common symptom. Hearing loss, tinnitus, or aural fullness may be present. A thorough history inquiring about activities such as trauma, scuba diving, flying, and straining is critical in the diagnosis of this disorder as the symptoms are vague and coincident with other vestibular disorders. Fistula test is positive.

 

Investigations

 

  • HRCT temporal bone has high sensitivity in detecting peri lymphatic fistula.
  • A combination of CT and MRI diagnose almost 100% of cases.
  • Other tests include audiometry and electrocochleography.

 

Management of a peri-lymphatic fistula is either by conservative or surgical methods. Conservative therapy includes avoiding anything that can increase inner ear or intracranial pressure and the use of intratympanic steroids in acute decompensation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Labyrinthitis presents with vestibular symptoms like sudden onset of persistent vertigo with associated symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, sweating and pallor and sensorineural hearing loss.

 

Option C. Paget's disease of bone usually presents with hearing loss as a prominent feature, when the skull is involved. It is not associated with a history of surgery, trauma or vestibulocochlear symptoms.

 

Option D. Vestibular Schwannoma, also called as acoustic neuroma is a tumor that arises from the Schwann cells of the vestibular, but rarely from the cochlear division of vestibulocochlear nerve within the internal auditory canal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Perilymphatic fistula should be suspected in patients presenting with vestibular symptoms following ear surgery, particularly when associated with activities that change intracranial or middle ear pressure. Diagnosis is largely based on clinical history, symptomatology, and specific imaging tests.

questions.text: A 60-year-old postmenopausal woman comes with a history of Colles’ fracture 6 months ago. Her DEXA scan reveals T score of -2.5. What is the next best step?(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Alendronate

 

OSTEOPOROSIS (V > H > C)

 

  • Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e., there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration.
  • Bone mineral density is measured by DEXA scan (65 years onwards).
  • Normal Ca2+, PO‑4, ALP
  • Hemiplegic – Humerus maximum loss of bone mineral density.

 

 

  • Etiology:

 

 

  • Radiological Investigation: 
    • Quantitative CT is a newer imaging technique that can be used to detect osteoporosis.
    • Radiological features are loss of vertical height of vertebrae (collapse) and codfish appearance (concave superior and inferior surfaces) of vertebrae

 

  • Singh’s Index is used for osteoporosis grading.

 

  • Treatment:
    1. Inhibit resorption: Bisphosphonates (drug of choice), Denosumab, calcitonin, estrogen, SERMS, gallium nitrate.
    2. Stimulate formation: Teriparatide (PTH analogue), calcium, calcitriol, fluorides.
    3. Both actions: Strontium ranelate
       
  • Alendronate:
    • Alendronate is approved for the treatment of postmenopausal osteoporosis, steroid-induced osteoporosis, and male osteoporosis.
    • Alendronate belongs to the class of bisphosphonate medications, which aids in the prevention of bone resorption and the promotion of bone density, making it a valuable treatment for osteoporosis.
    • Alendronate is an option for maintaining or increasing bone mass, whereas risedronate is preferred in men with osteoporosis.
    • It inhibit bone resorption at rates 1000 times greater than the effect on bone formation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Calcium and Vitamin D. They are given along with the bisphosphonates but are not the only treatment choice. Calcium is given at a dose of 1500 mg/day. Vitamin D is given at the dose of 400-800 IU per day. Initially, Vit. D deficient patients are treated with active metabolite 1,25, dihydroxy Vit D3 (short half-life 4 hours and expensive) then changing over to longer lasting and less expensive Vit D2 or D3 (t ½ up to 2½ months).

 

Option B. Hormone replacement therapy. The mainstay of bone loss prevention in postmenopausal osteoporosis is estrogen treatment. Daily dose of 0.625 mg of conjugated estrogen in combination with progestins are recommended. Progestin is essential (even though it has no independent effect on bone) to reduce the risk of developing endometrial cancer (due to estrogen).

 

Option D. Repeat DEXA scan after 6 months. The DEXA scan is repeated after 6 months to 1 year after starting of the drug treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alendronate, a drug of class of bisphosphonates is the drug of choice for the treatment of osteoporosis.

questions.text: Identify the cranial nerve passing through the given structure: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. IV

 

Explanation:

 

In the given image, the dorsal aspect of the brainstem is marked and the cranial nerve that is passing there is the trochlear nerve (CN IV).

 

Trochlear nerve

 

  • Origin : The trochlear nerve is the only cranial nerve that emerges from the dorsal (posterior) aspect of the brain. Specifically, it originates from the dorsal surface of the midbrain, below the inferior colliculus.
  • Exit proceed to the superior orbital fissure to enter the orbit.
  • Function: It is a motor nerve that innervates a single extraocular muscle, the superior oblique muscle. The primary action of the superior oblique muscle is to intort (rotate inward), depress, and abduct the eyeball.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oculomotor Nerve (III):

 

  • Origin: The oculomotor nerve originates in the anterior aspect of the midbrain. Specifically, its fibers arise from the oculomotor nucleus, which is located in the superior colliculus of the midbrain.
  • Exit Point: After emerging from the midbrain, it exits the brainstem at the level of the interpeduncular fossa (the space between the cerebral peduncles).
  • Function: It innervates most of the muscles controlling eye movements. It also contains parasympathetic fibers that are involved in pupil constriction and the lens's accommodation.

 

Option B. Facial Nerve (VII):

 

  • Origin: The facial nerve arises from the pons. Specifically, its fibers come from the facial nerve nucleus.
  • Exit Point: It emerges from the brainstem at the cerebellopontine angle, between the pons and the medulla. It exits lateral to the abducens nerve and medial to the vestibulocochlear nerve (VIII).
  • Function: The facial nerve controls the muscles of facial expression. It also has taste fibers from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue and carries parasympathetic fibers to salivary and lacrimal glands.
     

Option D. Abducens Nerve (VI):

 

  • Origin: The abducens nerve originates in the pons. Its fibers arise from the abducens nucleus, which is located in the dorsal pons near the floor of the fourth ventricle.
  • Exit Point: It emerges from the ventral surface of the brainstem at the junction between the pons and the medulla, in the groove between the pons and the pyramid of the medulla.
  • Function: It innervates the lateral rectus muscle, which abducts the eye.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The trochlear nerve is the fourth cranial nerve that originates in the midbrain at the level of the inferior colliculus from the trochlear nuclei. It is the only cranial nerve that emerges from the brainstem's dorsal surface and has the longest intracranial course.

 

The main actions of superior oblique are:

 

  • Depression in adducted position- Patients with trochlear nerve palsy have difficulty in looking downwards when eyes are in the adducted position.
  • Abduction
  • Intorsion of the eyeball.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old male patient was undergoing laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Halfway through the surgery, a sudden drop in EtCO2 to 8 mm Hg was noted. His SpO2 became 90% and blood pressure dropped to 70/50 mmHg and peak airway pressure was 18 cm of H2O. What is the diagnosis?

 

  1. CO2 embolism
  2. Severe bronchospasm
  3. Pneumothorax
  4. Single bronchus intubation

 

EtCO2-End-tidal carbon dioxide
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1 only

 

Explanation:

 

1. CO2 embolism: During laparoscopic procedures, CO2 is used to insufflate the abdomen, creating a pneumoperitoneum. This allows for better visualization and manipulation of the internal structures. If there's a vascular injury, especially to a large vein, CO2 can enter the circulation and cause an embolism. This can lead to sudden cardiovascular collapse and a sharp drop in EtCO2, as observed in the scenario. Also, a sudden drop in oxygen saturation (SpO2) can occur due to the embolism obstructing the pulmonary vasculature. The significant drop in EtCO2, in this case, is indicative of a CO2 embolism.

 

Other Options:

 

2. Severe bronchospasm: Bronchospasm would lead to an increase in peak airway pressure, which wasn't seen in this scenario (the peak airway pressure was 18 cm of H2O, which is within the normal range). Moreover, EtCO2 would generally be elevated in bronchospasm due to retention of CO2, not decreased as seen in the scenario.

 

3. Pneumothorax: A pneumothorax could cause a drop in SpO2 and blood pressure. However, the EtCO2 drop to 8 mm Hg in the setting of laparoscopic surgery more specifically suggests a CO2 embolism. Additionally, one would expect an increase in peak airway pressures with a tension pneumothorax.

 

4. Single bronchus intubation: If the endotracheal tube is advanced too far and intubates a single bronchus, it would lead to ventilation of one lung only. This can cause a decrease in SpO2, but the sudden drop in EtCO2 as seen in the scenario isn't typical for single bronchus intubation.

 

Educational Objective :

 

A sudden and significant drop in EtCO2 during laparoscopic surgery, along with a decrease in SpO2 and blood pressure, strongly suggests a CO2 embolism.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 1879

questions.text: The below-given image is characteristically seen in which of the following type of leprosy? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Borderline leprosy (BB Leprosy)

 

The given image shows a case of borderline leprosy, or dimorphous leprosy, as evidenced by the inverted saucer shaped cutaneous lesions on the patient's skin.

 

Key Characteristics of Borderline Leprosy

 

  • Lesions: Borderline leprosy often presents with numerous skin lesions which may be macular (flat), papular (raised), or annular (ring-shaped) with less defined borders compared to tuberculoid leprosy. The lesions can sometimes exhibit an "inverted saucer" appearance, where the center appears slightly depressed.
  • Symmetry: The lesions tend to be asymmetrical.
  • Sensory Loss: These lesions usually show some sensory loss, although not as pronounced as in tuberculoid leprosy.
  • Reactivity: Borderline leprosy is particularly unstable immunologically, prone to reactivations and shifts toward either more or less severe forms, depending on immune changes in the individual.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Borderline Tuberculoid Leprosy: Closer to the tuberculoid pole with fewer, well-defined lesions and significant nerve involvement.

 

Option B. Lepromatous Leprosy: At the opposite pole from tuberculoid leprosy, characterized by numerous lesions including nodules and plaques, with a high bacterial load but minimal sensory loss.

 

Option D. Histoid Leprosy: A rare variant of lepromatous leprosy presenting as nodules and plaques, often occurring in patients who have experienced leprosy treatment or relapse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Patients with borderline leprosy are at risk for developing reactions like Type 1 (reversal) reactions, which can lead to rapid worsening of lesions and require immediate medical attention.
  • Accurate diagnosis based on clinical presentation, bacterial index, and histopathology is crucial as the treatment duration and regimen may differ based on the type of leprosy. Borderline leprosy is typically treated with multi-drug therapy (MDT), similar to other forms of leprosy.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of Dermatology 9th edition page no 28.3, 28.5, 28.10

questions.text: Identify the pelvic diaphragm in the picture given below: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A

 

The structure marked "A" is the levator ani muscle which is the component of pelvic diaphragm.

 

Other structures marked in the above image are:

 

B: External anal sphincter

C: Obturator internus

D: Perianal fascia

 

Pelvic diaphragm -

 

The pelvic diaphragm is the muscular part of the pelvic floor. It connects to the pelvic wall on both sides, between the greater and lesser sciatic foramen. The pelvic diaphragm is formed by the levator ani and coccyges muscles, which define the lower limit of the true pelvis.

 

 

Pubococcygeus, iliococcygeus, and puborectalis combine to form Levator ani. The muscles in both sexes blend together posterior to the vagina and around the anus. The form in which the anococcygeal body attaches to the coccyx posterior to the anal aperture.

 

Urogenital hiatus is present anteriorly separating the muscles. This allows the urethra and vagina to pass through. Levator ani reinforces the external anal sphincter. In women, it functions as the vaginal sphincter.

 

The coccyges muscles are triangular in shape and form the posterior part of the pelvic diaphragm, one on each side. The apices are attached to the ischial spine tips. The bases connect to the coccyx and sacrum.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sphincter Ani Externus (External Anal Sphincter): This is a circular muscle that surrounds the anus. It's located below the level of the levator ani. It is innervated by the pudendal nerve, allowing for voluntary control over defecation.

 

Option C. Obturator Muscle: This term often refers to two muscles - obturator externus and obturator internus. They are situated on either side of the obturator membrane in the pelvis. Obturator Externus: Obturator nerve and Obturator Internus: Nerve to obturator internus (a branch of the sacral plexus).

 

Option D. Perianal Fascia: The perianal fascia is not a muscle but is the connective tissue located in the perianal region, around the anus. It's part of the deeper layers of the skin in this region.  It's associated with various potential spaces that can become sites of abscess formation if there's an infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The levator ani is the principal muscle of the pelvic floor and is composed of three parts: the puborectalis, the pubococcygeus, and the iliococcygeus. It is primarily innervated by the pudendal nerve and the S4 nerve root.

questions.text: Which among the following is not used in post laryngectomy rehabilitation?(INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Super supraglottic swallow

 

Super supraglottic swallow is not used in post laryngectomy rehabilitation but in dysphagia to prevent aspiration of food.

 

The Super-Supraglottic Swallow technique is employed for patients experiencing diminished airway closure. To perform this technique, patients are directed to take a deep breath and tightly hold it while bearing down. They should maintain this breath hold and bear down as they swallow. Immediately after the swallow (before inhaling), they are instructed to cough, followed by a forceful swallow once more (before inhaling). This sequence is aimed at enhancing airway protection during swallowing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A tracheoesophageal prosthesis (TEP) is a one-way valve inserted through a tracheoesophageal puncture. Occlusion of the stoma shunts the exhaled air through the TEP into the esophagus producing vibration of the upper esophageal sphincter resulting in phonation.

Option B. Esophageal speech is phonation produced by vibration of the upper esophageal sphincter.

 

Option C. Polite yawning also called nasal airflow-inducing maneuver is indicated for olfaction rehabilitation post laryngectomy. This maneuver induces a negative pressure in the oral cavity and oropharynx, which generates a nasal airflow, enabling odorous substances to reach the olfactory epithelium again.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Super supraglottic swallow technique is crucial for enhancing airway protection in dysphagia management but is not utilized in post-laryngectomy rehabilitation, where the focus is primarily on restoring voice and smell functions through other specialized techniques.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition 352, 353; Scott Brown 7th edition, Volume 2, Page No. 2090

questions.text: Which of the following jugular venous pressure (JVP) waves corresponds to the isovolumetric contraction phase of the cardiac cycle? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) c wave

 

The jugular venous pressure (JVP) waveform consists of multiple waves that correspond to different phases of the cardiac cycle.

 

The "c" wave corresponds to the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during ventricular contraction, causing a brief increase in pressure in the right atrium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The "a" wave corresponds to the atrial contraction, which occurs during the isovolumetric contraction phase of the cardiac cycle. This is the period between the closure of the mitral valve and the opening of the aortic valve, during which the ventricle is contracting and building up pressure, but no blood is being ejected yet. The "a" wave is caused by the contraction of the atrium against a closed tricuspid valve, leading to a brief increase in right atrial pressure.

 

Option C. The "x" descent corresponds to the descent of the tricuspid valve ring during ventricular contraction, which pulls the right atrium downward.

 

Option D. The "y" descent corresponds to the rapid emptying of the right atrium into the right ventricle during ventricular diastole.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "c" wave of the jugular venous pressure waveform corresponds to the isovolumetric contraction phase of the cardiac cycle, reflecting the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium as the right ventricle begins to contract.

choices.text: Nicotine gum

questions.text: Which of the following is the most effective drug in smoking cessation?(INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Varenicline

 

Varenicline is the most effective drug in smoking cessation. Varenicline is a partial agonist at the α4β2 nicotinic receptors. It is one of the 1st line oral drugs that is used for smoking cessation. The other drugs are Bupropion, even Nicotine replacement in the form of gums, lozenge, patch, spray can also be used.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Buspirone: Primarily used for the treatment of anxiety disorders, buspirone is not used for smoking cessation. Bupropion is used for smoking cessation.

 

Option C. Nicotine gum: As a form of nicotine replacement therapy (NRT), nicotine gum helps to reduce withdrawal symptoms and cravings by supplying a small amount of nicotine. While effective for many people, it may be less effective than prescription medications like varenicline, especially for heavy smokers.

 

Option D. Rimonabant: This drug was initially developed as an anti-obesity medication and was found to also have some effect on smoking cessation. However, it was withdrawn from the market due to psychiatric side effects, including depression and suicidal thoughts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Varenicline is the most effective medication for smoking cessation. It works as a partial agonist at nicotinic receptors, helping to alleviate withdrawal symptoms and reduce the rewarding effects of nicotine. This makes it a highly effective option for individuals seeking to quit smoking.

questions.text: In a village, the residents find a new groundwater source. After intake of water from this source many villagers presented with nausea, vomiting, dark bloody stools, conjunctivitis, and a burning sensation in the throat and stomach. Which poisoning do you suspect in this case? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Arsenic

 

The given clinical scenario points towards arsenic poisoning

 

Causes of arsenic poisoning: Arsenic poisoning occurs most often in major areas of agriculture and industrialization. It occurs through contaminated groundwater, air, soil or food.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Potassium permanganate: Typically causes caustic injuries, including severe mucosal burns upon ingestion, but not the full range of symptoms described.

 

Option C. Thallium: Causes symptoms such as gastrointestinal distress, neurological symptoms, and hair loss, but does not match the full clinical picture described.

 

Option D. Lead: Lead poisoning causes anemia, abdominal pain, neurological symptoms, and kidney damage, but does not match the described symptoms of conjunctivitis and burning sensation in the throat and stomach.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: 30 minutes
60 minutes
90 minutes

questions.text: A patient is on phenytoin for a seizure disorder. He was prescribed sucralfate 4 times a day for peptic ulcers. What should be the minimum duration of time between consumption of these drugs? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 120 minutes

 

  • Sucralfate is made up of aluminium octosulphate of sucrose. In the acidic pH of the stomach, it gets polymerized into a viscous fluid which adheres to the base of the ulcer for upto 6 hours. However, this viscous layer prevents the absorption of other drugs like phenytoin, ketoconazole, fluoroquinolones etc. from the stomach.
  • When a patient is taking both phenytoin (an antiepileptic drug) and sucralfate (a medication used to treat peptic ulcers), it's important to manage the timing of these medications to avoid drug interactions.
  • Sucralfate can interfere with the absorption of phenytoin when taken too closely together, leading to reduced effectiveness of phenytoin.
  • The general recommendation is to separate the administration of these two drugs by at least 2 hours. This separation allows sufficient time for the phenytoin to be absorbed before the sucralfate is taken, which can bind to drugs in the gastrointestinal tract and hinder their absorption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The minimum duration of time between the consumption of phenytoin and sucralfate should be at least 120 minutes (2 hours) to ensure that phenytoin is adequately absorbed and to avoid interactions that could reduce its effectiveness.

choices.text: Safety in pregnancy
Dose adjustment in renal failure
Cost ratio from cheap to expensive
As per safety or therapeutic index

questions.text: Category A, B, C, D, X in drug classification is indicative of which of the following?(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Safety in pregnancy

 

The categories A, B, C, D, and X are used to classify drugs based on their safety during pregnancy. This classification helps in determining the potential risk of medications to the fetus when taken during pregnancy.

 

Pregnancy drug category, which are indicative of their safety are as follows:

 

Category A > B > C > D > X

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dose adjustment in renal failure: Drug classifications for dose adjustments in renal failure typically involve guidelines based on the drug's pharmacokinetics and renal clearance. These guidelines are not categorized as A, B, C, D, X.

 

Option C. Cost ratio from cheap to expensive: Drug classifications based on cost are not typically denoted by the categories A, B, C, D, X. Cost-related classifications might be discussed in economic terms or based on generic versus brand name distinctions.

 

Option D. As per safety or therapeutic index: The therapeutic index of a drug, which measures its safety margin, is not categorized using the A, B, C, D, X system. The therapeutic index is a ratio comparing the toxic dose to the therapeutic dose, but it is not classified in this alphabetical manner.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The classification of drugs into categories A, B, C, D, and X is specifically used to indicate their safety during pregnancy, helping healthcare providers to make informed decisions about medication use in pregnant patients.

choices.text: 2-10 mcg/kg/min
< 2 mcg/kg/min
10-20 mcg/kg/min

questions.text: The dose at which dopamine acts on beta 1 receptors is:(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 2-10 mcg/kg/min

 

2-10 mcg/kg/min is the correct dose range at which dopamine primarily acts on beta 1 receptors in the heart, enhancing cardiac output by increasing heart rate and contractility.

 

Dopamine acts upon 3 receptors depending upon the dose:

 

D1 – < 2 mcg/kg/min (Present in the blood vessels of the kidney in highest concentration - Vasodilation and increased renal blood flow)

 

β1 – 2-10 mcg/kg/min (Present in the heart - Increased heart rate and contractility, which improves cardiac output)

 

α1 – >10 mcg/kg/min (Present in blood vessels - Vasoconstriction, which increases blood pressure).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. < 2 mcg/kg/min: At this dose, dopamine primarily acts on D1 receptors, causing vasodilation and increased renal blood flow without significant effects on the heart.

 

Option C. 10-20 mcg/kg/min: At this higher dose, dopamine acts predominantly on alpha 1 receptors, causing vasoconstriction and increased blood pressure.

 

Option D. > 20 mcg/kg/min: Similar to the previous option, at doses higher than 20 mcg/kg/min, dopamine continues to exert effects primarily on alpha 1 receptors, resulting in significant vasoconstriction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dopamine has dose-dependent receptor selectivity. It acts on beta 1 receptors at doses of 2-10 mcg/kg/min, increasing cardiac output by enhancing heart rate and contractility.

choices.text: RNA-dependent DNA polymerase inhibition
RNA-dependent RNA polymerase inhibition
Fusion inhibition

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of remdesivir? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. RNA-dependent RNA polymerase inhibition
 

  • Remdesivir is the only FDA approved drug for COVID-19, which is recommended for moderate to severe COVID-19 patients, hospitalized patients, patients on oxygen therapy and should be used within 10 days of disease onset, after which it has no proven benefit.
  • It inhibits RNA-dependent RNA polymerase.
  • While on treatment, monitoring of LFT, KFT and PT are required. It should be avoided in pregnant or lactating females, patients less than 12 years of age, if eGFR <30ml/min or ALT>5 times.
  • Adverse effects include anaphylaxis, nausea and infusion related reactions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. RNA-dependent DNA polymerase inhibition: This mechanism is not relevant for remdesivir. RNA-dependent DNA polymerase inhibition is associated with drugs targeting retroviruses, like reverse transcriptase inhibitors used in HIV treatment.

 

Option C. Fusion inhibition: Fusion inhibitors prevent the virus from fusing with the host cell membrane, thereby blocking entry into the cell. This is not the mechanism of remdesivir. An example of a fusion inhibitor is enfuvirtide, used in HIV treatment.

 

Option D. Entry inhibition: Entry inhibitors block the virus from entering the host cell. This is also not the mechanism of action for remdesivir. An example of an entry inhibitor is maraviroc, which is used in HIV treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Remdesivir works by inhibiting RNA-dependent RNA polymerase, thus preventing viral RNA replication in COVID-19 patients. It is important to monitor liver and kidney function during treatment and be aware of its contraindications and potential adverse effects.

questions.text: Anionic and weakly acidic drugs bind to which of the following? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Albumin

 

  • Anionic and weakly acidic drugs bind to albumin whereas basic /cationic drugs bind to α1 acid glycoprotein.
  • E.g., of drugs that bind to albumin are Aspirin, Barbiturates, Methotrexate.
  • E.g., of drugs that bind to α1 acid glycoprotein are Atropine, morphine, amphetamine etc

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Globulin: Globulins are another class of plasma proteins but are not the primary binding proteins for anionic and weakly acidic drugs. They are involved more in immune functions and binding specific hormones and metal ions.

 

Option C. Lipoprotein: Lipoproteins are complexes that transport lipids in the blood. They are not typically involved in binding anionic and weakly acidic drugs.

 

Option D. Alpha-1 glycoprotein: Alpha-1 glycoprotein (or alpha-1 acid glycoprotein) binds primarily to basic or cationic drugs, not to anionic and weakly acidic drugs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anionic and weakly acidic drugs bind predominantly to albumin in the plasma. This binding affects their pharmacokinetics, distribution, and overall bioavailability.

choices.text: Hemophilus alters penicillin binding protein sites, hence resistant to ampicillin
Easier to administer IV ceftriaxone than IV ampicillin
Cotrimoxazole is the drug of choice, but patient is allergic to sulfa drugs
Hemophilus produces beta lactamase, hence resistant to ampicillin

questions.text: A 14-month-old boy was diagnosed with Hemophilus influenza meningitis. The initial treatment plan was to start on ampicillin but later was shifted to ceftriaxone. What could be the probable reason? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Hemophilus produces beta lactamase, hence resistant to ampicillin  

 

Hemophilus influenzae, particularly some strains, can produce beta-lactamase, an enzyme that breaks down the beta-lactam ring found in penicillins (like ampicillin) and some other antibiotics. This enzymatic activity renders these bacteria resistant to the effects of these antibiotics. Due to the increasing prevalence of beta-lactamase-producing H. influenzae, the use of ampicillin alone is often not recommended for serious infections like meningitis. Ceftriaxone, a third-generation cephalosporin, is a preferred choice as it is more resistant to beta-lactamase and has good central nervous system penetration, which is essential for the treatment of meningitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemophilus alters penicillin-binding protein sites, hence resistant to ampicillin: While changes in penicillin-binding proteins can confer resistance to beta-lactam antibiotics, this is not the primary mechanism of resistance in H. influenzae. The major concern is beta-lactamase production.

 

Option B. Easier to administer IV ceftriaxone than IV ampicillin: While the ease of administration might be a consideration in some cases (ceftriaxone can be given once a day due to its long half-life), the primary concern in this scenario is antibiotic efficacy and resistance patterns, not the convenience of administration.

 

Option C. Cotrimoxazole is the drug of choice, but the patient is allergic to sulfa drugs: Cotrimoxazole (trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole) is not the primary drug of choice for H. influenzae meningitis. The first-line treatment is usually a third-generation cephalosporin like ceftriaxone or cefotaxime.

 

Therefore, the most probable reason for switching from ampicillin to ceftriaxone in this case is the beta-lactamase production by H. influenzae, making it resistant to ampicillin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary reason for switching from ampicillin to ceftriaxone in the treatment of Hemophilus influenzae meningitis is the production of beta-lactamase by H. influenzae, which renders the bacteria resistant to ampicillin. Ceftriaxone is more resistant to beta-lactamase and provides effective CNS penetration, making it a more suitable choice for treating bacterial meningitis.

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of cirrhosis of the liver presents with abdominal distension and swelling of the lower limbs. The preferred diuretic for this patient would be?(INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Eplerenone

 

  • Eplerenone is a mineralocorticoid (Aldosterone) receptor antagonist and a potassium sparing diuretic. In a patient of cirrhosis, there is splanchnic vasodilation, due to which there is decreased effective arterial blood volume. This stimulates the RAAS axis and as a result, the levels of Aldosterone are increased. Aldosterone ultimately leads to increased absorption of Na+ and water from the late distal tubules and collecting ducts along with excretion of K+ and H+ into the lumen.
  • This increased sodium and water retention leads to the development of ascites and edema.
  • Eplerenone, like Spironolactone, blocks this action of Aldosterone and leads to natriuresis and diuresis, without causing loss of K+. Therefore, it is the preferred drug in this patient.
  • It is important to note that in clinical practice, a combination of a loop diuretic (like furosemide) and an aldosterone antagonist (like spironolactone or eplerenone) is typically used for managing ascites and peripheral edema in cirrhosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Triamterene: Triamterene is also a potassium-sparing diuretic, but it works by blocking sodium channels in the distal nephron. It is less effective than aldosterone antagonists like eplerenone in managing ascites related to cirrhosis.

 

Option C. Chlorthalidone: Chlorthalidone is a thiazide-like diuretic that inhibits sodium reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule. Thiazide diuretics are not as effective in the setting of cirrhosis with ascites and are not typically used for this purpose.

 

Option D. Acetazolamide: Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that acts on the proximal tubule. It is used primarily to treat metabolic alkalosis and glaucoma, and is not suitable for treating ascites and peripheral edema in cirrhosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eplerenone, as a mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist and potassium-sparing diuretic, is the preferred choice for managing ascites and peripheral edema in patients with cirrhosis due to its ability to counteract the effects of elevated aldosterone levels.

questions.text: A patient who was receiving warfarin therapy for atrial fibrillation was prescribed a cephalosporin antibiotic to treat a lower respiratory tract infection. He returned to the hospital after developing hemarthrosis. Which of the following cephalosporins is most likely to have caused this? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Cefoperazone

 

  • The development of hemarthrosis (bleeding into a joint) in a patient on warfarin therapy, after starting a cephalosporin antibiotic, raises concerns about drug interactions that can potentiate the anticoagulant effect of warfarin.
  • Warfarin inhibits the enzyme Vitamin K Epoxide Reductase (VKOR) which in turn inhibits the gamma carboxylation of Glutamic acid residues of factors II, VII , IX and X.
  • Cefoperazone is a 3rd generation cephalosporin that contains methylthiotetrazole (MTT) group. This also inhibits the VKOR enzyme, just like warfarin. Therefore, in a patient who is already on warfarin therapy, this can lead to bleeding manifestations.
  • Cefotetan, Cefamandole are other cephalosporins that contain the MTT group.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cefixime: This is a third-generation cephalosporin and is not known to have a significant interaction with warfarin that would increase the risk of bleeding.

 

Option C. Ceftobiprole: As a newer cephalosporin, ceftobiprole is not commonly associated with significant interactions with warfarin that would lead to increased bleeding risk.

 

Option D. Ceftazidime: This is another third-generation cephalosporin, and like cefixime, it is not commonly associated with interactions that significantly enhance the anticoagulant effect of warfarin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cefoperazone is the cephalosporin most likely to cause hemarthrosis in a patient on warfarin therapy due to its MTT group, which can inhibit the VKOR enzyme and potentiate the anticoagulant effects of warfarin. Other cephalosporins like cefixime, ceftobiprole, and ceftazidime do not have this interaction and are less likely to cause such bleeding complications.

questions.text: Which of the following is a novel anti-depressant? (INICET Nov 2021
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Vilazodone

 

Vilazodone is a Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitor as well as a 5HT1A receptor partial agonist. It is a new antidepressant. It does not have the side effect of erectile dysfunction.

 

Vortioxetine is another example of a novel antidepressant, that apart from being a SSRI, acts on multiple other receptors of serotonin.

 

Other Options:

 

Lurasidone, Asenapine and Pimavanserin are examples of atypical antipsychotics.

 

Option A. Lurasidone: This is an atypical antipsychotic, primarily used in the treatment of schizophrenia and bipolar disorder. While it can be used to treat depressive episodes in bipolar disorder, it is not primarily categorized as an antidepressant.

 

Option C. Asenapine: Asenapine is an atypical antipsychotic used to treat schizophrenia and bipolar disorder. It is not classified as an antidepressant.

 

Option D. Pimavanserin: This is an atypical antipsychotic and inverse agonist and antagonist of the serotonin receptors. It is primarily used in the treatment of psychosis in patients with Parkinson’s disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vilazodone is a novel antidepressant with a dual mechanism of action, functioning as both an SSRI and a 5HT1A receptor partial agonist, making it effective for treating depression with fewer sexual side effects. Other Options listed are atypical antipsychotics and not classified as antidepressants.

questions.text: Which of the following is a centrally acting opioid antitussive?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Levopropoxyphene

 

  • Propoxyphene has two isomers: Levopropoxyphene and Dextropropoxyphene. Levopropoxyphene is a centrally acting opioid antitussive. It is an opioid derivative that acts centrally as a strong and partial µ receptor agonist and helps to reduce the cough reflex. It has no analgesic property but can cause some degree of sedation. Please note that the other isomer dextropropoxyphene is mainly used as an analgesic.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ambroxol is derived from bromhexine. It increases mucociliary clearance, thereby providing relief in productive cough. Thus it is primarily used as a mucolytic (not anti-tussive). Further it is not an opioid.

 

Option B. Diphenoxylate or Loperamide is indicated for non-infective diarrhea. These are not used as anti-tussive.

 

Option D. Levorphanol is a synthetic opioid which is chiefly used in the management of moderate to severe pain. It also have some anti-tussive properties similar to codeine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Levopropoxyphene is a centrally acting opioid specifically used for its antitussive properties. While levorphanol is also an opioid with antitussive effects, it is more commonly used for pain relief. Levopropoxyphene's primary indication as an antitussive makes it the most appropriate choice among the given options.

questions.text:
The anti-epileptic drugs which can also be used for the treatment of neuropathic pain are: (INICET Nov 2021)

 

1. Pregabalin

2. Carbamazepine

3. Lamotrigine

4. Gabapentin
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 1, 2 and 4

 

The question relates to the use of certain anti-epileptic drugs (AEDs) for the treatment of neuropathic pain.

 

  1. Pregabalin: This is an AED that's also commonly used for neuropathic pain. It works by binding to calcium channels in the central nervous system and reducing the release of neurotransmitters. It is used in the management of neuropathic pain associated with diabetic peripheral neuropathy, spinal cord injury or postherpetic neuralgia.

 

  1. Carbamazepine: Initially used as an anti-seizure medication, carbamazepine is also effective for certain types of neuropathic pain, particularly trigeminal neuralgia.

 

4. Gabapentin: Similar to pregabalin, gabapentin is used both as an AED and for the treatment of neuropathic pain. It also affects calcium channels and reduces neurotransmitter release. It is mainly used in the management of neuropathic pain due to postherpetic neuralgia in adults.

 

Other Options:

 

  1. Lamotrigine: While lamotrigine is an AED, its use in neuropathic pain is less established compared to pregabalin and carbamazepine. It may have some efficacy, but it's not a first-line treatment for neuropathic pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pregabalin, carbamazepine, and gabapentin are anti-epileptic drugs that are also effective in treating neuropathic pain. These medications are utilized not only for seizure control but also for managing various forms of chronic pain associated with nerve damage.

questions.text: A chronic smoker presented with shortness of breath, bilateral pitting pedal edema, and abdominal distension. On examination, jugular venous pulse was found to be elevated and liver was palpable 8 cm below the costal margin. An abnormality in which of the following structures is responsible for the patient's symptoms? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Right Ventricle

 

The patient’s presentation is characteristic of right ventricular failure, often secondary to chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) in chronic smokers.

 

Key clinical features include:

 

  • Shortness of breath: A common symptom in both left and right heart failure but is notably worsened by right heart failure due to fluid overload.
  • Bilateral pitting pedal edema: Indicates fluid retention, a hallmark of right ventricular failure.
  • Abdominal distension: Often due to ascites, which is related to increased venous pressure.
  • Elevated jugular venous pulse (JVP): Reflects increased central venous pressure due to right heart dysfunction.
  • Hepatomegaly (enlarged liver): Due to congestion of blood in the liver secondary to increased venous pressure.

 

Right ventricular failure results from the right ventricle's inability to pump blood effectively to the lungs, leading to a backup of blood in the systemic venous system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Left Ventricle: Left ventricular failure primarily causes pulmonary congestion and edema due to the backflow of blood into the lungs. Symptoms like shortness of breath would predominate without the systemic venous congestion (e.g., pedal edema, elevated JVP, hepatomegaly) seen in right ventricular failure.

 

Option C. Aorta: An aortic abnormality would not directly cause the combination of symptoms described. Issues with the aorta generally result in systemic hypertension, aortic aneurysm, or dissection, which have different clinical presentations.

 

Option D. Mitral Valve: Mitral valve disease, particularly mitral stenosis or regurgitation, primarily affects the left atrium and ventricle, leading to pulmonary congestion and symptoms more indicative of left heart failure rather than the systemic congestion seen here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Right ventricular failure is characterized by systemic venous congestion, which manifests as elevated jugular venous pressure, pitting pedal edema, hepatomegaly, and abdominal distension. This condition is often seen in chronic smokers due to the impact of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) on the heart.

questions.text: All of the following increase gastric acid secretion except:
questions.solution:
Ans.  D) Serotonin

 

  • Serotonin does not increase gastric acid secretion. It is primarily located in the enterochromaffin cells of the gastrointestinal (GI) mucosa and neurons of the GI tract, where it inhibits gastric acid secretion and stimulates the production and release of gastric and colonic mucus. Serotonin acts as an enteric neurotransmitter and increases intestinal motility.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Gastrin: Gastrin is a significant stimulator of gastric acid secretion, released by G-cells in the stomach in response to eating, which stimulates the secretion of hydrochloric acid by parietal cells.

 

Option B. Histamine: Released locally by enterochromaffin-like cells, histamine strongly stimulates acid secretion by parietal cells in the stomach through the H2 receptors.

 

Option C. Acetylcholine: Released by parasympathetic nerve fibers, acetylcholine enhances gastric acid secretion by directly stimulating parietal cells.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The key learning point is to recognize the role of various substances in the regulation of gastric acid secretion. Understanding these pathways is essential for the management of conditions like peptic ulcer disease, where control of acid secretion can be crucial for effective treatment.
